movie_review_blurb: Murphy steals every scene he's in with equal parts bounce and warmth.
An amusing scenario, until even Miike seems to lose his taste for the oddly sweet concoction and allows the film to drift aimlessly to a rainbow-hued finale.
Torem drifts into formula and his initially promising film goes unbearably soft.
While the film throws a solid pop punch, you could still swear you've seen it all before.
On top of a foundering performance, [Madonna's] denied her own athleticism by lighting that emphasizes every line and sag.
Guillen rarely gets beneath the surface of things. She lists ingredients, but never mixes and stirs.
[It has] a humanist touch that stands at odds with the film's wholesale demonizing of the scattered Soviet army.
Your taste for Jonah - A Veggie Tales Movie may well depend on your threshold for pop manifestations of the Holy Spirit.

It would all be too obviously feel-good if Ducastel and Martineau weren't also tuned in to the liberating drift of the open highway and a sharp native humor that adds needed flesh and blood to their walking metaphors.
The film's intimate camera work and searing performances pull us deep into the girls' confusion and pain as they struggle tragically to comprehend the chasm of knowledge that's opened between them.
The film lapses too often into sugary sentiment and withholds delivery on the pell-mell pyrotechnics its punchy style promises.

While much of the film's action ... comes live, as opposed to the digital mayhem of the game, Thai director Kaos (a.k.a. Wych Kaosayananda), making his inauspicious Hollywood debut, still can't breathe any life into it.
Why Crop Circles now, if not to ride the hype of M. Night Shyamalan's Signs to some quick cash? The movie's rambling, slapdash, repetitious nature suggests as much.

Thomas trudges through the film's action sequences with such obvious disinterest that when Wilson turns from a lackluster fireball to quip, 'Whoa, that was a big explosion,' you really know he's putting us on.
Hartnett's pitch-perfect sexual panic can be hilariously funny.
Dismally dull sci-fi comedy.
The film's plainness, and the understated force of van der Groen and Petersen's performances, sharpen its complexity of feeling until all mawkishness is cut away.
A deft exercise in atmospheric horror and insanity.
Diesel smolders as bad boy with spy toys Xander Cage.
The director has fixed this Arctic potboiler, passed down through the ages as part of a rich oral tradition, onto digital video with ... breathtaking punch and such a sweeping sense of immediacy.
Jericho and Hester spend so much time on investigative idylls in the damp spring countryside that spy work starts to seem like a military garden party.
The premise for this kegger comedy probably sounded brilliant four six-packs and a pitcher of margaritas in, but the film must have been written ... in the thrall of a vicious hangover.
What's most striking about this largely celebratory film ... is the sense of isolation that permeates these bastions of individuality in an Ikea world.
The gore comes with brutal regularity, so that, despite Farmer and Isaac's attempts to liven things up, the film still just wears you down.
Serves as further evidence that Argentina's film industry is at the forefront of a resurgent Latin American cinema.

Far from a shattering blow to my faith in Star Wars, I believe that in time these new films will only make it stronger.

movie_review_blurb: It's supposed to be post-feminist breezy but ends up as tedious as the chatter of parrots raised on Oprah.
movie_title: Amy's O (Amy's Orgasm) (Why Love Doesn't Work) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Best wear a helmet and have some fun.
Plays like a refreshing return to that point in the mid-1990s before independent film had been co-opted by corporate subsidiaries.

[A] fascinating, evenhanded documentary.
[Director] Yeung handles [his characters'] parallel journeys of self-discovery with humor, grace and an occasionally heavy hand, with Leow giving a winning performance as Ash.
It's easy to keep blaming Ken Burns for this kind of softcore Civil War porn, but enough is enough: This is a vanity project of the most indulgent order.
movie_title: The Last Confederate: The Story of Robert Adams (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Such artless inattention to the con man's craft might be overlooked if any of the characters or performers had the personality to pull one over on us, the audience.
It's a setup as old as the hills, but the unvarnished simplicity with which first-time director Benjamin Morgan rolls it out makes the tale worth another go-round.
This 'true account' of the Bell Witch haunting offers an encyclopedic rehash of spook films new and old, dressed out in murky period detail.
A conventional if appealing tear-jerker.
in The Squid and the Whale, Noah Baumbach weds his verbal gifts to a fresh visual acuity that brings layers of rich detail to a portrait of a family coping, poorly, with self-inflicted change.

It's the zippy chatter among the Serenity's wised-up space pirates that gives the film most of its punch, but with only serviceable action sequences and largely cookie-cutter effects, you can still sense the void just outside.
Gordon gives an intimate, balanced account of how political power, famine, power shortages and a hatred of America have shaped their young lives.
Prominently placed in Jaque's bachelor pad is a poster for Down by Law, but it's abundantly clear that Lozano and company have been re-watching Pulp Fiction for the last decade.
As a salvo in the culture wars, Dukes of Hazzard is a dud, and as an actual movie it doesn't rate much higher.
The Giants' longevity flows from the fact that they can't be explained, only experienced.
A film riddled with missed opportunities for good clean scares.
It's a refreshing change from the self-interest and paranoia that shape most American representations of Castro.

Vaughan brings such disregard to the film that its pedestrian on-court action might as well have been shot from the bleacher seats.
Disney's most winning animated couple since Bambi and Thumper.
Stinks from start to finish, like a wet burlap sack of gloom.
Moving and, ultimately, hopeful -- a hope that extends further than most documentaries allow.
Nemesis never feels true to itself, its energy never fully engaged.
Too sincere to exploit its subjects and too honest to manipulate its audience.
Rather quickly, the film falls into a soothing formula of brotherly conflict and reconciliation.
Pushes the Hollywood action movie to stratospheric new levels of incoherence.
Despite the film's aspirations to soul healing, its uplift remains mechanical, like an escalator's.
It can't shake the impression of a video premiere stretched to big-screen size.
A one-way ticket to Palookaville.
A captivating coming-of-age story that may also be the first narrative film to be truly informed by the wireless age.
Solaris is what you'd call a "thinking person's sci-fi film," and it has all the strengths and weaknesses that that term implies.

Never do you get the feeling that anybody is in any real danger, or that there's any real attraction between Newton and Wahlberg-and when you're making a caper film that doesn't have any suspense or romance in it, there's not a hell of a lot else left for
Arthouse hokum.

It's hard to imagine anybody ever being "in the mood" to view a movie as harrowing and painful as The Grey Zone, but it's equally hard to imagine anybody being able to tear their eyes away from the screen once it's started.
Writer/director Burr Steers displays a pitch-perfect sense of the way Igby is at once repelled by his family and his upbringing and yet an unmistakable product of it.
Nothing in Gore Verbinski's previous résumé indicated he had the ability to create the lingering atmosphere of low-key dread he displays in The Ring.
Amounts to little more than a waterlogged teenage version of Fatal Attraction.
Secretary isn't a movie about humiliation or depravity at all; it's a dizzy fairytale about two people who help each other to stop feeling ashamed of the very things that give them pleasure.
Reese Witherspoon is such a skilled comedienne that it's a shame that people seem to prefer seeing her in films like Sweet Home Alabama, which are completely unworthy of her talents.

Reign of Fire contains several scenes in which the screen is filled with immense fire-breathing dragons, but you don't feel the slightest twinge of awe or fear for the size of these creatures or their incredible destructive powers.
A small thing can have large significance: that's a nice theme for a children's film to have.
The surprising thing about Mostly Martha is not that it dodges the clichés it sets up... but that its fulfillment of those clichés, and the warmth you feel as a result, seem so honestly earned.
This thing is virtually unwatchable.
One of the oddest and most inexplicable sequels in movie history.
movie_title: American Psycho II: All American Girl (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The Audition DVD includes a director's audio commentary for the final half-hour. You may as well turn the commentary on-you'll be clamping your eyes shut for most of it anyway.
Couldn't someone take Rob Schneider and have him switch bodies with a funny person?

Happy Times sounds like any of the dozens of heart-tugging comedies that Miramax seems to release every month, but it has such a peculiar premise and the central performance by Zhao Benshan is so winning that Zhang gets away with it by the skin of

Like many Disney films, Little Otik is based on a classic European folktale, but while Disney cleans these stories up into candy-coloured moral fables ready to be adapted into breakfast cereals and ice shows, Svankmajer eagerly plunges into their d
Capped by a final plot twist so insane I almost feel obligated to salute it out of respect for its sheer lunacy.
Birth is the beigest, most suffocatingly tasteful film I've seen since Woody Allen's Another Woman.
Stage Beauty pretends to be a celebration of acting, but in fact it's saying you'll be happiest if you go through life playing the most conventional role you can find.
To quote the haunting Damien Rice song that bookends the film, you can't take your eyes off of it.
You can't stop thinking about how awful Bale looks-partly because his transformation is so unnerving, but also because the film doesn't give you anything else to think about.
The Return feels like an experiment designed to find out how much basic plot information you can withhold from an audience and still have an interesting movie.
The notion that being stalked can lead to a spiritual rebirth is pretty goofy, but Enduring Love is skillful enough to make it seem like a reasonable proposition.
I don't think you could ask more from a biopic than what Bill Condon accomplishes with Kinsey.
There's a rock-solid authenticity to every scene of The Pianist that seems utterly unquestionable to me.
Standing in the Shadows of Motown takes one of the great unknown stories in music history and translates it to the screen in the blandest way possible.
movie_title: Standing in the Shadows of Motown (2002)

movie_review_blurb: I can't say as I was surprised by a single scene in Evelyn, and yet, despite all the manipulations of the script, the film is so sincere and good-hearted that it won me over anyway.
Anyone in the mood for a gender-bending yakuza comedy/horror film and who doesn't mind seeing a lot of bodily fluids spewing onto the screen ought to give Gozu a whirl.
Notorious C.H.O. made me laugh as long and hard as any movie I've seen this year.

If you want a poster-friendly snippet, Alan Partridge: Alpha Papa is a truly splendid British export, fit to burst with character, idea, charm and heart and not to be missed by anyone who's partial to the sheer joy of quality comedy.
Heartfelt and thorough yet lean and effortless, Iron Man 3 is nothing short of the best Marvel Studios film to date and a triumph for Shane Black and Robert Downey Jr.
The Martian is a breathtakingly bravura piece of film-making.
A gorgeous, lavish Gothic thriller which is part Hammer horror, part classic Roger Corman and, in the end, absolutely Guillermo del Toro.
The Lobster is a bit of everything. At times it's hilarious, especially in its first half-hour or so, sometimes it's deeply disturbing and occasionally thought-provoking.
This one's dead in the water.
A haunting, uncomfortable, occasionally voyeuristic movie, which ultimately serves as a life-affirming evocation of the durability and resilience of the human spirit. Brilliant.
Scouts Guide isn't good enough to qualify as a guilty pleasure but it gets an extra mark or two just for its zombie cats... that's something you don't see in The Walking Dead.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Moretz acquits herself well as the no-nonsense Cassie, forced to grow up quickly in terrible circumstances - but it never shifts out of first gear.
It's really more of a miss than a hit, man.
Although Ghost Dimension offers the series' fans some sort of closure it's all a bit limp and lame and can't offer up even the mildest of scares.
American Ultra isn't really able to live up to the potential of its principal conceit and whilst it hasn't found much favour at the Box Office we suspect it'll develop into a bit of a cult favourite.

Gunn keeps the action moving at a pace that's sometimes exhausting but amidst all the explosions and the crashing spaceships and exploding cityscapes there's usually room for a quick quip or laugh-out-loud gag.
Pixels just isn't funny -- at all -- and it's forced to resort to simple knockabout humour, unsophisticated wordplay and childish slapstick.
This is fairly generic, predictable stuff.
Maggie is magnificent -- but in ways we might never have expected from a film toplined by the former Governor of California.

McQuarrie has created a clever, witty, exciting modern espionage thriller which not only pays its dues to the earlier titles in the series, but also tacitly acknowledges that Ethan himself is starting to get a little long in the tooth.
It's a shameful waste of time.
Fast, fun-packed (but never frivolous) and riotously, raucously enjoyable.
Big and blousy, brash and loud and with a distinct twinkle in its star-spangled eye, it's the action movie to see if you really can't stomach any more wand-waving wizards and transforming robots.
For the most part In Fear, largely improvised with the two leads only broadly aware of the general direction of the story, is a quiet triumph.
Despite its brief running time it could do with a little tightening up... but as an homage to a very particular style of filmmaking it's a quiet, commendable triumph.

Frequently very funny and almost always absolutely tongue-in-cheek - but it looks like we'll have to wait a bit longer for the movie which really gets the balance right in presenting a combination of classic drama and high-concept fantasy.
Stark, brittle, disquieting and with an ending to rival The Mist for bleakness, Containment is British genre cinema to champion and one to shout about from the nearest rooftop.
The Other Side of the Door throws a lot of mud at the wall and most of it sticks, thanks to a powerful performance by former Walking Dead star Callies.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Door (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It Comes at Night demands that its audience's work with it and the end result, whilst not always entirely satisfactory, is never less than compelling and highly watchable.
This is one Boy, which doesn't really need to be seen or heard.
The Cloverfield Paradox, despite a strong opening and a satisfactorily-downbeat ending, has little of real interest going on for the bulk of its running time.
Running for little over an hour, The Earth Dies Screaming moves at a fair old clip and it certainly doesn't hang about.

The world we're being asked to engage with is never completely believable and the buddy movie clichés and heavy handed social commentary become uneasy bedfellows in a schizophrenic, undisciplined movie that eventually deteriorates.

A Brilliant Monster is a cut above many creaky low-budget under-the-radar indies. It's confident and genuinely cinematic despite its apparent lack of visual ambition and it's shot through with jet black humour.
Beyond Skyline, beyond belief, is beyond good.
Dunkirk sees Christopher Nolan really coming of age as a director. It's his masterpiece at last and it's destined to become regarded as a very important film indeed.
47 Metres Down is great fun -- despite a slightly dodgy twist ending clunkily telegraphed halfway through the film -- and Moore and Holt carry the drama well.

Terrible performances abound, the incidental music rarely fits in with what's happening on-screen and even a 'shock' ending is utterly unable to redeem a film which has been so inept and, most unforgivably, bloody boring for so long.

Life is unapologetically derivative - you'll enjoy ticking off all the boxes and spotting all the similarities to other genre favourites ("That bit's pure Quatermass!", "There's The Thing!") and yet it's still an edge-of-the-seat thrill ride.
Hidden Figures is a rich and uplifting experience.
The Witches (or Le Streghe) is a terrible, pointless film even making allowances for the crazy, random excesses of the psychedelic 1960s and truly appalling dubbing on the English language version.
Swiss Army Man isn't easily-digestible viewing but sometimes film needs to remind us that it's an art form as well as an entertainment platform.

There's no doubt that this is confident, striking, film-making and if it merely serves as the final step in Gibson's rehabilitation and allows him to forge ahead with his new career as a director of true vision and power.
A wonderful and welcome surprise, a visit to 10 Cloverfield Lane is highly recommended.

It's a magnificent action film, it's a wonderful character piece, it's big, brash, bursting with confidence and brio; it's Marvel firing on all cylinders just when, by rights, we might be expecting the law of diminishing returns to set in.
Midnight Special really is very special indeed.
You won't give a mechanical monkey's uncle what happens to any of the generic grunts... but there's still some fun to be had in the well-executed action sequences and superbly-realised killer robots.

Although the movie's hardly destined to figure on anyone's 'top ten horror movies' list, it's guaranteed to provide a few thrills and spills for the ninety-odd minutes you spend in its company in the multiplex.
The Shallows is effectively a one-hander and Blake Lively handles the heavy lifting required to make us care about Nancy and believe in her plight with effortless aplomb.
Somewhere along the way, around that sixty-minute mark, the wheel comes off an already-wobbly wagon.
Brittle and brutal and yet shot through with a knowing vein of black humour, TGWATG is a gripping and intelligent thriller.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A treat for the eyes, the heart and possibly even the soul.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Although [director Eugene] Jarecki (The Trials of Henry Kissinger) is clearly left-leaning, he takes pains to be fair and balanced by including commentary from right-wingers.
Unfortunately, it just isn't that funny as a comedy.
With apologies to the great black poet Gil Scott Heron, the revolution may not be televised but sometimes it sure is trivialized.
Funny, fast-paced and deliberately provocative.
Its breezy charm papers over narrative cracks and minor annoyances.
Leaves you to fill in the gaps, but you won't care enough to bother.
A relatively modest B-movie bolstered by A-grade technical wizardry.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This is one of the most assured, fully-formed British debuts of recent years.
Stripped of the baggage that so often complicates and corrupts queer romance, Call Me by Your Name is allowed to flourish as an unfiltered evocation of the agony and ecstasy of first love.
At once intimidatingly dense and breezily concise, uncompromisingly experimental and riotously entertaining.
As the full story of Jonathan's demise finally takes shape, it transpires that Maoz has kept a final, bitterly cruel trick up his sleeves.
One hell of a calling card, and perhaps the most dazzling fusion of grim social realism and giddy genre thrills since Cristian Mungiu's 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days.

Touch Me Not should strike a chord most readily with those who've struggled to understand or express their own identity, but adventurous viewers of all persuasions should approach this celebration of female and minority sexuality with an open mind.
Matzembacher and Reolon perform a deft balancing act, crafting a character study that is empathetic and emotionally engaging yet unflinching and unsentimental, and unapologetically erotic.
Haigh has rearranged the building blocks of mawkish teen melodrama into a bracing and bittersweet coming-of-age fable.
Fortunately, an outstanding cast helps make the transition from stage to screen a success.
The film is great to look at and not burdened with technical information.

Although the characters speak sparingly, especially the taciturn Hsiao-Kang, we come away understanding their world a little better. The conflicts that they encounter along the way are by no means resolved, but the ending is satisfying just the same.

In all, Chasing Great remains engrossing throughout, offering a close-up look at a very rough and tumble sport. Watching the film, it's hard not to get swept up into the spirit of the fans and the players.

Despite the film's tendency to shy away from deeper questions of motivation, Curry's storytelling is well-structured and strangely compelling. I found myself rooting for Vandyke - and thanking my lucky stars that I was not in his place.

Submission is well acted, finely paced and craftily photographed, but provides no real revelations that will add to the discussion about campus politics or sexual harassment. Which is OK - thankfully, it's not a film that wants to teach us a lesson.
The movie's biggest laughs come from parts that were probably not intended to be comic.
Can adults sit through it with minimal doses of Novocaine from the concession stand? The answer: A qualified yes.
What we ultimately are left with seems to be a case of a director's serious, high-minded aesthetic in unholy alliance with inherently silly material.
Say, since Alex and Emma is supposed to be all about people of letters and the creative process, maybe somebody interested knows. Is lame-o all one word or hyphenated?
The movie is extraordinary mostly for the sheer wastefulness of it all, the work of little boys who've never outgrown their love of blowing things up.
In its non-hysterical depiction of the fog of personal relationship wars, the movie gently makes the point that, yeah, it really is a wild world out there.
There's not enough - well, hardly anything - new here to call Open Range a great Western. But it's probably as good as we're going to get and as good as it needs to be.

This movie, benign and conventional as it is, needs a gutsy performance to keep it from sheer sogginess. The biggest surprise the movie generates is why it's taken this long for Lane's career to take off.
In My Boss's Daughter, there is no gee-whiz factor, only one Herculean whiz. A pox on this scatological scourge, I say. Let us all together put down the seat and flee for our sanities.
I have to admit I thought I'd sooner see a Wendy's bacon cheeseburger in Le Divorce before a slit, bloody wrist.
The Order is scuzzy and lazy, such a muddle that no one really need be offended. Actually, no one need even bother with it all. That's why I'm being paid in this space, to spare you the temptation.
Matchstick Men is so good when it is good that it's somewhere between exasperating and galling when it undermines our invested goodwill with a monster contrivance out of deep left field.
This is sophisticated, sultry noir for those who fancy this sort of thing, but then, who doesn't?
Cold Creek Manor is cautious to the point of inert.
In a single sentence, Allen's character invokes Camus and Henny Youngman. If an unfunny joke is told in the forest and nobody hears it, it's still an unfunny joke.
S.W.A.T.'s last, seemingly interminable 45 minutes make the Mini Cooper chase of The Italian Job seem practically Truffaut.
A peppy and perspiring timewaster, but we don't mind.
Normally, I subscribe to the theory that Hoffman and Hackman - and Cusack, too - elevate any movie they grace and are worth following anywhere. In this case, I declare a mistrial.
Raising Helen is competent, commercial, square-as-square-can-be popular entertainment.
It's a fairy tale in the best sense of the word, though the movie is far too hip and Julia Stiles' Paige too independent the heroine for any pat, happily-ever-after endings.
At a certain point, Taking Lives gives up any pretense toward sense and starts piling up insanely improbable extravagances.
The film concentrates, in awe-inspiring detail, on the almost incomprehensible rigors of mountain climbing and evolves into a philosophical, even spiritual adventure movie.
Clooney and Zeta-Jones have a level of antagonistic banter recalling the best of the Hepburn-Tracy chemistry. Now, this is what is meant by the term movie star.
There is something cruelly funny about getting dumped on your honeymoon, but that was done far better in Elaine May's The Heartbreak Kid.
Burton has a big payoff up his sleeve. In a movie practically schizophrenic in mood, he manages to present the inevitability of death with a touching beauty and elegance.
When it's all said and done, there comes a not half-bad twist. But by this time, we've endured too many reprises of canine flambé, plus Eric Stoltz as a drooling pervert.
It's a dichotomy of appearance, the forging of nature's splendor defiled by base human behavior. That said, I wish it had stayed truer to the fatalistic mood it works up.
Nancy Meyers is like some grandma who keeps hugging you harder than you want to be hugged.
Even when The Human Stain founders, the skill and professionalism of those trying to communicate Philip Roth's mood is undeniable.
Master and Commander has a full arsenal primed to wash over you, in more ways than one.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: In the Cut demonstrates that miserable taste and artistic miscalculation hardly are the exclusive domain of male filmmakers and actors.
Beyond Borders can be wrenching and vigorously committed, but it's also occasionally tasteless and calculating. Think Doctor Zhivago with landmines.
Gentlemen - you whose significant other may hold the weekend movie choice card - keep a stiff upper lip. You'll get through Calendar Girls just fine.
The trouble with this art movie is that it's more a movie than it's art.
movie_title: Rivers and Tides: Andy Goldsworthy Working With Time (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Klaus reminds us in his masterful approach that patience is sometimes the most powerful device for a filmmaker to impress the magic of the story upon their audience.
Hounds of Love, the bold debut feature of Australian filmmaker Ben Young, follows in the footsteps of compatriot Justin Kurzel's own viscerally disturbing urban nightmare debut, Snowtown.
A film of genuine force, it strikes you in the gut with a clenched fist, simultaneously seduced by its beauty while recoiling at the moral abyss.

Jawbone may be an example of the catharsis of filmmaking and storytelling, the first time effort at screenwriting for Harris and feature direction for Napper has culminated in a solid piece of filmmaking.
The White King is a bold and brave piece of filmmaking that embraces film as an incomplete form. The ideas are presented in such a way that they require the engagement of the audience.

Kirke and Kravitz's performances are as bold as the writing and the direction, LeBeau, in particular, remains in our minds, not only with an immediacy but perhaps the conclusion of her quest for the truth is a lasting and evocative image of ambivalence.
Regardless, Brad's Status that has the potential to communicate as deeply as it does to offer a lighter, yet nonetheless touching experience.
Berlin Syndrome progresses slowly, never dramatically gratuitous or exploitative of the inherent drama of its story.
[Rian] Johnson's miscue has posed a disquieting question: Are these filmmakers authors or fans?
Disappointing in comparison to other recent war movies...or any other John Woo flick for that matter.
...it will be remembered by true movie lovers a little better than it saccharine-coated competitors.
Another in a long line of ultra-violent war movies, this one is not quite what it could have been as a film, but the story and theme make up for it.
If you're a teen girl, you'll love it. Otherwise, this one probably wasn't made for you.
...not the typical flashy blockbuster Tom Cruise fans may have come to expect.
Quite funny for the type of movie it is...
A surprisingly intriguing film that continues Lyne's reign of the `sexy thriller' genre.
A very enjoyable road trip/buddy movie for the open-minded.
This one is not nearly as dreadful as expected. In fact, it's quite fun in places.
The awful title should be a warning to you about the film.
What would have been a surefire blockbuster in any other time is now a very hard film to "enjoy" post-9/11.
One of the better recent teen comedies...
While it's not quite what the first three were, it's on the right track. This one definitely is an improvement from `Episode 1'.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Another Hollywood-style action flick that entertains, but isn't terribly original...
Although not the best comedy in recent memory, it's not the worst either.
...quite possibly the best action film of the year.
A so-so film version of the great book that looks good, but just isn't very satisfying.
All of the buzz is true! Denzel Washington's performance in this movie is amazing.
A fast paced and fun creature feature unlike many in recent decades.
It's exactly what you'd expect.
Critics and cynics will probably beat up on this flick, but if you go just wanting to be entertained, that's what you'll get.
This one is probably best seen as a rental. From the looks of things, it shouldn't take that long to make it to the video store, either.
It's a shame they couldn't have put Hawn and Sarandon in a better movie than this.
This fantastically weird cartoon is definitely one of the most intriguing movies of the year.

Unlike most "Hollywood on Hollywood" movies, this one is actually a winner.
Frightening realism is always scarier than gore, and Williams is frighteningly realistic.
It's pure fantasy for kids of all ages, plain and simple.

To dismiss this as another "sci-fi alien flick" would be a shame.
Exactly what you'd expect, but worth it if you've enjoyed the other ones.
If you enjoy more thoughtful comedies with interesting conflicted characters; this one is for you.

While not all that bad of a movie, it's nowhere near as good as the original.

Great performances...boring movie.

...like most sequels, just isn't as good as the original.
