Grief, anguish, revenge. All of these, when rendered onto the canvas of a well-rounded character, are so much more potent than the sight of a city crashing into another city or a looming CGI spaceship drawing ever nearer to its fatal destination.
The film is unfailing in its attention to detail, brutally unforgiving in its fan-service, and riddled with genuine moments of exultant joy.
John Wick: Chapter 2 is a big, angry, joyous sequel that more than earns its place alongside its predecessor.
Guardians of the Galaxy Volume 2 is a relentlessly joyful, heart-pounding, exhilarating slab of pure wonderment.
Rogue One is an explosive, brilliant entry into the Star Wars universe. It's a bracing slap in the face, but a bloody fun one to watch.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Jacob, and his interactions with Queenie in particular, give the film the spark it so desperately needs to succeed.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The same saccharine joy that made The Lego Movie so great is cloaked all over Gotham City and it just doesn't sit quite right.
Beyond is, above all else, fun to watch; it's a proper Star Trek experience. And it feels profoundly good to say that.
The Dark Knight Rises not only realistically tackles the physical and emotional ravages and consequences of a being Batman, but also makes the entire three-film story scintillatingly cyclical.
It is a rip-roaring, swashbuckling jaunt through galactic space which will leave you reeling.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: I urge you to stop seeking out information on this film, and instead wait until this Thursday and see it, on the biggest screen within reach. You won't be sorry.
The VFX are the best I've seen in any Marvel movie, ever. If you do see Doctor Strange -- and you really ought to -- I recommend seeing it at IMAX.
A hyper-violent slab of enjoyably silly blockbuster schlock, but by no means essential viewing.
Another essential, damning indictment of America's torture policy.
movie_title: You Don't Like the Truth: 4 Days Inside Guantanamo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A remarkable film that signals an exciting new voice in the LGBT landscape.
Visual flourishes aren't enough to detract from a confused plot and mawkishly sentimental overtones.
movie_title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An assured debut with great performances and a wonderfully odd brand of British humour.
War is awful. We get it.
Thought provoking, but leeringly nasty and deeply unsettling. This is one that will linger with you for days.
An honest, frank and often moving documentary that deals with its difficult subject matter sensitively and compellingly.
One of the most imaginative and visually arresting films of the year. Essential viewing.
movie_title: Prezít svuj zivot (teorie a praxe) (Surviving Life (Theory and Practice)) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An unexpected and deeply moving tale of the fragility of young romance.
A warm and charming, if somewhat forgettable, little experience.
Regularly fascinating, but often somewhat inaccessible in its lack of historical context for the uninitiated.
As summer movies go, The Dark Knight is head and shoulders above most.
Jason Filardi's broad script is an uneven hodgepodge of culture clash, screwball romance, urban crime drama and sitcom.
Me, Myself & Irene is one of the most daring, pungently funny and wholly original American comedies in ages -- and one of the silliest, too.
Although lively at times, the proceedings are far too perfunctory to generate a 'can-you-top-this' quality. The result is a film that knows some of the words, but not the music.
The pandering, sappy script misses ample opportunities for satire and never brims with enough material or ideas to sustain the picture's 85-minute running time.
A comedy that surpasses stupidity, and not in entertaining ways.
Never more than an extended TV episode, the originality of its heroine and messages merit a recommendation for families seeking slightly more thoughtful animated fare.
A joyless amalgam of horror movie cliches.
Muniz and Duff have a huge following, but they're at the service of endless Meet Cutes and a violent finale that could easily be dubbed 'Explosion Parade.'
The film's only distinction remains Chow.
An uneven but engagingly quirky comedy-drama driven first by character, second by plot formulas, Cage is surprisingly convincing despite seeming at first like the wrong choice.
The script is on autopilot and even the voice work feels phoned in.
The film is so truncated, so obsessed with style and composed of so many self-contained episodes that it fails to say anything new.
The movie is skillfully paced by rising director Gary Fleder and has all the usual Grisham touches: big issues, broad characterizations, tense showdowns and a swelling bounty of twists and clues.
Summercamp! maintains a gentle, lackadaisical tone that eloquently captures the triumphs and traumas of this ageless ritual.
It's neither epic enough to fulfill a grand scope, nor intimate enough to be an overpowering emotional experience.
A loud, frantic mess, a movie that wants to be a screwball farce but is simply farcical and screwy.
Battle of the Five Armies sets out to deliver the killer climax promised by its two prevaricating predecessors, and to some extent succeeds.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Interstellar feels like a collection of arresting moments and ideas that don't quite hang together.
Competent but unremarkable.
Vincent Lindon is staggeringly good in the part, burying so deep into his demanding role that actor and character merge and become indistinguishable.
movie_title: The Measure of a Man (La loi du marché) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Mr Gosling is as new to comedy as Mr Crowe, but embraces it fearlessly in a role that requires little dignity and plenty of pratfalls.
A film full of loud noises and flashy effects that is watchable, after a fashion.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's tiresome stuff for the most part, but there are a few genuinely funny scenes, and even in muck like this, Ms Aniston shines.
While the film itself is pretty bearable in parts -- Claflin and Clarke are good, and work well together -- it's all rather pat and manufactured.
Nice looking and well acted, The Commune is afflicted by melodramatic tendencies that eventually overwhelm it. But there are rich dramatic moments, and Trine Dyrholm is exceptional.
It's typical Aardman stuff, playful, inventive and funny.

This impeccably photographed film doesn't quite manage to reconcile its two narratives, but should be required viewing for those who think anyone but the desperate would willingly board those fetid coffin ships.

Patrick's Day has Hitchcock-ian overtones, especially when Patrick's mother tries to persuade him that Karen was a figment of his imagination. And while not everything in it holds together, Walker and Fox are very good as the warring women.
Ms. Hausner's film proceeds at a stately, measured pace, and uses classical compositions and stiff exchanges to underline the tedium of early 19th-century bourgeois life.
Although more sombre than some of the studio's biggest hits, it has in spades the gorgeous, painstaking animation that has become Ghibli's trademark.
Ms McCarthy deserves better.

All of this implicitly criticises the failures of America's increasingly iniquitous society, but more subtly and intelligently than is usually the case in Mr Moore's work. It's surprisingly thought-provoking.
The Kardashians don't need satirising, they're inadvertently doing it themselves, and Patsy and Eddy seem almost demure and ladylike in our relentlessly trashy age.

For its first hour or so, 'The Legend of Tarzan' works tolerably well as a straightforward action adventure... As the film goes on, however, the special effects dis-improve, and are positively amateurish during an epically absurd climax.
It's the fine script that runs out of steam, though by the time it does, Wiig and co have won you over and left you thinking that a sequel to this thing might not be entirely offensive.
It takes a special kind of film actor to make a performance like this work, and Mr Damon certainly fits that bill.
The finer plot details of this film cannot be approached without laughter: it's a pretentious, grandiose mess, packed with tiresome special effects that at least distract from the dreadful dialogue.
The Daughter rises nicely to a memorable crescendo, and while its script is pretty ordinary, Odessa Young is outstanding as the unfortunate Hedvig.
There's a TV movie tinniness to the film's rather pat denouement, but plenty to enjoy otherwise, and Damian Lewis's portrayal of the cagey spy Hector is note perfect.
The pleasures of Money Monster come from watching old pros like Clooney and Ms Roberts negotiate their way effortlessly through this formulaic but entertaining thriller.

It is relentless, horrifying, and skilfully implies the endless carnage going on in the background while driving forward a simple but powerful narrative which proves that, even in hell, you never stop being a parent.
It's a fine, if rather depressing documentary.
Ms Streep is delightful in the role, giving Florence a kind of quiet grace that counteracts her silliness, and getting tremendous comedy out of the singing sequences, which are suitably excruciating.
Jokes come thick and fast in a film that plays to the cheap seats but may bewilder the younger viewers at whom it's presumably aimed.

I'm not sure this film has the emotional resonance of the original, and nothing much is done to develop the characters of Marlin and Nemo. But Finding Dory is a lot of fun, and went down a bomb with junior critics.
Mr Linklater may be a fan of Marcel Proust, because this film is suffused with a heady nostalgia for the lost past.
Green Room is one of those rare horror movies that actually gets better rather than worse as it proceeds.
It's a wonderful film, beautifully made and a compelling argument against the perversions of puritanism.
I'm not really sure what it all means, but it is gorgeous to look at, and rather entertaining.

Bryan Singer has made enough of these superhero things to know how to put them together, and for long periods balances competing story lines and the contradictory needs of action and drama reasonably well.
It's kind, moving, and nicely done.
movie_title: Journey To The Shore (Kishibe No Tabi) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A kind of home movie with hidden depths, Laurie Anderson's Heart of a Dog is discursive, whimsical, jokey, profound: it will infuriate some, but I loved it.
The high winds of hamminess roar through the rafters in Corinna McFarlane's The Silent Storm.

Tom Twyker's film is nicely photographed and alive to the beauty, absurdity and hidden dangers of Saudi life. Its plot, though, is rarely credible, and only Mr Hanks' gurning, sweating businessman holds this flabby production together.
Spectacularly unpleasant.
It's a lean, grim and perfectly assembled thriller, a little gem in fact.
Zoolander No. 2 proceeds at a consistently hysterical pitch and, though it drags in parts, is worth watching for some genuinely hilarious moments.
For long periods, to be fair, Jurassic World is easy to watch and pretty entertaining, especially when Chris Pratt is on the screen.

Efficient, well-crafted and solid to a fault, The Finest Hours might have been made 30 or 70 years ago, and starred Gary Cooper or James Stewart -- it's profoundly old-fashioned but pretty enjoyable for all that.
A fine supporting cast includes a crazed Helena Bonham-Carter, the special effects are splendid, but the film is hamstrung by a storyline that just doesn't hang together.
Stillman's film unfolds delightfully, is full of fun and wit, and Tom Bennett is superb as the idiotic but inordinately wealthy suitor.
The Price of Desire takes a wonderful story and makes a bit of a hash of it.
Ms Albert emerges as a quicksilver talent whose obfuscations enraged many, but harmed absolutely no one.
It's soppy stuff, not nearly funny enough, and Lily Collins' sterling efforts are mainly in vain.

This tale is very well told, nicely paced and perfectly pitched in a movie that doesn't make the mistake of outstaying its welcome. And like all the best children's films, it reminds world-weary parents what being a kid actually feels like.
It almost has a Mills & Boon quality, but it's very nice to look at and Fassbender and Vikander are most convincing as the doomed lovers.
It's a very sweet film, dominated inevitably by the cat, whom I believe is played by Bob himself.
It's impressive... but also arid, and superficial, a film composed of brilliant moments that lacks unity and is too concerned with itself to truly come to life.
Rogue Nation's secret weapon is Anglo/Swedish actress Rebecca Ferguson, who has more star quality than any Bond girl I've ever seen and reminded me at times of a young Romy Schneider.
Alex Fegan's documentary Older Than Ireland pursues a simple but very effective premise - interviewing Irish men and women who, at 100-plus, are older than the state itself.
Miss You Already is commendably brave in its unsweetened depiction of cancer, and in fact this is probably the most honest depiction of the disease I can remember seeing in a cinema.
A thriller of sorts that starts reasonably well before drifting to an aimless halt.
The Imitation Game is a polished and efficient drama, and looks great on a comparatively modest budget of 15 million, especially the loving reconstruction of Alan's beautiful machine.
Anne Fontaine does a fine job overall of telling a story in which faith is pitted against moral pragmatism, and ordinary human decency.
Deeply silly but undeniably entertaining.
The film overall is atmospheric, involving, well acted and beautifully written, and Tracy Letts is wonderful as the infuriatingly reasonable Dean.

It's perfectly paced and looks magnificent, with a scale and grandeur that perfectly fits the subject. The landing itself is superbly realised, and made me glad I won't be flying anywhere any time soon.
Despite this rather limited emotional arc, Ben Younger's film sings at times: the boxing scenes are excellent, and Hinds and a virtually unrecognisable Eckhart do much to beef things up dramatically.

Nadine is by turns endearing and infuriating, and while Edge of Seventeen ends a little too neatly, it's a lovely comedy that really captures the wild unpredictability and melodrama of the teenage state.
Dwayne Johnson does a wonderful job of voicing the conceited Maui, and if the storyline is not entirely satisfying, I could watch those gently undulating animated oceans forever.
Hail, Caesar! should be a lot of fun, but is essentially a collection of nicely written scenes held together by nothing.
Somehow, it all works, and Winlset almost makes us believe that Lady Macbeth has been reborn east of the Volga.
All the glamour and intrigue of that original film is gone, and Secret in their Eyes proves that throwing movie stars at a story is not always the best way to tell it.
The Program is a drama, not a documentary, which allows it to flesh out the bones of this story into something approaching a minor Shakespearean tragedy.

Davis wishes to deconstruct his old life, and begin a new one. He does so slowly and unconvincingly in a film that takes itself extremely seriously but never manages to breathe earth and life into flimsy characters.

A sometimes impassioned but oddly meandering documentary, it tells the stories of the hugely influential 60s group through the recollections of Iggy Pop and fellow band members Ron and Scott Asheton. But as usual, Iggy's the main event.
It's a lot of fun, and commendably mind-bending.
Everest is nice to watch, and pretty impressive technically. But it becomes a bit of an effort after a while, and it's always hard to deeply sympathise with the thrill-seeking western climbers.
July Jung skilfully keeps you guessing in a film that might move slowly but is rich in sexual and psychological tension.

Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates is a brisk and frantic comedy that tries hard to be hilarious. It fails despite a talented cast and a workable premise, falling victim to a kind of desperate crassness.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Guillaume Nicloux's drama Valley of Love is no masterpiece, but worth watching for anyone with an interest in high-quality screen acting.
In Ashish Ghadiali's interesting but profoundly un-cinematic documentary The Confession, we hear one man's very personal experiences during the war on terror.
It treats arms dealing as a heady adventure, ignores its consequences, and Hill and Teller manage to make their characters even more dislikeable than they were intended to be.
Strange Occurrences doesn't set out to poke fun, but instead lets Knock and its devotees speak for themselves, sometimes to their detriment.
movie_title: Strange Occurrences in a Small Irish Village (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [Almodovar's] film is both melodrama and meditation, his two leading ladies rise to the task brilliantly, and the director unfolds his sometimes unlikely tale with the ease and skill of a master.
It's quite a film.

It's a lot better than the second film, almost as likeable as the first, and features an ensemble cast of excellent comic actors who are led from the front by Renée Zellweger with her usual bravery and aplomb.
A salty but warm-hearted comedy from Peter Foott
It's well-crafted, its air of menace is palpable, and Mr Cranston brings depth and detail to a tricky role.
Blair Witch adds nothing to the original idea, and managed to make me feel simultaneously anxious, and bored.
Howard's film unearths startling footage of them performing, and fades out the awful screaming so you can actually hear them play. They were pretty good, it turns out.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Denzel Washington, as we've come to expect from this masterful and unfussy screen actor, carries the entire film by sheer force of personality.
A delightfully bleak satire set in a dystopian present.
There's a lot more to Ira Sachs' indie drama Little Men than initially meets the eye.
The battle scenes alone make this solid and well-paced film worth watching.
The Clan explores the dark side of bourgeois respectability, and offers telling insight into the banality of evil: it's a fine film, but not an easy watch.
Serena is pompous, stiff, drab and dreary, and the fizzing chemistry between Cooper and Lawrence that David O Russell so brilliantly captured is curiously absent here.
Jason Bateman is very good at radiating gentle melancholy, and here plays a man with plenty to be blue about.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Jennifer Kent's feature is beautifully made and cleverly filmed and paced. It's one of the most satisfying horror films I've seen in a while, and ends on a refreshingly original note.

Things get pretty hammy towards the end, too, but perhaps that's to be expected in this kind of movie, which reminded me a bit of Gone Girl but also of enjoyably silly 80s thrillers like Fatal Attraction.
The Shallows looks pretty good and rattles along at a lively pace. It is, however, profoundly silly.

Captain America: Civil War rumbles busily towards a confrontation between Cap and Iron Man, but that fistfight is perhaps the least interesting bit of this frenetic, hyperactive and intermittently enjoyable film.
It's the film's action scenes that are most disappointing, and made me feel like I was inside a video game.
It's very nicely, if a little safely made, and gives you a compelling sense of how blithely an entire generation was squandered.
This is plodding, pedestrian, derivative stuff.
Dreary and charmless.
A Walk Among the Tombstones is no cerebral cop drama, and promptly settles down into a formulaic but perfectly watchable psycho-thriller.
It's beautifully made, and lovely to look at.
This stiff and stilted drama is weighed down by its blathering script and hamstrung by a lack of wherewithal.
Rosoulof's film is shocking, relentless, a remarkable piece of work.
It's a sweet, well-intentioned film.
While it overreaches itself at times, it's a warm, engaging and winningly sincere comic drama.
The writing feels rushed and heavy-handed at times, and laden down with clumsy exposition. There are some delightfully funny moments, though.
O'Kane is alright in a film that's solid rather than spectacular, but Sarah Greene is quite exceptional as the 20-something Noble, and seems bound for bigger things.
While one grows tired of describing how Denzel Washington has made an ordinary film more than watchable, he's at it again here.
The latest in a long line of teen fantasies, The Maze Runner is a cagey dystopian thriller that tries to make a virtue of its limitations but becomes samey and tedious after a while.
It's a very silly film.
As to the three principals, they've grown up with the Potter saga and have done so reasonably gracefully.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: In Fear was made for next to nothing but that is not always a virtue. After an adequate start its storyline goes precisely nowhere.

Affleck is becoming a more skillful director with each passing project, and in terms of both technical accomplishment and entertainment value, Argo is a worthy successor to his previous films, Gone Baby Gone and The Town.
[The Other Side of the Door] relies on repetitive and predictable horror tropes and runs out of steam long before it ends.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Door (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Stiff but tolerable.
Charlie Kaufman is a true original, and while he doesn't make many films, the ones he has certainly stick in your mind.

It's sweet, irresistible stuff, but the animation is absolutely spectacular, blending influences from ancient Chinese and Japanese art with a glorious palette of colours to create something truly special.
Robert Eggars' directorial debut The Witch is so good it almost feels as if William Friedkin had decided to have a pop at Arthur Miller's Crucible.
An irredeemably dumb disaster movie with good effects and virtually no plot.

Includes a lot more action than its rather funereal predecessors and the special effects are strong. But they take their own sweet time with the storytelling, and a final Divergent film is on the way.
It's brilliant, pared-down film-making, and Cotillard is exceptionally good in the central role, letting her face speak volumes about the pain of depression and rejection.

Lucy is a brash, breezy and breathlessly paced thriller, with a high-concept plot that falls apart the moment you start thinking about it. But Besson's camera moves so fast that you rarely get the chance.
Out of the Furnace trundles along with no apparent purpose and at several key points makes no sense.
Lone Survivor sticks pretty closely to the facts, has real momentum and a series of impressive action sequences
Efron and Poots don't quite work together, but Mackenzie Davis is very good as the privileged, but secretly passionate, Chelsea.
These clips are fascinating, but Journal de France would have been a stronger documentary if Monsieur Depardon had provided narrations for some of them.
Using dialogue sparsely and shocking images relentlessly, McQueen's movie brilliantly explores the implications and legacy of slavery, and debunks some of its more cherished myths.
Crimson Peak is a lot of fun for the most part, knowingly camp and nicely photographed, but the CGI effects become too dominant late on, as Mr del Toro lashes on the guignol.
Fiennes approaches his story intelligently, and adds poetic visual flourishes to Abi Morgan's fine script.
It's impossible not to like and McConaughey's Ron is a compelling screen creation, a skinny, crazy zealot whose relentless energy seems to come from nowhere.
Those considering a life of crime may think again after seeing Starred Up, a bleak, brutal and compelling thriller set in a singularly grim British prison.
Labor Day is a humourless and heavy-handed melodrama built around an extremely unlikely romance.
This version neither fizzes nor sparkles, but may prove a painless enough experience -- if you're unfamiliar with the original.
Salvo is nicely put together, and told for the most part without recourse to words. But under the Sicilian swagger, there's not much substance or character to cling to.
Pierre Niney is outstanding as Saint Laurent.
Chris Evans is a perfect fit for the Captain America role -- charming, square-jawed, and witty rather than giddy, he provides a solid anchor for the other characters to fly around.
It is a winning and worthy sequel that relies more on jokes than songs, and features some lovely non-muppet guest performances.
Farhadi uses grace and fluidity to tell a story in which no one is quite innocent.
Morgan Neville's hugely enjoyable, Oscar-winning documentary celebrates the unsung heroes who helped make some of popular music's most celebrated songs and albums special.

Brigitte Helm is absolutely brilliant in a tricky dual role. The real star, though, is Lang's incredibly fecund imagination and his glorious realisation of the futuristic Babel he dreamt up in his head.

Andrew Garfield seems more comfortable in the role than he did first time out, and a late plot twist suggests his character is bound for darker waters in the two sequels Sony have already committed to.
After a not very impressive crash sequence, the film settles into a running battle between young Master Smith and a series of CGI monsters, a schema that sounds tiresome, and is.
Though at times you feel like you're being told when to cry, that doesn't mean you won't start dutifully blubbing on cue.
Entertaining in an instantly forgettable sort of way.

All of this is most intelligently handled by Monsieur Vallée and his screenwriter Nick Hornby in a film that's handsome, entertaining and not short on insight. And Ms. Witherspoon's gutsy performance deserves the attention it's getting.

Murphy and Moriarty almost make their absurd premise work at first, and Killian Scott and John Bradley are good in pivotal roles. But the idea is quickly stretched too thin, and a preachy streak in the writing becomes tedious.
Kill Your Friends is based on a novel of the same name by John Niven, which on the strength of this ghastly mess I have vowed never to read.
The subsequent trial is absurd, and Kafkaesque, and tells us more about the social iniquities of Indian society than it does about justice, or the law.
El Club memorably teases out the enduring themes of sin and redemption.
While My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2 is redeemed somewhat by an underlying well-intentioned sweetness, it's a tired and dated little movie that might have been made in the 1980s.
[A] whimsical and good-natured comic drama.
This technique gives the drama compelling veracity and spontaneity, as well as a free-flowing headiness that captures the divine madness of 20-something night-life.
A dense thriller set in a particularly gloomy suburb of Dublin.
Badly told and badly made, The Huntsman: Winter's War lacks the clarity and moral satisfactions of a proper fairy tale, and wastes the talents of its cast, especially Jessica Chastain
Dheepan is powerfully told, and takes one inside the mind of a man who's haunted by his recent past.
Gorgeously photographed by Seamus Deasy, Fitzmaurice's film catches the unhinged passion of the teenage state, and ends as uncertainly as perhaps it should.
It's all very nice, and pleasant to look at, but Irons' vibrant and colourful performance is this only thing that gives this film life.
Promising but rather confusing.
It's all very nicely done, but just a little bit joyless.
Van Dormael's film is touching, wise, very funny at times, and winningly surreal.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Gavin Hood's film cleverly explores the vexed ethics of remote warfare, and a fine ensemble cast help make this a clever, thought-provoking and deeply satisfying thriller.
It's a delightful film, excellently acted and charged with undercurrents of familial emotion.
If the story's a bit thin for a feature-length movie, there are some lovely moments along the way.
It's an odd, disjointed, incoherent film, and only Mr Cheadle's acting and snatches of Mr Davis's divine music make it worth watching.
A schlocky and charmless horror film with demonic overtones, Friend Request doesn't have the wit to develop what might have been an interesting idea.
It goes nowhere very slowly.

It's a cheesy and hackneyed action yarn that winks at the camera and just about gets away with it. It does so mainly because of Idris Elba, an actor with more than enough presence and charisma to hold this kind of thing together.
Well made and briskly edited, American Sniper is a decent and very watchable action film. But it appears to have absolutely nothing to say about the politics behind all the soldiering.

Director Alice Winocour establishes an atmosphere of woozy paranoia, and uses Schoenaert's brooding presence to great effect. But the tension is dissipated when a real threat emerges, and Disorder turns into a conventional action thriller.

This is Saoirse Ronan's film. She's given a huge amount to do, and asked to transform before our eyes from a callow, floundering girl into an assured and confident woman. She does so brilliantly, and talk will turn to Oscars.

While the superhero films of Christopher Nolan carefully established their own coherent world and remained faithful to it, Mr Snyder's saga loses control of its various sub-plots early on and descends into chaos.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A real treat for cinephiles.
Zombie Apocalypse is as dumb as a box of rocks, and as spectacularly violent as you'd expect.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Davis Guggenheim's solid and moving documentary He Named Me Malala gives us the background of a story that shocked the world, but could have been more rigorously made.
Beautifully balanced, cheerful but incisive, Taxi Tehran is playful, but also deadly serious.

The Panthers' confused manifesto included shades of Marxism, Leninism and the black nationalist theories of Malcolm X... But the movement's descent into violence and corruption was swift and fatal, as Mr. Nelson's fine film painstakingly demonstrates.
movie_title: The Black Panthers: Vanguard Of The Revolution (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Johanna Schwartz's worthy documentary follows some of Timbuktu's most prominent musicians as they flee south to avoid the violence, join forces for concerts of protest, and eventually return in muted triumph to their liberated lands.
movie_title: They Will Have to Kill Us First (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Though Brando's life has been catalogued ad nauseum in countless biographies, Mr Riley's film provides a greater insight into his personality and talent for the simple reason that we hear it from the horse's mouth.
The spine of this drama is Jake's relationship with his daughter, but even that seems a bit contrived and saccharine, and overall the film is mired in bathos and cliché.
A witty, pleasant film that meanders aimlessly once its premise has been established.
Tangerine builds beautifully towards a messy and hilarious climax. Mr. Baker's film is full of wit, but also compassion, and its street-level momentum reminded me of early Truffaut. It's that good.
This gloomy little film has neither the imagination nor the effects to carry off its story.
[Abrams'] plot mirrors that of A New Hope, but deliberately so: it will charm old fans, win many new ones, and make everyone an awful lot of money.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The inventiveness and chutzpah with which Miller keeps this mad pursuit interesting is remarkable, as is the movie's cinematography, and design.
Mr Baron Cohen outdoes himself with a film so offensively bad it's hard to imagine him being financed to make another one.
It's good and bad, trashy and brilliant, flimsy and substantial all at the same time. And as for Tarantino? He's maddening, frustrating, totally unique.
There are fine ensemble performances from McAdams, John Slattery, Paul Guilfoyle and Stanley Tucci, but Michael Keaton is Spotlight's secret weapon.
A fine and slyly witty low-budget thriller.
Zootropolis takes the form of a jovial noir thriller, is nicely voiced by the likes of Jason Bateman and Ginnifer Goodwin and should go down very well with the smaller viewer.
High-Rise explodes in an ill-disciplined orgy of mayhem late on which reminded me of Ken Russell at his worst. Interesting film, though.
This very handsome period film had a kind of Downton Abbey watch-ability but is pretty silly, and becomes an out-and-out pantomime at the end.
Superficially gritty but hopelessly romantic.
It's an eerie, stylish, oddly beautiful and commendably macabre little film.
Truth is well made, but a little too pleased with itself.
Frenetic, muddled and hopelessly encumbered with meaningless special effects, Pan is chaotic, a bit of a mess.
Based on an idea by sci-fi writer MR Carey, Girl with All the Gifts is a pretty decent horror film, with science that makes sense and a nice overall visual design considering its slender $4m budget.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's an elegiac, dreamy little film, and catches perfectly the passing madness of the teenage state.
Stephen Burke's story is competently told and the escape itself is nicely handled.
Simon Curtis's film is bland to look at, handsomely but antiseptically photographed. But the story - a good one - is decently told...
veryone, even the dithering ex-husband, is infuriatingly lovable, and while Home Again has its comic moments, its characters are overwhelmed by the saccharine fumes of Meyers-Shyer's screenplay.
There's nothing neat about Mackie Burns' film: like Daphne herself, it's messy and squalid, compellingly real.
Well made but prone to recycling genre cliches, Brimstone is needlessly nasty, and Koolhoven misses no opportunity to decorate his sets with viscera.
This frosty Jo Nesbo murder mystery fails to live up to its early promise.
There are more misses than hits in The Ninjago Movie.
The more we discover about the threat that faces them, the more risible this derivative horror yarn becomes.
Shot in black and white and full of pithy moments, Potter's film purrs like a Rolls Royce engine and ends with a wonderful joke.
While younger viewers may be moderately amused, this will not go down in the annals of great cartoons.
movie_title: The Jungle Bunch (Les as de la jungle) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Narrated by Colin Farrell, It's Not Yet Dark tells his and his wife Ruth's remarkable story as well as it could be told.
Jeffrey Tambor is perfect as the lugubrious Malenkov, and Beale oozes malice as Stalin's sadistic henchman Beria. And what a masterstroke it was to cast Steve Buscemi as Khrushchev.
While Happy Death Day starts well enough and is very proud of its sense of humour, it's too lazy to bother its arse when the time comes to justify its premise.
While slowly choking on the worthiness of its subject matter, Marshall putters along perfectly pleasantly, and messrs Gad and Boseman are a winning double act.

The opening scenes made me suspect I was about to endure a sickening bout of saccharine British Empire nostalgia. But Andy Serkis' directorial debut is much more substantial than that, telling the moving story of an unlikely pioneer.
Heat hangs heavy in the air in this beguiling, almost overpoweringly sensual drama, which is languidly paced, and filled with the sleepy sights and sounds of a northern Italian summer.
So far as Grace is concerned, she is still a star, and I must admit the more of this film I watched, the more I liked her.
Property Of The State clunks along like a TV movie and ultimately fails to justify its exhumation of this awful event.

Michelle Pfeiffer, Penelope Cruz, Josh Gad, Willem Dafoe, Judi Dench, Daisy Ridley - this train positively teems with mildly overacting thespians, and all enter into the spirit of this snug and watchable piece of period silliness with aplomb.
... [Tomi Reichental] lost 35 members of his extended family in the 'final solution', 70,000 of Slovakia's 90,000 Jews were exterminated, and this horror was merely a microcosm of a wider slaughter.
I'm normally the first to moan about the awful ubiquity of the superhero genre, but when they get these things right, one has to admit they can be fun.
Blood flies and bones crack with merry gusto in The Villainess, which is strong stuff and not for the squeamish.
Victoria And Abdul offers a shamelessly saccharine version of British imperial history and seems to imply that the Raj was a bumbling, genial regime rather than a rapacious foreign occupation.
[Jennifer] Lawrence is brilliant and suffers soulfully like a latter-day Joan of Arc.
It's a simple idea, but an effective one, and Mr Roberts strings it out for 85 minutes with some clever twists and turns.
The originality here, though, is in the cultural detail, and the earthy likeability of the two leads.
Valerian is like watching a cartoon on a drunken ferry trip.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is a charmless and ham-fisted production whose cynical attempt to connect with the young is surely destined to fail.
Sally Hawkins is wonderful as the fragile but irrepressible Maudie, and Ethan Hawke is, if anything, even better as a man terrified of caring.
I can't help feeling this well made, sensitive and funny drama has arrived a decade or two too late to interest a wide audience.
This will infuriate some viewers, but the director is making a point, about time, how quickly it passes, and how casually and mindlessly we squander it.
All of that might sound stupid: it is.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The scares are nicely handled early on and director David F Sandberg breathes new life into hoary horror tropes. But the movie loses puff after an hour when it decides to show us the monster.
As an action film, it's irreproachable -- just don't expect it to mean anything.
In an era where two-hour films are the norm, Dark Tower's 95-minute length is suspicious and suggests radical post-production cuts. Whatever went on, the results are not edifying.
In a different movie, Reynolds and Jackson might have made a winning team, but here their foul-mouthed joshing seems forced and Jackson, perhaps smelling a rat, sails wildly over the top.
Everything, Everything looks and sounds like a lot of these disease-of-the-week teen dramas... But it's slickly made, has a couple of decent twists, and Amandla Stenberg is a likeable young actress.
It's a very enjoyable drama, by turns hilarious and touching, and Rush gives a rich portrait of a dedicated craftsman who truly suffered for his art.
Quest meanders somewhat, but is compelling in parts and gives a fascinating insight into the shocking iniquities of a deeply divided nation.
What could go wrong? Rather a lot and the most enjoyable parts of. Soderbergh's smartly written film involve the negotiations and shared worries of the amateurish but thoroughly lovable gang.
A film that's high on charm but perilously low on historical overview, or morality. I ended up liking old Barry, but really, was I supposed to?

Francis Lee has a background in TV acting, and had only directed a couple of shorts and a documentary prior to this. Let's hope he gets to make more feature films, because God's Own Country is pretty special.
This tense and occasionally interesting drama never quite manages to escape its theatrical origins, but [Ben] Mendelsohn and [Rooney] Mara bring the story to life.
[There are] interesting bit[s] of Limehouse Golem, but the murder case itself is dull stuff.
It's partly a horror film, of course, but also a surprisingly funny and touching coming-of-age story that reminds one of 80s classics like Stand By Me (another King adaptation) and The Goonies.
... a gorgeously photographed and archly misanthropic film that is also wickedly funny.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: For all his swagger, McGregor is more likeable than I thought and this watchable, if not especially illuminating, film will be warmly welcomed by his legion of fans.

All very interesting, no doubt, but this film tells its story in stilted fits and starts, and is oddly tasteful and decorous in its treatment of what one presumes was a human triangle born of deep passion.
Yet again Paul King and his co-writer Simon Farnaby have wonderfully caught the playful innocence of the original stories while adding more than enough adult humour to keep the guardians entertained.
The match itself is great fun, and a fine voice cast includes Timothy Spall, Tom Hiddleston and Maisie Williams. But Early Man sags a little in the middle, and isn't quite as funny as it needs to be.
It's competent enough, but depressingly familiar stuff.
A fine ensemble cast display various shades of bravery and suffering.
A fine film could have been built around [Denzel Washington], but Dan Gilroy's screenplay veers off in 10 directions at once after a promising start, and tells its story clumsily.

Indeed, the oppressive style and sublimated Hitchcockian tensions might not be for everyone either, but I loved this film, omelette and all, and suspect it will eventually be seen as a Gothic classic.
Black Panther is worthy, no question, but it's also a little dull.

After an hour or so of aimless waffle, the incident itself is thrown away in 10 minutes, accompanied by a predictable dose of jingoism. These guys are heroes no question: they deserve a better movie than this.
Like the unfortunate yachtsman, James Marsh's film gets stuck in the doldrums after a solid start, and wanders aimlessly though not unpleasantly towards its sombre conclusion.
A film about films, and a lush Cold War melodrama involving an interspecies romance that should be creepy but isn't, Guillermo del Toro's Shape of Water is an unexpected and irresistible delight.
Loveless, a sorry tale of marital breakdown, evokes a system bereft of structure or purpose, and a society ethically adrift. It's a grim masterpiece.

Robbie is superb as Harding, a raw, determined young woman whose chippiness makes her hard to like. And Allison Janney's LaVona is a wonderful creation, a banal monster who gasps oxygen through a nasal tube while smoking furiously.

Studio comedies have been so bad for so long that when a halfway decent one comes along, we critics tend to get overexcited. But Game Night is a little better than decent, and handles its commendably silly premise with real skill and charm.
Francis Lawrence's film is hammy and grandiose, and has delusions of geopolitical relevance, but is considerably less awful than I thought it was going to be, and strangely entertaining.

Emotional, poetic, intensely moving, A Fantastic Woman is beautifully directed and photographed, has Hitchcockian undertones and finds memorable ways of visually evoking Marina's isolation and bravery.
John Erskine's absorbing documentary The Ice King explores Curry's short but hectic life using archive footage and interviews. His grace on the ice still makes one gasp.
One has taken Jackman for granted in this role, but there's something grandly Shakespearean too about the Wolverine's rage against the dying of the light.
What's interesting about this film is not so much its story as the clammy, visceral way Ramsay tells it. It's breathless, bleary stuff, pure cinema, and Joaquin Phoenix is superb in the lead.
The film's look evokes the 50s flashbacks in Annie Hall, but it's joyless, clumsy stuff, pastiche Clifford Odets.
As is so often the case with horrors, The Lodgers comes unstuck a little late on, but it's a handsome film, full of good ideas.
Many great films have emerged from Australia, but few as good as Sweet Country.
A lazy and derivative sequel to the modestly successful 2012 children's animation.
Clocking in at a staggering 142 minutes, The Death Cure makes the massive mistake of taking itself too seriously.
The longer it goes on, the louder and shriller Girls Trip becomes.
Sometimes their ethical band-standing sounds a little pompous, but they all seem genuinely motivated more by idealism than ego. Which sounds almost far-fetched given what was coming next.

The necropolis Miguel explores is a magnificent creation, a heaving, neon-lit, labyrinth...Coco has heart as well as jokes, and there are probably worse ways of introducing children to the party-pooping concept of death.
Gibney's film honours the persistence of those families who have campaigned with great dignity for over two decades to see justice done.

The Florida Project is not a sentimental film and never fetishises its protagonists' poverty. It's oddly beautiful though, lingering over the sun-dappled highlights of a childhood that's about to go bad.
Suburbicon makes much of the venality lurking behind the carefully tended facades of post-war America's newly minted suburbia, and is not without its moments.
It's more of the same, and is probably funnier than the first film, but Daddy's Home 2 is the opposite of subtle and Gibson's performance is bizarre.
Jane, a gorgeous National Geographic documentary, uses fabulous 16mm archive footage and interviews with Goodall herself to document her achievements in the field.

Franco's portrayal of him is brilliant: obscured by prosthetics and that impenetrable accent, he digs deep into Tommy's complex and by no means unsympathetic personality, and never makes the mistake of letting his character in on the joke.
One of the most refreshing things about David Gordon Green's film is its avoidance of stars and stripes jingoism.
Clever, mean-spirited, gleefully unpleasant, Better Watch Out is an efficiently nasty Yuletide comic horror that operates as a sort of anti Home Alone.
I've a high tolerance for samurai films, but Blade of the Immortal did not charm me.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a touching, intimate film conducted mainly in Yiddish, and while the culture is particular, the human problems are universal.

The plots of the Pitch Perfect films are never complex, and this one seems especially rudimentary. But it doesn't matter because the frothy charms of the first two films have been equalled and possibly even bettered by Pitch Perfect 3.
Best of all, though, is Jack Black, whom I could watch pretending to be a pampered teenage prom queen till the cows come home.
Two hours and 20 minutes is longer than your average superhero yarn, but thanks to Sorkin's sparkling script and Chastain's intelligent acting, the time never drags.

Plummer memorably portrays him (J. Paul Getty) as a sly, watery-eyed egomaniac. He's the stand-out performer in a meticulous, slick and surprisingly amusing thriller that picks relentlessly at your faith in human nature.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Hostiles does not make the common mistake of insultingly sentimentalising Native Americans. It looks fantastic, and Christian Bale is at his intense and commanding best playing a soldier destroyed by the cruelty of war.

Mundcuczo's implicit criticisms of Europe's attitude to migrants are undone somewhat by his film's messianic undercurrents, but for all that it's endlessly inventive, and ends in memorable and unexpected fashion.
(Stiller's) recent work with Noah Baumbach has brought out the very best in him. He's excellent in Mike White's Brad's Status, a perceptive and witty comic drama about a man consumed by envy.
After a while, the jokes get desperate, but for a long time McDonagh's robust and emotional drama works, and McDormand is superb as the embattled but resourceful Mildred.
A film that is watchable and entertaining, but rather stilted dramatically, unimaginative in its storytelling and a little too in thrall with its waddling hero.

Brize's film is poetic, elegant and drifts dreamily through its melancholy story with wonderful sleight of hand, helped by the brilliant acting of Judith Chelma, who quivers with suppressed emotions as she stoically endures her lot.

In his sleek and entertaining performance, Hanks makes nodding references to Jason Robards' portrayal of Bradlee in All the President's Men, and Meryl Streep's quiet, uncertain portrayal of Graham is a joy to watch.
This clumsily orchestrated and preposterously plotted film judders to a standstill long before that speeding train does.
Emer Reynolds' magnificent account of the creation of Voyager I, a Nasa space probe launched in 1977 with the noble aim of introducing ourselves to extraterrestrials.
Though you'd never know it from her broad New Jersey drawl, Danielle Macdonald is an Australian actress, and may be something of a find.

If ever we needed an antidote to the mythologising pomposity of superhero movies, it's now. Enter Captain Underpants, a lovable and winningly irreverent animation inspired by the children's novels of Dav Pilkey.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: For the most part it's a beautifully made, mournful meditation on life and death, with a nervy sub-plot involving a stalker and lots of amusing asides. And Stewart is luminous throughout.
While The Salesman is not quite as good as [Farhadi's] other Oscar-winner, A Separation, it's a very strong piece of work.
[A] compelling documentary.
This film is not funny at all, but it is misogynistic - profoundly, obnoxiously, and needlessly so.
It's a fine film, lush, evocative and beautifully made.
James Gray's long but very entertaining film reminds us of the derring-do that once drove Britons to overrun the globe.

It's perfectly watchable and not without a sense of humour, though the jokes are sadly lacking late on. Decent cast too, led by Jake Gyllenhaal's wily space station veteran who's been up there so long he's not that keen on coming down.
Once the shooting starts Free Fire loses its sparkle, and descends into sub-Tarantino territory.
Johansson has reinvented herself as a sci-fi specialist in recent years, and is excellent here as the automaton with a troubled soul.
It's Alec Baldwin's wonderful Boss Baby voice-over that almost saves the day.
In this wonderfully orchestrated film, Mungiu illustrates how the omnipresence of backhanders and corruption ruins all achievement and makes real advancement impossible.
A very nicely handled chiller set in a small-town morgue.
Nixon's Dickinson is simultaneously fearless and brittle, and her superb performance helps vivify a film that is, by necessity, housebound.
An Oscar-nominated documentary which uses the life and words of writer James Baldwin as the starting point for a far-reaching visual investigation of the African-American experience.

Ann-Margret plays Albert's girlfriend, and Matt Dillon is a dim-witted cop, but it's Freeman, Caine and Arkin who make this film work: they're great together, and Arkin's comedy has lost none of its sharpness.

Table 19 starts slowly but pings to life once the diners have been assembled: Craig Robinson and Lisa Kudrow are excellent as the unhappy couple, and Stephen Merchant's comic timing as Walter is superb.
Julia Ducournau's feature debut Raw has been described as one of the most unsettling horror films ever made, but there's a whole lot more to it than that. It gets under your skin from the word go.
Absurd? You betcha, but boy do director F Gary Gray and his cameramen handle the whole thing well.
The Handmaiden is sensuous rather than lurid, an erotic thriller with a sense of humour and more than a few twists up its sleeve.
Good books tend to make bad movies, but The Sense of an Ending is a rare and satisfying exception.
Ridley Scott handles the planetary and space sequences beautifully, especially an action-packed climax that will have you on the edge of your seat.
The chemistry between Watson and Stevens is more crucial to Beauty and the Beast's success, and there are no problems in that department.
Handsome Devil is a funny and touching coming-of-age story set at a rugby-mad Irish boarding school.
Jordan Peele's Get Out is so clever you could write a thesis on it the length of War and Peace.
Atmospheric, but rather glibly directed, Gold is fun but sometimes feels like a feature-length episode of Dallas.
[A] solid and efficient thriller.

The Forest plunders the J-horror vocabulary to muster what jumps it can, and is pretty nice to look at. But only the really good horror films know how to end on a high note, and this isn't one of them.

Ben Mendelsohn is satisfyingly nasty as the film's principal villain, and while I'd like to have seen a little more of Mads Mikkelsen, an ensemble cast of proper actors gives the film authenticity, and grit.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Passengers is entertaining enough, lovely to look at and there are some ingenious touches.
The footage used in Otto Bell's film is breathtaking, but unfortunately it's accompanied by an overbearing soundtrack and commentary that cheapen Aisholpan's achievements.
Franco's pretty good at comedy and has fun playing the obnoxious but decent Laird. Though the cast in general do their best, it's all in the service of a flabby, aimless script.
Someday, someone will have to explain to me how Collateral Beauty ever got made.
An engaging Irish documentary about the all-too-brief Formula One career of Drogheda driver Tommy Byrne.

Driver is superb in a supporting role and disappears too quickly, while Neeson is as intense as I've ever seen him playing an older and wiser Jesuit who's arrived at a silent accommodation with his faith.

Weaver is very good as Conor's severe and brittle grandmother and Felicity Jones, who's dominating the multiplexes at the moment in the latest Star Wars vehicle, delivers a very different kind of performance here.
The actors, however, are not at fault here, the story is -- or rather the lack of one.
[Beckinsale] deserves better, and looks like she knows it.
The early scenes have a certain gritty intensity, but once Coughlin heads south the film loses focus, and Affleck is cast adrift as the only three-dimensional character.

Manchester by the Sea is wistful, elegiac, and the sights and sounds of an Atlantic fishing town are beautifully captured by the muted cinematography of Jody Lee Lipes. But there are moments of high drama, even comedy.
Chazelle pulls it off magnificently, helped by the fearless commitment of his two leads.
The nightmarish battle scenes on Okinawa are masterfully handled, and include some of the most sickeningly violent sequences I've ever had to endure.
Boyle's visual storytelling is fluent and imaginative, and the performances are excellent.
While no masterpiece, Sing is a good deal of fun: Matthew McConaughey heads up a fine voice cast, and some of the singing is wonderful.
Jackson tells his story well, but there were times when I found myself wondering if I should be enjoying myself quite so much given Denial's subject matter.
This is badly directed stuff: frenetic editing makes the innumerable fight scenes incomprehensible, and gratuitous sadism underpins a sorry exercise.
At two hours and 43 minutes, Toni Erdmann may test the patience of some, but it's a wise, insightful, boldly eccentric and, at times, hilarious film that raises all sorts of interesting questions.
Worthiness, then, is not in short supply in Loving, and the solid performances of Negga and Joel Edgerton put a human face on some very ugly legislation.
Risible, predictable, unintentionally camp, Unforgettable is hilarious but never on purpose, and would almost constitute a good night out.
There's a dizziness to Sheridan's cinematic storytelling here that at times makes the film hard to follow.
Beatty's performance is one of the production's brighter spots; his screenplay is the real problem as it never quite decides which story to tell, never mind how to tell it.

Berlin Syndrome [is] an ambitious thriller from Australian director Cate Shortland that aims for the psychological richness of Hitchcock and early Polanski but falls frustratingly short. Teresa Palmer is very effective, however
Ghastly.
This worthy, solidly made drama would remain frustratingly two-dimensional were it not for Brian Cox.
Gentle it may be, even slightly clichéd in its storytelling, but I enjoyed Gifted, a nicely written treatise on the mixed blessing of being a childhood prodigy.
What emerges is a picture of a rather sweet and vulnerable woman who was overwhelmed by the trappings of wealth, and fame.
Salty, funny, and enlivened by some fantastic Dublin rap music, Cardboard Gangsters has a rare authenticity in terms of its subject matter and location.
The problem with these films has always been the fact that they fatally lack charm. No matter how silly a voice you give them, the Transformers themselves are impossible to engage with.
I really enjoyed it, but don't blame me if you don't.
If From the Land of the Moon were not in French, and did not star Marion Cotillard, we'd be rolling around in the aisles laughing at it.
movie_title: From the Land of the Moon (Mal de pierres) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Hampstead is a slighter, sillier affair, and reminded me of one of Richard Curtis's fluffier endeavours. It's very watchable, though, thanks to the winning pairing of Diane Keaton and Brendan Gleeson.

Pat Shortt and Ardal O'Hanlon provide emotional resonance playing their respective parents. O'Hanlon in particular is excellent as an older man coping with depression, and overall, Twice Shy is a little gem.
The film's visuals are splendid, epic, and remind you of a David Lean film.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Halal Daddy is a well-meaning but ham-fisted attempt to refract the complexities of multicultural Ireland.
An interesting if rather unfocused documentary by Laura Poitras.

In Edgar Wright's glibly stylish drama, bank raids and getaways are carefully choreographed in time to the music. This is mildly interesting at first, but fails to disguise the fact that this is a bog-standard genre picture.
A sprawling Swedish drama that plunges back and forth in time, Hannes Holm's A Man Called Ove can be distilled to one simple message -- don't judge a book by its cover.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Kirsten Dunst, Elle Fanning and Angourie Rice play young, frustrated women whose various foibles are skilfully revealed during Coppola's elegant, well-acted and wickedly funny drama.
This gag-laden kids' animation is bright, breezy and doesn't hang about.
Sadly, Niki Caro's film makes a right old mess of telling this fantastic story, and even the normally resplendent Chastain does not escape with her dignity entirely intact.
It's a tense, atmospheric, cleverly crafted period thriller.
This is real cinema: spare, terse, expertly edited. I saw it in 70mm, and so should you if you can. But mostly, you should just go see it -- it's a masterpiece.
Du Maurier's stories are all about mystery, and atmosphere, and Roger Michell understands this very well. His film is handsome, genuinely cinematic, and both Claflin and Weisz are well cast.
The script lacks vigour, and overall the enterprise is hopelessly derivative.
There's a nice twist involving a female car called Cruz, and the animation in the racing sequences is very good.
Full of humour, and beautifully acted, After the Storm tellingly explores the slights, resentments, rivalries and grudging affection that are lifeblood of every family.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There's something appealingly old-fashioned about Their Finest, a film that recalls with warmth and humour the glory days of British cinema, and includes some lovely acting, particularly from Nighy.

Painstakingly made using a stop-motion animation style similar to that favoured by Tim Burton, My Life as a Courgette is not at all as grim as it sounds, and focuses more on hope and kindness than the dark starts to the children's lives.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Promise tells its story well, and should be commended for doing so.
Pugh is outstandingly good as the spirited but ruthless young bride, who starts out as a seething victim before seizing control of her life in spectacular fashion.
The jokes are good, the music's super cheesy, but the galaxy doesn't seem in too much peril.
Sleepless commits the cardinal sin for a thriller -- it's rather dull.
It's very silly, and very funny, and Steve Coogan, Kenneth Branagh and Simon Callow give their all in hammy cameos.
Harmonium builds uneasiness masterfully, and midway through a shocking act changes the film's direction entirely.
This all sounds sickeningly mawkish, but the hovering presence of death adds salt to the proceedings, and Hallstrom and his actors have made this film oddly watchable.
There's nothing wrong with anyone's acting. The problem here is the concept, which seems absurdly forced.
There's a sort of soul to these films at their best, and here it's provided by the excellent Waterston, whose character seems like a gentler version of Ripley in the orginals.
Katell Quillévéré's Franco-Belgian drama Heal the Living is worth watching for its opening scenes alone.

[it's about] a depressingly familiar theme in Iranian society: the side-lining of women by a bull-headed, retrograde theocracy. But Behzadi's direction, and Dwolatshahi's subtle, elegant performance, make Inversion a lot less dryly didactic than that.
While the film descends into the usual pyrotechnical showdown late on, it's watchable, well made and not excessively violent overall, which should make it suitable for older children.
It flies along at a lunatic pace and while about half the jokes don't work, it is occasionally entertaining.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The plots of these films have always been nonsensical, but this one seems daft above and beyond the call of duty.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Other Side of Hope is a film full of playful asides and moving moments, outbursts of music, joy and despair.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There are few words, but The Red Turtle doesn't need them: nature is the star of this film.
Even the inevitable cameos from David Hasselhoff and Pamela Anderson are mishandled, thrown away.
It's predictable stuff for the most part, and the jokes thin out half way through, but Schumer and Hawn are great together, and Schumer wrings every last drop of laughter out of the script.
Sombre, well-made and relentlessly depressing, In View is an earnest study of crippling grief that features a very strong performance from Caoilfhoinn Dunne.
What the original actors executed with ease, this lot make look clumsy, and joyless.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: NatGeo really should have made Killing Kennedy a feature-length theatrical release, as the 95-minute run time makes the story feel too compressed.

movie_review_blurb: Top-notch performances buoy up this sentimental (some might say clichéd) musical romp -- and who doesn't enjoy a guilty pleasure of the vintage Parisian variety?
The performances never falter, and even James Horner's heavy-handed score can't dim the film's unfathomable, unshakable ending.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: British cinema fans shouldn't miss this one.
Every bit as visceral and provocative as the original, but cinematographer Enrique Chediak's deserted London can't hold a candle to Anthony Dod Mantle's.
The purity of the docu conceit falls apart thanks to the intrusion of a spooky score and deliberately eerie camera shots.
Hegedus and Pennebaker treat this event as both rehearsal and performance, allowing occasional moments of beauty and humanity to peek through.
Poor plot twists and CGI-heavy action further muddle what might have been an intriguing story of fanaticism and superstition.
Those wanting to see a film devoid of clichés and implausibility should look elsewhere. Still, Hopkins is terrific, inhabiting the role like, well, a man possessed.
There's an annoying "buddy movie" feeling to this that just won't go away. At least Centurion had a sexy witch to offset the unintentional homo-eroticism.
Fattening fairy tales for the screen is tricky, and Hardwicke gets it half right, valorizing romance over duty, integrity over tyranny.
This is really a story of finding peace and purpose in a chaotic world.
This is a gritty, dreamy Everyman story, sure to resonate with viewers who grew up on the wrong side of the tracks.
As happens with big-screen comics, the dialogue fizzles at times. But mostly this is a delicious mash-up of styles and genres: gothic, steampunk, Wild West, martial arts, dystopian fun.
For those like me, deeply imprinted by Siegel's version, Coppola's reimagining is artful, clever, and more than a little beguiling.

The film has an alluring lexicon of moods: luminous, glossy, animalistic, pastoral. If not for the trail of corpses left behind, this might be reminiscent of other dreamy European coming-of-age narratives.
The film is never self-consciously stylized or manipulative; even the hauntingly lovely score by Warren Ellis does not overburden the action. This story feels plausible and intimate.
A Man Called Ove's darkness and humor are balanced artfully, a merit one often sees in Scandinavian film.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Dominique Abel and Fiona Gordon's vision tries to elevate the everyday to a realm of magic by way of the absurd.
The ending of the film comes off as part cliff-hanger, part poetic justice, and altogether odd - it made me immediately want to know what's next on the menu.
As with many of his other films, Darren Aronofsky's mother! teems with sublime metaphors.
Lucky is thought-provoking, but not preachy or precious.
... the film turns out to be a beautifully photographed and thoughtful nail-biter, suspenseful in a way that illuminates what must have been Norway's most terrifying moments.
I enjoyed God's Own Country for its realistic style and its unflinching vision of intimacy.

Director Craig Gillespie deftly creates a story full of humor, suspense, and revelatory events, the latter involving such high stakes some viewers may find themselves gasping, cheering, and applauding as if they're, well, attending a sporting event.
Could this film be any better? The cinematography beguiles. The dialogue is natural yet artful. The cast is first rate in every way
I love the way Blame captures the kaleidoscopic emotional experience of being a teenage girl, one moment ecstatic and exuberant, the next dreamy and dark, the next angry and despairing.

With this effort, Trier is digging deeper into what looks like his customary theme: when self-acceptance becomes a form of empowerment it can lead to redemption -- if one can muster the will to survive.
With Unrest, Brea has crafted film that will no doubt improve awareness, outreach, and support for many people whose visibility and voices have been too dim for too long.
The film's stunning final images suggest that there will be no end to this passionately creative endeavor, driven by the hunger to satisfy.

This film's tensive beauty and white-hot performances, not to mention its brilliant score and letter-perfect direction, may well distract the average filmgoer from the profound messages lurking in the screenplay.
The result is a well acted film that conjures up a Golden Age of Hollywood vibe, enlivened by references to a halcyon era gone by.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It features breathtakingly beautiful colored pencil drawings.
The voiceover is simple, taken from a poem, and the animation's colorful surreal treatment of claymation is whimsical, inventive, and deeply affecting.
Lou is a sweet, funny, and kinesthetic Disney piece.
Garden Party is a dynamic, brilliant short that catalogs the leftover detritus of a fancy party.
It's a dark twist on several familiar Roald Dahl fairy tales, with some slightly adult themes and very funny action, all narrated by a rather sage old wolf.
A truly devastating piece, given the recent mass murder in Parkland, Florida, but it unfolds with an almost eerie calm.
This is a lyrical, powerful piece by Kevin Wilson, Jr.
A young woman moves through the mayhem with almost serene courage.
Predictable but very well acted fare.
Realistic and moving, with beautiful cinematography, this is a stirring call for awareness of the plight of deaf schoolchildren.

The plot is straightforward, but the film's tone and style supply an artful mix of sensations. The lighting is colorful and heady...The film's rhythms gracefully accompany her endeavor, rising and falling with every setback or tiny, incremental victory.
This sympathetic, enthralling film is a tribute to her talent and courage, the gifts behind the alluring impact of her unforgettable face.
This taut, often hilarious, thriller is a stellar example of why Scandinavian cinema continues to impress.
This film is definitely one of the most interesting documentaries of the year so far.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Spielberg's timing is nearly perfect, and so is his film.
The performances by Ange Dargent and Théophile Baquet could not be better, and it's their authenticity and abandon that make this film a fine addition to the coming-of-age canon.

The uplifting ending is not necessarily in keeping with Millhauser's pensive, downbeat tone. But it's a hard-won redemption that trumpets exuberantly in favor of young womanhood's need for shouting, singing and silence in equal measure.
The tiny cast of Goodnight Mommy is impressive indeed: the naturalistic style is perfect for the slow building tension that heats up to fever pitch by the climax.
Watching this documentary is not only a fascinating exploration of one of television's greatest artists, but a potent reminder of how deeply engaged we have been with this mode of storytelling.
movie_title: Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Charlie Kaufman crafts worlds where people find love in unlikely places, and lose love so easily you'd think they actually want to be miserable.
For those like me, deeply imprinted by Siegel's version, Coppola's reimagining is beguilingly satisfying.
Maleficent is genuinely entertaining, beautiful, and thought-provoking.
[Free Fire] is an impressive display of innovation and shift in form for this talented, well-established filmmaking team.
Horror fans in search of a smarter-than-average thriller that will make their hearts race and their viscera quiver should not miss this one.
Even given a misplaced sense of genre at times, when Circle decides to be a horror film, its intense visuals and creepy mood are more than up to the task.
What makes this film so haunting is not simply its frightening take on our near future (treating as if it's the recent past): it's also in the film's gorgeous photography and dreamy music.
The Road is a murky harbinger of our future, but perhaps more urgently, a cautionary tale clearly reflecting our present.
[Silence] stayed with me, like a day of cold and somber weather that affects your mood for weeks, because it has somehow worked its way into your bones.
The restoration and re-issue of Julie Dash's masterpiece is a valuable reminder that black female filmmakers are still woefully underrepresented in contemporary cinema.
The Witch's brief jolts of violence seem perfectly calibrated to knock us out of our seats: not by generating horror on the screen, but within our viscera.
Add Todd Haynes' midcentury love story Carol to your list of favorite Christmas-themed films.
The Last House on the Left is perhaps best seen as a reminder of why remakes of classic horror films almost always fail.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Even though the dialogue occasionally feels calculated, there is an undeniably compelling air of menace and secrecy generated, making it hard to guess what might happen next.
Even amid the complexity of his vision, there are moments of searing simplicity and emotional speechlessness that even the most hardened loner among us cannot fail to take to heart.

King Hu's Dragon Inn stands alone - a seminal example of a genre that continues to thrill admirers and fans throughout the world.
The dark and twisted labyrinth at the heart of this story is thoroughly unexpected, and ultimately terrifying.
Therapy for a Vampire takes a primal urge and runs with it. There are unexpected moments of glee and grotesquerie, comic twists and turns.
movie_title: Therapy for a Vampire (Der Vampir auf der Couch) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's tempting to dismiss this as directorial misfiring or lack of clarity. And yet there are indelible moments of pathos, pain, and wonder.
Alex Gibney's powerful documentary looks closely at some recent examples of malware designed to wreak havoc worldwide.
Porter's thoughtful visit to the frontlines of this battle serves up much-needed breaths of fresh air in a toxic media environment that minimizes women's struggle for legal healthcare.
Bonnie and Clyde don't really know that killing kills. The film does -- unlike the run of movies about violence now, which mostly know that killing sells.
Earlier Antonioni films have often seemed studied, but not this one. Its details are easy and apropos.
The film earlier has one of the very best Tracy-Hepburn love scenes, full of the sense of private shelter that they uniquely purvey.
George Lucas, who made American Graffiti, has put together a sci-fi film that draws on any number of associations. Star Wars is both amazing and familiar.

Cold, masterly, without pathos, and not even particularly sympathetic; it has the noble structure of accuracy.

Poor Morgan, one feels; victim of a satire that doesn't bite, lost in a technical confusion of means and ends, and emerging like an identikit photograph, all bits and pieces and no recognisable face.

movie_review_blurb: Too often, though, potentially comic scenes are spoilt by faulty timing, a determination to hammer home the joke and play for an easy laugh.
It's a cool, violent film, romantic in a disciplined, disenchanted way about its battling gangsters.

One could, no doubt, if sufficiently determined, see all this as some deep, dark (in fact, practically subterranean) satire on the military mind. But there's precious little evidence of irony in Robert Aldrich's direction or the script.

Here is an enigmatically modern film with the deceptive air of a staidly old-fashioned one.
Mistrust a movie with too many close-ups of Bisto Kid children and doleful dogs: they suggest a director cleverly boxing his way out of some very tight script corners.
Sebastian is wayward, a bit too consciously out to please, but enjoyable precisely because it never comes too close to defining its own terms.

A film in which grandeur of conception is not up to grandeur of setting.
This remains a failure for which I would trade ten successes: a totally absorbing experience on the screen, a film of deceptive, tricky surfaces and cold perceptions.

Mr Hall's halfway house between screen and stage looks almost as uncomfortable a perch as the curious grave-like earthwork in which Judy Dench's Titania has her sleeping-quarters.
The mixture of posed speeches, arty apparitions and some willfully unfocused camerawork, suggests some kind of timeslip, as though the film had been deep-frozen twenty years ago.
This is the purest piece of entertainment filmmaking we have had from him in some years; it is also, which does not inevitably follow, the most purely entertaining.
A brilliant, crammed, allusive work.
The Party hardly gets beyond a rather watery smile. A pity, because the idea remains engaging.

All is lethargy, inanity, a yawning prettiness.
The whole film crackles with a painful electricity.
When it's good, though, Szabo's film is very good indeed.

A luminous, haunting adventure.
Pretentious, undeniably. Yet there is a hypnotic lure which has to do almost entirely with the setting.

movie_review_blurb: It is all sympathetic enough but low on vitality.
A film so critical of others' attitudes should perhaps have given more positive vetting to its own.
Francis Ford Coppola, whose previous film was the bouncing You're a Big Boy Now, again directs like a bulldozer with a sense of humour.
A visually sumptuous - and perhaps languidly paced - tale that immerses the viewer in a deeply atmospheric world.

All-around genuinely thoughtful filmmaking and one heck of a performance from Saoirse Ronan resulting in a tense, funny, touching and, overall, wildly enjoyable experience.

Action captured in an all-encompassing yet perspective manner and top notch performances resulting in piece with the power to stick with you long after the credits roll.
A monster movie-disaster film hybrid that doesn't take itself too seriously. The combination works beautifully making the piece wildly enjoyable and surprisingly believable, too.

A tough watch and when the sadness peaks, it leads you to write it off as the slightest bit exploitative, but the performances are so raw, it's nearly impossible not to be swayed.
Not only reveals that Abigail Breslin as an incredibly talented singer, but an actress who can take a subpar script, breathe life into it and make it somewhat enjoyable, too.

movie_review_blurb: If Napoleon Dynamite's Napoleon and Deb lived happily ever after and had a kid, that kid might be Spork.
Such an entertaining, engaging and well-made film, you practically feel as though you're part of the world yourself. It isn't just a movie; it's an experience.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A little 'Nightmare on Elm Street,' part 'Exorcist' and a hint of 'Paranormal Activity.' Honors genre expectations while delivering a fresh and horrifyingly unpredictable experience.
Just like the memory of the wolf pack's big night out in Thailand, funny jokes seemed to have simply slipped the filmmakers' minds.
An idiot's guide to not even amateurish, but flat out terrible filmmaking.

movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Delivers a respectable presentation of hardship, but still manages to maintain a light enough tone making the film a viable source of entertainment and not just a pity party.
Looks aren't everything but here they're enough to keep you entertained most of the film. Beyond that, the only way it will have resonance is through the Daft Punk soundtrack.
Easily one of the most emotionally impactful films of the year and is something that will certainly haunt you long after the credits roll in the best possible way.
Painfully boring.
