Slackers, Rejoice! Makes the comedy honor roll for being inventive and riotously funny.
Do these snakes deliver? Do they ever! More action-packed fun than just about any movie seen this summer.
By the numbers, teen-dance romance that takes it's lead from Save The Last Dance, Dirty Dancing and numerous others that it shamelessly imitates.
a slow moving but uncompromising film that will have you in it's grip days later, largely due to the galvanizing performance of Ryan Gosling.
Shines a welcome light on a group of everyday heroes who, in risking their own lives to save others helped turn America's darkest hour into their finest - and ours.
Don't even think about missing this one! Little Miss Sunshine Sparked a bidding war at Sundance and is worth every penny. Riotously funny!
Expertly written and directed, this outing is definitely not for the squeamish. So guys, be sure you take your girlfriend to hang on to!
Early reviews compare this to Hitchcock, but Hitch was never this obvious. Even at less than 90 minutes, this is a drawn-out, butt numbing sit.
Talladega Nights is the summer comedy winner that clocks more laughs per minute than any other!
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Spending time with this motley crew is probably the best reason there is to set sail for a multiplex all summer.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Pure holiday entertainment, a wonderful, toe-tapping musical gift everyone is likely to love.
You'll laugh your Heineken off! Check your brain at the door for this hilarious and unapologetically raunchy yukfest.
A startling political thriller and the year's most urgent and important film, you owe it to yourself to see this beautifully written and directed movie.
We'll be talking about this one for years to come.
It's fun but a little too homogenized for its own good, beocming more likea very expensive sitcom pilot.
Tailor made for future Sunday school classes everywhere, this by-the-numbers account adds nothing new to the story but has lots of pretty pictures
Note for Michael Mann fans: A thrilling new director's edition on DVD has 20 minutes of new footage.
It is hard to imagine what possible point there was in turning it into a movie. Nothing MOVES.
A haunting and remarkable emotional journey that takes us places movies rarely dare to go.
Destined to become the most hilarious musical epic ever.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A hugely entertaining high-octane action suspense thriller.
One of the year's best pictures, an unforgettable motion picture experience with an outstanding cast that shines brightly right down to the smallest part.
There are a lot of laughs to be mined from the spectacle of ego-inflated superstars tripping over each other trying to grab a $65 gold statue, but you won't find them here.
Our advice - if you do feel compelled to hit the mall to see this movie, don't go out to eat afterwards.
A toe-tapping 'happy feat' of remarkable animated movie-making.
A gut-wrenching torture scene is just one reason why Daniel Craig deserves to become the first Bond ever to be nominated for a Best Actor Oscar.
If this sounds like your idea of a fun movie night, go for it. But its not exactly ours.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's pleasant stuff, going down about as easy as a vintage merlot.
The reason to see the movie is Bale who can play slow-burning psychosis about as well as any actor today and is outstanding again.
If you are into extremes this ultra-violent blood feast is probably just your ticket.
movie_title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Ferrell proves just the right choice, nicely underplaying for a change and ratcheting up his game opposite major talents.
This mishmash retread fails to find its own identity on any level and should head straight to cable TV where it belongs.
It its another 'Truman' show you want, Infamous certainly will fill you up.
Robin Williams turns in his smartest, funniest performance in at least a decade.
This may be Annette Bening's finest screen work ever.
A cotton candy account that plays loosely with the truth in trying to be hip, contemporary and pink.
A skillfully told, beautifully shot coming-of-age story.
An exciting, thought-provoking and moving motion picture experience.
This dazzling film and first-rate thriller holds you spellbound and doesn't let go.
A hell-raising soul stirring musical documentary about the right of free speech.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An explosive real life screen thriller. Derek Luke gives an Oscar-worthy performance.
An unqualified triumph from Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu. World class filmmaking of the highest order.
This computer animated time-waster is a bit too frenetic for its own good.
Thank you Kazakhstan for giving the world a pure comedic genius.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: As raw, rich and edgy as it gets.
A slight but amusing british comedy.
With more white powder than even Al Pacino's nose housed in 'Scarface', Steep pushes human endurance and achievement to the limit with indescribable eye-popping crazy feats of Big Mountain glory.

The ads proudly trumpet this supernatural drama as coming from the producers of 'The Sixth Sense' and the co-writer of 'Batman Begins'. Unfortunately the ingredients that made those films work so brilliantly are, well, INVISIBLE in this gimmicky ghost sto
We will use our own powers of clairvoyance to predict a mercifully short life in theatres and a quick trip to the DVD shelves.
It's closer to a small kind of affecting and simply human story we rarely get to see in mainstream movies anymore.
It has been exactly 50 years since Sidney Lumet made his first movie but let's hope on the basis of this shattering edge-of-your-seat stuff that he hasn't made his last.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Finally a really smart, really funny movie about the ups and downs of life, love and family.
A powerful human drama that rips into you like a hurricane. Suspenseful, emotional and completely engrossing throughout.
A political potboiler guaranteed to get your heart racing. It pushes all the buttons these kinds of suspenseful dramas usually do.
The premise of this film has just got to be the ultimate wet dream for your average vampire.

Del Toro delivers another powerfully simple and effective performance. Berry is fine but her character just doesn't add up, perhaps inevitable in a movie that seems to have been lost somewhere in translation.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Ben Affleck may not have made the wisest acting choices in recent years ('Gigli, anyone?) but here, in an impressive directorial debut, he proves he definitely has what it takes for a career behind the camera.
It simply rocks. In every way, an exceptional film. This is one of those rare gems you must not miss.
Both stars definitely deliver and the movie directed by Kenneth Branagh is handsome enough, but for some reason it just doesn't connect the dots.
It's the real deal. A whimsical, funny, moving film. Gosling is no less than astounding in the surprise movie comedy treat of the year.
It will most likely be admired by those who actually already reached their OWN 'golden age'.
In many ways this traditional-looking flick gives off a vibe of been there-seen it but at the same time it pulsates with a raw energy and rhythm all its own.
Just when you thought Hollywood might have forgotten how to make a smart adult thriller along comes a film like this.
It marks a return to the lost art of true storytelling, every bit as epic as 'The Godfather' and just as fascinating to see.
An outrageously hilarious and RAUNCHY comedy that creates so many huge - and we mean humungous - laughs you will probably have to see it more than once just to catch all the dialogue.

It's kind of a chinese 'Casablanca' set in 1942 Shanghai. This is an extraordinarily well-made movie, something we've come to expect from the man who gave the world 'Brokeback Mountain' and 'Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon'.
A bone-chilling, disturbing thriller about a forbidden subject the government would probably like to sweep under the rug.
A rare bird in the world of mainstream movies. It's thoughtful and literate enough to make it seem positively original.
A wonderful mix of humor and humanity, vintage Wes Anderson that's fine and funny as he takes us on a soul searching magical mystery tour.

Pure Disney formula stuff (think 'The Pacifier' and 'Three Men And A Baby'). But despite its predictability the movie turns out to be a comic touchdown for The Rock who scores lots of laughs in this winning family entertainment.
A riveting ticking time-bomb of a movie that really works. The last 30 minutes are so intense you won't be able to move.
A mystic and mesmerizing journey of adventure and self-discovery.
'Superbad' and 'Knocked Up' got the delicate balance just right for this kind of raunchfest. 'Chuck' apparently didn't get the memo.
A masterwork that already has the feel of a classic. This take on the last days of an iconic western figure constantly surprises and intrigues.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Something that would have been a bad idea for an Off-Broadway concept show has inexplicably been turned into a bloated two hour and eleven minute movie musical.
A heartbreaking story that is told with honor and intelligence in a stirring film that will haunt you long after seeing it.
Like the character Douglas plays you may have to search to see this hidden gem yourself, but its well worth the hunt.
In the end 'Eastern' promises - and delivers - an intelligent film full of it's own brand of sound and fury.
The film's poster showing Woodcock holding two strategically placed basketballs is funnier than anything in the actual movie!
Think 'Harry Potter' meets 'Bridge To Terabithia'. While perfectly fine entertainment for people age 12 and under, adults will find the whole thing a bit of a snooze.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A true shocker that will shatter your nerves and get you talking.
Seinfeld, what happened? You've gone soft on us. Sure, some of it is fun but where's the sting?
Agree or disagree, love it or hate it, you won't be able to turn away. It's Robert Redford's urgent, impassioned wake up call for America.
Unparalleled visual splendor, a bloody red-velvet fever dream of a musical for people who think they HATE musicals.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Even though it's wildly unbelievable and rather hokey at times, this is total entertainment from start to finish.
You'll want to stand up and cheer for Charlie Wilson, a smart and absolutely irresistable true tale about a guy who dared to make a difference.
After 'Superbad' and 'Knocked Up', Judd Apatow has now pulled off the movie equivalent of the Triple Crown.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: An absolute triumph for Denzel Washington. Here is a movie that can make a difference. What more can you ask from a film?
This chick-lit flick is an 'English Patient' style epic.
It brings up lots of questions to ponder and mostly succeeds as a fascinating, if frightening statement on the way we are.
A humane and enriching motion picture experience that soars and takes flight as a first class piece of filmmaking.
Kids at the preview screening ate it up but everyone else will probably be shouting 'ALVIN!!! SHUT THE F*** UP!'"
Mind-blowing excitement, an expert thriller that really thrills and makes you think. A special shout-out for the dog, Sam. Now that's acting!
Incredibly John Cusack has never been nominated for an Academy Award but this movie may change that. He's simply terrific in a fine and moving film.
A pure charmer and a heartfelt original, you will find this a totally unexpected, enormously satisfying and oddly rewarding trip to the movies.
Like Lord Of The Rings and Chronicles Of Narnia it's a visual feast that transports you to an alternate world of jaw-dropping awe, unforgettable images and pure adventure.
A psychological thriller that focuses more on the 'psycho' than the 'logical' for its own good. But who says everything has to make sense when you're just trying to blow a few brains out?
Just in time for the holidays comes this vile exercise in yuletide terror. On the plus side Rachel Nichols gets to run around in a slip most of the time.
Tough to watch? Sure. Worth it? Absolutely. Perhaps the most inspiring film in many years.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The filmmakers of Awake have crafted a domestic thriller that just may end up putting you ASLEEP.
This motion-capture animated version is genuinely exciting to see although the process still gives us the creeps.
It's a shame that with the vast canvas of this seemingly never-ending conflict that this crap is the image De Palma wants to convey.
A wry, devastatingly witty look at a family you won't soon forget, no matter how hard you try.
It's so 'G' you almost want to gag, but its heart is in the right place. Take a kid or take a pass.
Its success is largely due to the casting of Amy Adams who is simply sensational. She weaves some serious movie magic into this thing.
It can be admired for trying something a little different from the usual family film, but in the end, it just doesn't work. At all.
Cate Blanchett has delivered the most audacious, astounding and entertaining performance of the year by ANYONE, male or female.
Film adaptations of King's work tend to be hit and miss, but with last summer's '1408' and now this scary-as-hell flick, he's on a roll.
It delivers top-notch action, dazzling gunplay and lots of fireworks. What more could we ask for?
A remarkably well-detailed doc that proves 'Rock The Casbah' is not just that song from the cell phone commercials.
movie_title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten (2007)

movie_review_blurb: John Cusack is perfect but it's Bobby Coleman who delivers one of the most uniquely original kid performances ever. You actually believe he might be from Mars.
A great American film. A dark and sometimes bleakly comic vision of our violent culture.
A ho-ho-hum yuletide comedy trying to shoehorn Vaughn's fast talking wise-guy brand into a warm and fuzzy Christmas confection that seems like it has been focus-grouped to smithereens.
The film successfully navigates the tricky waters of family dysfunction. A savagely funny/tragic/hopeful portrait of the way we are circa 2007.

It packs enough red-hot fiery action for six movies. The fact that it makes some suprisingly ironic and pertinent points about extreme violence as entertainment gives it the kind of gravitas blood & guts films like this rarely aspire to achieve.
This story has been told at least four times too many already!
A fast-paced, smart and exciting black comedy that is a wild trip, a nifty mixture of acerbic wit and suspense that would totally absurd if its most incredible parts didn't happen to be true.
How did this little gem EVER sneak into theatres this summer? Laughs, insight, human emotion...What a concept!
It's a beautifully crafted, superbly well-acted suspense-filled tale that will creep you out.
It's the toys 'r us in this awesome sci-fi blockbuster. It's bound to produce several inferior sequels but the pure joy of discovery from this kick-ass original is not-to-be-missed.
One of those quirky little movies that thinks it is much smarter than it actually is. For a fine Kingsley fix, rent 'Sexy Beast' instead.
Funny, sad, eye-opening, infuriating, shocking- and pure Michael Moore. A must for anyone who cares about the state of their health and the health of the States!
A powerful,provocative and spellbinding film. This is a movie not to be missed and one that will be a force at Oscar time.
This bright family comedy is a great time at the movies for everyone, thanks in large part to the brilliant Steve Carell.
When it comes to Hollywood's treatment of his works, Stephen King hasn't always hit the jackpot. But with this smart and highly entertaining ghost story his luck may change.
This truly inventive and wacky tale of love among the nerds is a rare original and a real find.
The concept is great and the movie has its moments. Just not enough of them.
Sure, the CGI work is all pro and the Silver Surfer effect is a cool visual but the dumb lines and forced chemistry just don't cut it.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A remarkable portrait by Marion Cotillard so uncannily rich and detailed it defies description. Screen acting just doesn't get much better than this.
Cowabunga, dudes. Summer officially begins and as surfer bird movies go this one hangs a perfect 10.
If this sounds like your cup of crud - and you know who you are - you probably won't be disappointed.
A harrowing and inspiring tale of courage and endurance. It shows us the best in ourselves.
This one hits the jackpot as a sleek and stylish caper flick even Sinatra himself would have loved.
A virtual cinematic guide to pop culture circa 2007. How it all plays 10 years from now doesn't really matter because we guarantee you will be quoting lines from this movie for a long time to come.
The animated blast of the summer- a rowdy, racy, brilliantly executed sci-fi psychedelic head trip that may just blow you away.
Riveting, repulsive and creepy, it takes paranoia to the outer limits in a film that crawls under your skin.
With state-of-the-art everything, this is the 'Pirates' to top them all.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Although yet another set-in-the-80's coming of age film, it's a familiar but affecting story.
The kind of strong, intelligent adult drama that was an endangered species in Hollywood until 'Crash'. Overall, it's a winning bet at the movies.
A musical for people who HATE musicals.
Green isn't just the color of ogres. It also represents the cold hard cash studio execs can again expect to reap, no matter how often they repeat the same basic joke.
It's not worth ten bucks and parking, but it is a passable DVD rental which is where this sitcom-level script can be seen the way it should, on a 27-inch TV screen.
You might want to check out this pulse-pounder in the lull between swinging superheroes and yo-ho-ho'ing pirates. You may just discover that THIS is the little sequel that could.
A fantastic trip to the City Of Lights thru the eyes of some of the world's greatest stars and filmmakers. A memorable movie experience like no other.
An intense and startling movie for our times. It hits you right between the eyes.
A bright , easy to like technicolored comedy that details the simple truths of trying to find happiness when you live in nowheresville and everyone is in your shit.

If most of the characters in this edition seem to be zigzagging in confusing fashion from good to bad and back again, the awesome production is forturnately in safe hands as usual with director Sam Raimi putting the human touch above the dizzying and dazz
A unique and surprising movie experience. A strong alternative to the current sequelitis plaguing the industry.
Super BAD!
If for any reason your wife or girlfriend - or both - try to drag you to this thing, break up with them instead. It would be less painful.
More fireworks than any other film this summer. Bruce is back in the one role that fits him like a glove.

This Sundance Film Festival winner will give you a lump in your throat and a sense of pride reliving a great moment the whole world once shared that now seems virtually forgotten. This movie guarantees it won't be.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Who knew 'Dumb And Dumber' would turn out to be one of the most influential films of all time?
Big screen entertainment that rides right next to the great ones, a blazing action-packed film that reminds you what first-rate storytelling and filmmaking is all about.
Loaded for fun, a trigger-happy full-frontal assualt on our senses that really seems to be winking at a whole macho-movie genre.
It will rattle your comfort zone and keep you unnerved throughout.
Boy meets girl. Boy shacks up with girl. Boy almost marries girl. Girl loses interest in boy. Boy loses girl.Boy and girl lose audience.
Over-the-top melodrama that offers lots of freewheeling gunplay and action in desperate search of a believable story.
Often gripping and fascinating, it's bound to create waves of controversy.
It's one to see, an engrossing, surprising and moving drama that will restore your faith in the power of movies to tell great human stories.
A fast, furious and riotously funny british farce in the tradition of Monty Python and Peter Sellers.
A great American comedy. A hilarious and richly human tale of two guys trying to hang on to their own twisted dreams of glory.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The ads for this third, count 'em, THIRD remake of the campy 1956 classic sci-fi film 'Invasion Of The Body Snatchers' warn 'Do Not Trust Anyone' (yeah, who tells you to see this movie!)
Every generation seems to have one iconic comedy that gets to a special place... and lives on forever as a true classic of its times. For this generation Superbad is going to be that film.
Well cast and smartly directed by Matthew Vaughn, this colorful confection is better than it has any right to be.
A masterpiece that HAS to be the front-runner for this year's animated Oscar. It's actually the rare 'toon that even deserves consideration for Best Picture.
Lights out.
It may have taken six years to get Jackie Chan and Chris Tucker back together but the chemistry is still there even if it looks like everyone probably signed on just to mint money.
It is as if the filmmakers created an 11th commandment of their own: Thou Shalt Not Laugh. And we don't.
8-year olds will eat it up but adults probably will want to exit the theatre with, as Underdog might say, 'the speed of lightning and the roar of thunder!'
It's hot stuff! Lopez and Anthony set off fireworks. In fact Lopez has never been better. As a musical showcase it scores big time.
If this film somehow manages to become a hit it will be a bigger feat than ANYTHING this dumb dude tries on screen!

It's the best action picture in decades, a two hour high-tech chase around the world that surpasses everything that's come before it including Oscar winning classics like 'The French Connection' and 'Bullitt'.
Zeta-Jones and Eckhart manage to turn this film into an okay chick flick that IS probably best left for the chicks.
It had to happen. The Simpsons have finally become bona fide movie stars and this hilarious, clever and irreverent film proves it was worth the wait.

If you go in expecting another 'Aliens' you're likely to feel burned. This modestly produced tale is about cerebral and thoughtful as the science fiction action genre gets.Boyle's ambitious film bites off more than it can chew.

Even with Sandler up to his old tricks, he and James aren't really to blame for the failure of this movie-by-committee that throws a bunch of tired jokes against the wall and settles for the two or three that actually stick.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It rocks the house! Guaranteed to be an unqualified 100% summer smash, it's a total blast. You have got to see Travolta's hilarious, risk-taking performance to believe it! He (or is it she) and the entire cast are terrific.
A vibrant, funny, moving, highly entertaining and richly rewarding movie experience. Don Cheadle soars into the highest rank of film actors with this role. Ejiofor and Henson are magnificent.

You won't be able to take your eyes off the screen as this terrific psychological game of cat and mouse unfolds. The incredibly sexy Sienna Miller burns up the screen with raw, sensual star power. She's hot
Spectacular. Harry Potter is a true movie phenomenon. This one seals the deal. If you weren't hooked before, you will be now.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: There should be no debate that this little gem deserves to be as big a hit as it was at Sundance.
An often riotously funny slapstick farce that ought to appeal to moviegoers of all ages.
You may just want to forget about any sort of cinematic monogamy and find another movie to see.
Nine is simply sensational and is indeed a worthy successor to his Best Picture winner, Chicago in every way.
This film fully belongs to Patel and Irons, who have two of the best roles in their careers.
Tom Hanks is understated and wonderfully effective in a very fine adaptation of Dave Egger's potent and surreal novel that seems just right for these ever changing times.
Susan Sarandon gets to shine in her best screen outing in some time.
Director John Carney scores again with a ragtag musical coming of age story that should please fans of his Once and Begin Again.
If you can accept the far-fetched premise at hand there is a fun performance from Kevin Costner that makes Criminal tick as well as it does.
Jon Favreau has turned a delightful 50 year old disney 'toon into a live action visual marvel of CGI that merges technology with heart and soul.
Jake Gyllenhaal tears up the screen with one of his best performances in a challenging film about a man trying to put his life on re-set after his wife dies in a tragic car accident.
Helen Mirren and cast are superb in a truly great thriller that becomes the first significant movie about drones and the morality of modern day warfare. A great humane achievement from Gavin Hood.
Writer/director Bob Nelson nearly equals his own Oscar nominated script for Nebraska with this touching, funny and true father/son story with terrific turns from Clive Owen and Jaeden Lieberher.
Subversively funny, raunchy comedy has very funny performance from Melissa Rauch and says a lot about fleeting fame and small town America.
Sally Field triumphs in her first full-bodied leading role in a film in years. 'Doris' skillfully walks the line between broad comedy and emotional drama, never missing a beat.

There are a lot of cinematic influences here from Hitchcock to War Of The Worlds but the original CLOVERFIELD surprisingly isn't really one of them in this pure anti-sequel that entertains while it surprises.
For all the silliness on hand, I have to admit I had a much better time than expected at this one, Baron Cohen's best since Borat.

If this is what you have to go through being President of the U.S. then why does Donald Trump even WANT this job? London Has Fallen and so has this franchise with a pointless sequel that just blows things up.
A triumph. A smart and absurdly funny movie that takes a different view of the war in Afghanistan. Tina Fey is terrific in a different kind of role, and Martin Freeman steals it.
This comic book superhero comedy is just plain super fun , a raunchy movie that parodies the whole genre while still honoring it. Ryan Reynolds has found a vehicle worth his talents.
Ben Stiller's misguided sequel is a true fashion disaster. I liked the first but something has been lost in translation 15 years later.
An entertaining and expertly crafted Coast Guard tale deftly navigated by Chris Pine and Casey Affleck in the most stoic performances of their careers.
Best. Panda. Ever. A threequel that beats the standard with fight, fun and loads of heart.
The worst film of Robert De Niro's entire career (or maybe anybody's). Get Zac Efron a new agent - fast.
This is the rare film that can be enormously entertaining but also make a real difference.
The film is not just as a wrenching study of two people afflicted with a mental illness but also as a heartbreaking, but ultimately impossible, love story.
It's sensational fun.

J.J. Abrams and team brilliantly merge the old and the new into a Star Wars that soars on every level. Han Solo is back but it is Daisy Ridley's Rey that is the heart of The Force Awakens. She's a keeper.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Leonardo DiCaprio is at his best battling against the elements in this brutal and beautiful snowy western. The grizzly bear attack is worth the price of admission alone.
Jennifer Lawrence proves a mop can be just as empowering as a bow and arrow in David O. Russell's ode to smart and determined women everywhere who have a dream.
Trumbo reminds us of a very dark time in America as well as Hollywood. Important but also hugely entertaining. Bryan Cranston nails it.

But one of the unquestioned highlights is when the boys come upon that giant piano Tom Hanks played in Big. This leads to a great musical sequence among the three and is representative of the goofy anything-goes nature of the whole movie.
Love The Coopers is the perfect gift for the entire family, and that's certainly not a bad thing these days.
However you can find it, it is worth checking out, another high water mark for both Bateman and Kidman.
Money Monster is riveting entertainment, a heart-pounding, edge-of-your-seat exercise that doesn't let up for a minute.
The latest edition in the X-Men saga may be biting off more than it can chew but thanks to Oscar Isaac's Apocalypse it is still catnip for fans of the franchise.
Sacha Baron Cohen's clever and time-less performance elevates this sequel which outdoes the original in laughs, charm and heart. Worth a return trip down the rabbit hole.
Tom Cruise rules in this immensely entertaining action thriller that smartly doesn't try to be anything other than what it is, and that's a very good thing for movie fans.
In the year of Trump "Denial" ,which is about the libel trial involving a demogogue, just may be the most important and urgent film of 2016.
Tim Burton has found the best material in years to match his quirky and endearing cinematic style.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Not nearly as magnificent as the originals it is based on, this Denzel Washington western vehicle still has its moments even if there is too much gunplay and not enough character development.
Superb drama of aimless youth on the back roads of America captures the restlessness of a new generation in a movie as important now as Rebel Without A Cause was in its time.
Well meaning but paint-by-numbers disaster movie shortchanges the really interesting story behind the Deepwater Horizon oil spill disaster and its consequences.
Emily Blunt's startlingly good lead performance makes this 'train' trip worthwhile for fans of the book and others who like mystery psychological thrillers.

Disappointing film does not live up to its Sundance reputation and plods along until effective final scenes, but by then it is too little and too late in a movie that looks like it would be better on television on History.
Ben Affleck continues his action star cred in this fun, but violent look at an accountant for the mob who also knows how to kill when he has to.
Ava DuVernay's searing documentary blows a hole in the constitution and provides serious food for thought in upending what we think we know about our system of justice.
A brilliant performance by Rebecca Hall powers this fascinating true and tragic story of a local news reporter teetering on the edge.
Whatever side of the fence -- or wall -- you are on politically, there's no arguing that the younger Cuaron has produced a hell of a nail-biter.
Stone is back in his wheelhouse attacking topical and urgent material with his usual filmmaking style and substance.
Eastwood, at 86, continues to be a marvel, and this stands as one of the four-time Oscar winner's best films.
This movie packs an emotional wallop.
John Krasinski delivers a movie that expertly blends laughs , tears and family dysfunction in way we can easily recognize. Margo Martindale and Richard Jenkins shine.
Well meaning but paint-by-numbers biopic of boxer Roberto Duran simply takes too many swings and wanders all over the place in search of a POV.
Don't Go.
A sweet and enlightening peak into the early lives of the Obamas as director Richard Tanne takes us on their first date way back in 1989. Both stars are flawless.
This is a smart, intelligent and darkly funny movie in every respect and a big leap forward for Phillips.
I'm with Hur - just NOT this version.
It is an epic inspired by the tradition of Kurosawa and Lean, mixed with more than a bit of the fantasy of The Wizard of Oz.
A great American film that is not only an exciting cat and mouse bank robber thriller but also a movie with much relevance for these times.
Meryl Streeps turns bad singing into high art as Florence Foster Jenkins in a hilarious and sophisticated movie for grown ups this summer.
The animation is gorgeous, with contemporary home life scenes in CGI and the world of The Little Prince in stunning stop-motion design.
A great premise pitting bad vs badder heads toward the darkness rather than the light but succeeds with a terrific cast including ace performances from Margot Robbie and Viola Davis.

The beauty of this film from writer-directors Jon Lucas and Scott Moore is that it is broad and silly at times but never over the top and always grounded in characters we genuinely understand and care about.
One of Philip Roth's lesser known novels becomes the best movie adaptation to date with a fine Logan Lerman and two Oscar worthy supporting turns from Tracy Letts and Linda Emond.

Bryan Cranston is once again caught up in the drug world but this time he is 'Breaking' Good in this true story about a Federal Agent going deep undercover - a movie that doesn't let up the tension for a minute.
A slick, entertaining but not quite ready-for-slime-time female reboot of the 1980's comedy classic.
A gorgeous romantic fever dream of a movie musical. La La Land is one for this age - and the ages. Stunning in every way.

With the frenetic style of so much of what passes as kids fare these days, the simplicity of seeing The Peanuts Movie and this wonderful bunch of characters again on the big screen is more than enough.

A very smart, funny, intelligent, pertinent and important look at the machinations behind a Presidential campaign. This one just happens to be in Bolivia with Sandra Bullock and Billy Bob Thornton playing the dirty tricks.
Yes, there may be a bit of a history lesson here but a fine cast led by Carey Mulligan brings this inspiring story of women fighting for their rights vividly alive.
Truly a mind blowing adventure, Inside Out is wildly inventive and totally original. This one is for everyone - kids AND adults.

Not your typical movie biopic, Love & Mercy is a harrowing musical ride into the mind of Brian Wilson of The Beach Boys. Splitting the role between John Cusack and Paul Dano is a risky move that mostly pays off.
This Sundance winner is something special indeed, a movie featuring teens that can't be classified as a TEEN MOVIE. It's a masterful funny/sad and illuminating human story.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Dino-mite special effects take this sequel to new heights. Returning to the spirit of the original and ignoring the previous two editions, Jurassic World is just pure people-chomping fun.

If you were a fan of the TV show will you be disappointed? Probably not. It's nice to have Ari, Vince and the gang back even if at nearly two hours this ENTOURAGE feels a bit like forced binge watching.

For my money SPY is the funniest film so far this year. I can't recall laughing out loud this much in a long time. Paul Feig has the magic touch when it comes these kinds of movies - and that is no small feat.
The fault isn't in the earthquake in SAN ANDREAS, it's in the script. Dwayne Johnson's heroics may be able to save everything else in this by-the-numbers disaster (movie), but not that.
Crowe clearly is a romantic at heart and has created an intriguing film dealing with a man whose personal life is caught somewhere in the middle between his past and future.
Helen Hunt proves as adept behind the camera as she is in front of it in this funny and moving story that movies rarely do - the relationship between a mother and son. It's a winner.
Understated and low key this is a surprising zombie movie that features fine performances from Abigail Breslin and maybe the best that Arnold Schwarzenegger has ever given.
I want my 87 minutes back. Directed, produced and starring smart women in a complete and total comic misfire that is almost painful to watch.

I was never a fan of the 1967 version with Julie Christie, but director Thomas Vinterberg gets it all right this time with this hugely romantic adaptation of Thomas Hardy's novel that features a never-better Carey Mulligan in the lead role.

It suffers from a bit of Transformersitis in laying on the action and effects too thick this time. The thrill may be gone in seeing these comic book icons together but the banter between them still works and it does have its moments of sheer fun.

Russell Crowe's feature directorial debut is a triumph for him, an epic adventure and humane story that reminds me of the kind of movies I used to love before Hollywood found gold in them thar comic books.
Fresh and original movie where geeks meet street with very funny consequences. A terrific cast and smart script make this Sundance sensation a summer winner.

Like a cross between a Twilight Zone episode and Somewhere In Time, The Age Of Adaline is a splendid new romantic drama with a beating heart all its own and terrific performances from Blake Lively and Harrison Ford.

Finally Hollywood has figured out how to get teens off the internet and into theatres. Make a movie that takes place ENTIRELY in front of a computer screen. But after 82 minutes you may feel a migraine coming on .
It provides a nice showcase for the villainous talents of Douglas.
Helen Mirren and Ryan Reynolds make a great pair in this fascinating and true tale that makes for a highly entertaining and compelling tale.
Spectacular stunts, a touching send-off for Paul Walker and pedal-to-the-metal action make this one furiously good - best in the series so far.

For some reason this movie offended a lot of critic-types at SXSW but the only thing that would really be offensive here is if it wasn't funny. And thanks to a nice teaming of Will Ferrell and Kevin Hart this is surprisingly funny stuff.

Al Pacino shows a new side of himself - rock star - in Danny Collins and that's something to sing about. He pulls it off and is backed by a terrific cast in this smart and entertainment movie for grownups.

The action sequences have been ramped up and Insurgent smartly diverges from the book but it's still such a confusing and uninvolving storyline this YA adaptation made me HUNGER for something more. Thank God for Shailene Woodley though.

Sean Penn, an actor you can't take your eyes off when he's on screen , is not the problem with The Gunman. Neither is its terrific , if underused , cast. This attempt to turn Penn into a late-blooming action star is just too convoluted.

In the vein of those tough guy Warner Bros movies of the 40's , Liam Neeson and Ed Harris show what pro acting is all about in this edge-of-your-seat action thriller that may be far-fetched , but highly entertaining anyway.

Enchanting and beautifully filmed. Disney's live action translation of their 1950 animated classic is the perfect family movie. A great cast includes the stunning Lily James and a complex evil Stepmother from the great Cate Blanchett.
The first great film of 2015. Kevin Costner knows his way around this kind of story and is wonderful. Inspiring.

A total delight from Disney Animation, Big Hero 6 will have you rooting for this ragtag team originally introduced in a little -known Marvel comic. But its the overgrown marshmallow named Baymax that will steal your heart.

Christopher Nolan outdoes himself with this thrilling , and emotionally moving. sci-fi drama that has echoes of 2001 but carves out its own gripping story by smartly focusing on the human element so often missing in this genre.
The Theory Of Everything surpasses the standard biopic to become an unexpected and moving love story between Stephen and Jane Hawking. The acting is superb in this winning film.

If the Russian accents from this non-Russian cast weren't grating enough, the convoluted and seedy story of Child 44 would be reason enough to pass on this one despite the usually reliable presence of Tom Hardy and Noomi Rapace.
A moviing coming of age story of self discovery that should resonate with audiences and at Oscar time.
Entertaining and wonderfully satisfying.
A bare bones plotline won't matter to fans seeking a good time at this stripped-down 'hey, let's put on a show' road movie.
Bradley Cooper cooks up an acting feast and digs deep into the role an arrogant but talented chef who needs to realize there are more important things in life than just the right amount of sauce.
Ridley Scott shows a lighter touch this time in outer space as Matt Damon proves there is life on Mars and in this gem of a sci-fi adventure.
Steven Spielberg reteaming with Tom Hanks and with help from the Coen Brothers and a great team has made a masterful film that ranks high on the list of anything he has ever done.
Aaron Sorkin's dazzling and dizzying screenplay is the star of this show which is blessed by crackerjack direction from Danny Boyle and a great Michael Fassbender in the title role.

Robert Zemeckis renews your faith in the wonder of movies with this breathtaking film version of Philippe Petit's walk across the twin towers of the World Trade Center in 1974. A thrilling movie experience for everyone.

It may not be quite in the league of The Departed or Goodfellas but sharp direction and a chilling performance by Johnny Depp as Whitey Bulger makes this a worthwhile entry in the gangster film genre.
A sensational thriller that grabs you by the throat. Director Denis Villeneuve stages scenes with the eye of a master and he's aided by the great cinematographer Roger Deakins and a first-rate cast.
Nancy Meyers delivers another funny, warm, smart and sophisticated comedy for adults that features Robert De Niro in perhaps his most likeable performance ever.
I was on the edge of my seat watching this movie.
Shot in Nepal and the Italian Alps, cinematographer Salvatore Totino has a lot to work with and he makes the most of it. The technical aspects of this grueling film are superb throughout.
It is fun to see both stars doing a light comedy like this in a movie that, in another era, might have been perfectly suited for a Bob Hope and Bing Crosby-style road picture.
No Escape is insanely intense. Is it credible? Who cares. This movie is full of heart-pounding action that takes your breath away. From start to finish it is just plain fun.
Way overrated when it played Sundance, if this disappointing and dreary film presents one of the most unappealing ensembles of characters I have seen in a long time.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: An epic fail in Hollywood's comic book movie universe this not-so-fantastic flop is so bad it could send the whole genre on a downward spiral. What a mess.

The return of Schwarzenegger to his signature role is the main attraction of this fifth installment in the Terminator franchise. He's not the problem as much as a terribly convoluted time travelling storyline that does not honor the best of this series.
An exceptional young cast and strong direction make this powerful and gritty N.W.A. biopic a cut above most showbiz sagas.

Seek this riveting crime drama out wherever you can find it. Kevin Bacon is creepily great as a corrupt sheriff out to get his police car back from two joy-riding young boys. Director Jon Watts scores with a masterful gem.
Jesse Eisenberg at his most neurotic saves this frenetic action comedy and makes it worth watching despite an overabundance of violence laced in with its silly plot.
It's NOT a hit,man. By the numbers and mindnumbingly dull action movie is a robotic as its leading man.
Is there anything Meryl Streep can't do? She is astonishing again and at her absolute best is this rockin' fun movie that proves Streep can sing with the best of them.
Hooves down the funniest animated movie of the year. Aardman has done it again - and brilliantly . Shear heaven for 'toon fans. Somewhere Jacques Tati and Charlie Chaplin are smiling just like me.
This franchise reboot ratchets up the raunch and the fun making VACATION a breath of fresh air and raucous laughs. Truly hilarious stuff with lots of comic smarts and a great cast.
Not just the best movie of the summer, but also the best SUMMER movie of the summer. A whipsmart action film that dazzles from start to finish. Cruise in control of the best 'MI' yet.

There is no fault in the new stars of the latest John Green book-to-movie adaptation and this teen dramedy is a slight cut above the norm in the genre even if a lot of it doesn't add up. Still, it's got heart and a nice theme about living life to the max.
The premise is clever , the effects are good and it was nice seeing Pac Man again but Pixels is stretched way too thin for its own good. Are kids really going to care about this 80's throwback?
Southpaw might not rewrite the rules of this genre, but it certainly is a sterling addition to a great legacy of movies set in the ring.
It may owe a lot to BOB & CAROL & TED & ALICE, but this new age suburban swingers comedy is very funny and enlightening.
Pedal-to-the-medal kick ass action drives this summer winner to the max. If there is any justice Charlize Theron will get an Oscar nomination. And so will the movie.

Stuffed with jast as many, if not more, laughs than the original. Ted 2 is blissfully politically incorrect so if you are easily offended better lighten up if you plan on seeing this Seth MacFarlane jokebook.

A harrowing and heartbreaking , ultimately very sad documentary look at the life and death of Amy Winehouse, a singer in the mold of the all time greats who let the dark side of fame get the better of her.

Guy RItchie's in-your-face directorial style serves this blast from the past well but it is the cool and funny chemistry between Henry Cavill and Armie Hammer that makes this a nice tribute to the 60's classic spy series.
Sorry fellow critics but you are WAY off on this one. American Pastoral gets it right and becomes one of the best Phillip Roth adaptations ever.
No one should plan on getting the tux out for the Oscars for this one, but what is wrong with some good old fashioned fun and a gorgeous swing through beautiful European locations?
Miles Teller is a knockout in this surprising boxing film that takes a stunning turn to be the most remarkable comeback story I can recall.
Jessica Chastain in her best performance to date powers Aaron Sorkin's sensational directorial debut.
Rian Johnson has delivered arguably the best Star Wars ever, or at least certainly the most fun.

This is a movie combining gorgeous clothes and food for thought that makes it a must feel and smell, a sumptuous cinematic recipe ripe for the decade in which it's set but one that is weirdly engaging in this one as well.
Gorgeous, lyrical story of first love and desire during an Italian summer hits you right in the heart.
Greta Gerwig makes a winning directorial debut with a funny and very human comedy that happens to have Oscar-caliber performances from Saoirse Ronan and Laurie Metcalf.
A truly charming origin story of how Charles Dickens came to write A Christmas Carol. A better feel good movie for the holidays is not possible. Dan Stevens and Christopher Plummer shine.
Pixar proves with its 19th feature film that not only has it not lost its touch, it's getting better.
A sweet and winning feel good family movie that also happens to have a strong message against bullying and lack of kindness toward our fellow human beings. A must for family viewing.

Dark, brooding, forgettable mashup of DC comic book superheroes not only displays zero chemistry between any of them in this corporate shotgun wedding of prized characters, it also is just plain forgettable.
The scenery and spectacular production values of director/star Kenneth Branagh's remake of the Agatha Christie classic outshine the all star cast. It helps if you don't know whodunnit.
Quickly produced sequel is the right tonic for the season providing a double mother lode of laughs - and what is wrong with that?

[Woody] Harrelson, from a different part of Texas than Johnson, just nails this role, even if the makeup job is a bit jarring at first. You get used to it and completely succumb to Harrelson's talents in transforming into the 36th president
Despite a dream teaming of director George Clooney, the Coen Bros, Matt Damon and Julianne Moore this misguided mishmash of noirish black comedy and social commentary fizzles.
Miles Teller leads a superb cast in this gripping and powerful true story of Iraq veterans heading home and fighting the war within themselves.
I don't recall asking for another round of Jumanji and the laughs don't come easily in this version despite a game cast.
It's hammer time again and Thor Ragnarok rocks with laughter put the emphasis on the "comic" in comic book moviemaking. The cast is up to the challenge.
In Curtis' hands, Goodbye Christopher Robin avoids cheap sentimentality and surprisingly explores the underbelly of what instant celebrity can do to you, especially if you are a kid.
Though all the requisite action scenes are here he navigates the story in an intelligent direction that reminds of some of the more accomplished films in this genre.
Andrew Garfield and Claire Foy give two of the best performances of the year in director Andy Serkis' moving true story of polio victim Robin Cavendish.
A good old fashioned Hollywood romantic adventure, that had the good grace to cast Kate Winslet and Idris Elba, makes for an entertaining adult-appeal movie in the best sense of the word.

Visually stunning and ambitious sequel to the 1982 film has a cool performance from Ryan Gosling but is blissfully helped by its original star Harrison Ford, even if the two hour and 44 minute running time could definitely use some editing.
Tom Cruise delivers his most audacious - and best - performance in years in this amazing and notorious true story that just might blow your mind.
Reese Witherspoon proves there is still life in the romcom genre after all in a movie where Hallie Meyers Shyer proves a talent for comedy runs in the family.
There is nothing like this dame when she plays a queen. Judi Dench shines again in a surprising royally entertaining tale from the great Stephen Frears.
Jake Gyllenhaal triumphs in one of the best performances of the year, and his career, as a survivor of the Boston Marathon Bombing in 2013. An inspiring film that doesn't beg for sympathy.
Not for everyone so be warned but Darren Aronofsky has created an intoxicating and polarizing movie like no other with a superb Jennifer Lawrence as our guide into sheer madness.
The sequel to the surprise hit is bigger and more colorful but just as wacko as the first in many ways. Kingsman is still a clever twist on the spy movie formula and fans won't be disappointed.

Emma Stone and Steve Carell are matchless and at the top of their game in a film that goes places that just might surprise you. A superb trip back to the notorious tennis duel between Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs.
An action thriller that delivers on its promise with Michael Keaton in a down and dirty turn and Dylan O'Brien showing great promise as a new star in the genre.
Brad's Status is quiet and unassuming, a dramedy worth spending time with.
An inspiring and remarkable film tribute to these brave (indeed) men in a job that is often taken for granted, albeit one that puts you through the wringer at the same time it makes you feel proud.
It may have taken almost 40 years to get this screen reunion, but it is well worth the wait.
Tonya Harding's familiar scandal makes for an unexpectedly fine black comedy with sensational performances from every member of its cast.
James Franco has made a wickedly funny and very good movie from the ruins of one of the worst ever made.
It's got Oprah,diversity in casting, good message but it is STRICTLY for kids.
This winning comedy about a gay high schooler looking for love hits you right in the heart.

After some nine X-Men movies of various stripes and styles including a couple of previous stand-alone Wolverine films, I had little hope that the best was yet to come. But indeed it has come in the form of Logan...
Sex, seduction, violence, torture, deception, spies, russians, nudity, twists, turns - what more can you ask for especially with Jennifer Lawrence in charge?
This is a small, adult film that will have smart specialty audiences thinking. What's wrong with that? It also happens to be highly entertaining.
While providing food for its ravenous creatures, it also provides food for thought.

The lack of the usual Hollywood showboating in favor of reality is admirable, if dull in some spots, but the idea is audacious and makes it all worth checking out - a curio from a world-class director who at 87 still knows how to change things up.
A rumination on grief, loss, memories , and the stuff we hang on to, Nostalgia is a movie to be remembered for exceptional performances from a first rate ensemble cast.
Like its predecessors, Fifty Shades Freed almost seems structured like a musical except it stops every few minutes for a steamy sexual encounter rather than a song.
The live-action stars also shine, with an appealing Gleeson overcoming the unlikable aspects of Thomas, while Byrne plays as a lovely woman with a place in her heart for both a rabbit and a man.
This is a superhero movie for the ages, and especially for this age.

Daniela Vega is striking in this transgender drama that has become an Oscar favorite for Foreign Language Film. It hits on many levels and remains compelling throughout for its themes and emotional resonance.
Third time around for the Maze Runner gang doubles the action quotient and should please fans despite an overlong running time and predictable plot points for this type of YA vehicle.

What could be overbearing (sorry) kid stuff instead is wonderfully droll and charming throughout, a children's film that really does not talk down to its intended audience and should please every member of the family.
As timely and urgent as movies can get, The Post is a high water mark in the careers of Steven Spielberg, Meryl Streep and Tom Hanks.
Roger Michell wrote and directs this adaptation with the flair it needs to connect to a new generation who may never have even heard of it.
Let's hope Gore doesn't have to do another sequel. In a summer that features several superheroes on the screen, you can count the former Vice President as a member of that company.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [Theron] is firing on all cylinders here, proving blondes not only have more fun, they have more guns - and know how to use them.
As a time killer, you could do worse thanks to Reynolds and Jackson and even Hayek, who made me laugh and has a natural affinity for comedy.
There have been many docus on this subject, but none so determined to pull back the curtains of this different kind of alleged corporate industrial pollution.
What makes it work so splendidly are some terrific characters you don't mind spending a couple of hours with.

Without giving too much away, this trio's relationship goes on for decades, but it is the act of watching it evolve and usurp puritanical attitudes to triumph in so many ways that makes this fascinating biopic work as well as it does.
Fortunately Daddy's Home 2 not only has Ferrell and Wahlberg doing their thing that worked well the first time, they have real pros in Lithgow and Gibson to come to the rescue.

McDonagh has a way with a line that is without compare, and he has put together a cast who knows how to sock it home. Harrelson is excellent with a character who also takes unexpected turns that we aren't prepared for.
Hugh Jackman fronts a lively family musical as PT Barnum, a role he was born to play. Terrific Pasek and Paul songs light up the screen with a holiday treat.
Scott Cooper does well by the genre and delivers a dark but powerful western that pulls no punches and features a great Christian Bale performance.
Netflix's misguided mashup is like Lethal Weapon meets Lord Of The Rings but does star Will Smith no favors.
Payne has cast this film perfectly with Damon an ideal fit as Paul, and Wiig nicely underplaying her comic predicament.
It's a Christmas miracle that Scott met this date, but one for which lovers of smart and dynamic filmmaking should be grateful.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Guillermo Del Toro's magical masterpiece is simply a fever dream of a romantic movie - and then some.
Cohen just can't seem to make the tonal shifts work, and the film falls prey to some cringe-inducing scenes in its second half.
Murray gives a blessedly good performance.
A star is born in this highly entertaining hip hop delight with three different generations of women played by Danielle Macdonald, Bridget Everett and Cathy Moriarty take the cake.
Smart, clever and hilarious it is fun from start to finish line.
A funny and frenetic animated comedy which is blessed to have Alec Baldwin calling the shots as this little bundle of power who looks he should be running Exxon Mobil, not sucking his thumb.
Nazis, Animals , and a superb performance from Jessica Chastain make this a memorable and different WWII-set film.
Life succeeds nicely on its own terms.
Watching Paxton play pure evil is to just be reminded of his exceptional range, never stereotyping this corrupt cop and keeping us off balance.
In the end this is all about Harriet, and with MacLaine in charge things are right with the world.
It may indeed be a "tale as old as time," but in this case as least, it is nice that time has come again.
A remarkable cinematic triumph that ought to have audiences purring for more.
An irresistible boy and his dog tale that will have you laughing through tears. For anyone who ever loved a dog.
Well cast and acted, but this guy is no laughing matter and who really wants to spend time with him even IF he's played by Robert De Niro?
Teen girls especially ought to love this fish out of Mars tale that features an engaging turn from Asa Butterfield and some nice elements that make for an implausible but entertaining ride.

[It's] a handsome looking indie that may be too truthful to have wide appeal, but should be a must for anyone looking for a smart and revealing showbiz story that at its heart is wholly -- and unapologetically -- human.
Yet another head scratching video game adapation , but this one wastes an A-list cast on pure hokum, although it is not as bad as Warcraft.
Director/Star Ben Affleck serves up a nice ode to the gangster pictures of the 30's and 40's with top notch cast and great production value.

Genuinely hilarious comedy pitting Bryan Cranston vs James Franco in a battle of wits between dad and daughter's boyfriend. Some classic comic set pieces make you forgive the film's occasional trips over the top.
Scarlett Johansson is the reason to see Ghost In The Shell. She electrifies as this cyber enhanced force against crime who tries desperately to what's left of the human inside.

Peter Berg and Mark Wahlberg reteam for a stirring and fascinating movie that focuses on the aftermath of the Boston Marathon Bombing and the heroic efforts of a few who helped define the term 'Boston Strong'.

Jennifer Lawrence and Chris Pratt turn on the movie star wattage in an entertaining movie that is part Titanic, part Gravity, part The Martian and part Twilight Zone but marches to the beat of its own heart.
Coming from someone who is not really a Star Wars freak, I have to say I was impressed. This could be the best one yet.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An inspiring story that had to be told - and finally has been. Superb acting all around and a remarkable tale make this a big winner.
There's no way around it. Natalie Portman is astonishing in a surprising and engrossing look at a Jackie Kennedy we only thought we knew.
This tuneful 'toon works on every level, a charming, funny, heartfelt and toe tapping holiday treat for everyone at any age.
Lion is an emotional corker of a true story that charts a remarkable journey that redefines the meaning of family and home.
Robert Zemeckis makes a great old fashioned romantic spy movie that delivers a great pairing between Brad Pitt and Marion Cotillard.
An explosive and riveting political thriller that blows the roof off Washington D.C. Jessica Chastain is sensational.

The Edge of Seventeen is its own animal, powered by a perceptive and wryly funny take on things by Craig - who also makes her directing debut - and highlighted by the performance of a never-better Steinfeld.
Tom Ford's stylish, complex suspense thriller is actually worthy of Hitchcock in many ways. A superb ensemble cast also doesn't hurt.
A quietly effective love story that doesn't succumb to Hollywood convention and allows Joel Edgerton and Ruth Negga to deliver two of the year's best performances.
Amy Adams is terrific in this cerebral but enthralling sci fi drama that turns out to be much much more than just another Alien movie.
Almost Christmas delivers the gift-wrapped goods thanks to some downright funny scenes and the blissfully hilarious presence of Mo'nique.
Ang Lee's latest is the year's most disappointing film and it isn't just the annoyingly unnecessary 120 frame 4K 3D technology, but just a plain lousy script.

It may be dialogue driven but Denzel Washington's vision of a Fences film version is fully realized in this superbly acted movie of the late, great August Wilson's Pulitizer Prize and Tony winning play.
A documentary with all the "Write Stuff" for lovers and purists who fear the typewriter has gone the way of the dinosaurs. This remarkably entertaining movie proves there is still hope.
A wonderful and touching family film in which Chris Evans shows what a super hero really is. He's terrific and so is the whole cast including a genuine new find by the name of McKenna Grace.
Fate Of The Furious delivers all the knockout stunts the fans expect even if the series is drifting into over-the-top James Bond style plots.
A smart and sexy romantic drama with intriguing twists and a terrific turn from Kate Beckinsale who shines among a great ensemble cast.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A moving and beautifully acted adaptation of Jeanette Walls' memoir features a career-best performance by Woody Harrelson who is sensational here.

Although this film has trappings of a lot of prison films and shows you might have seen, writer-director Ric Roman Waugh has more on his mind and seems to be pointing out that the system can suck you in and lead you down the wrong path.
Annabelle: Creation succeeds on its own terms and is definitely a horror fan pleaser.
Idris Elba as Gunslinger is out to save the world along with this movie adaptation of the Stephen King book series. He is the one strong reason fans should check this out.
It's one of those movies that we just don't see made successfully as much anymore because the tone between humor, raunch and heart is more difficult to balance than you think.

Kathryn Bigelow and writer Mark Boal are to be commended for tackling important and pertinent stories, but Detroit is a mixed bag. In your face filmmaking packs a wallop but ultimately sheds no new light on the race war in America 50 years later.

Dunkirk manages to be a stirring , yet intimate epic all at the same time. At its core though it is a gripping thriller that is unlike anything I have ever seen in this genre, a bravura triumph for Christopher Nolan.
Dazzling visuals from the eye of director Luc Besson overcome the wooden acting of the leads in this colorful sci fi spectacular.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A surreal, hypnotic and ethereal meditation on life, love, loss, and the questions we keep asking . Casey Affleck is covered in a white sheet and Rooney Mara eats a whole pie in one shot. Not to be missed.

A smart and entertaining reboot of the Spider-Man franchise is young at heart and in execution. This could be the first true coming of age comic book movie that adults will like just as much as their kids.
Even if a whole feature film of Minions was a bit too much of a good thing, having them back in a choice supporting role is just the right tonic.
Fast and Curious action flick driven by cool playlist, hot wheels , and style for miles. Love the soundtrack, baby.
Sofia Coppola proves taking this remake from the male side to the female point of view is just the ticket. A rare Civil War story about those women not in the heat of battle.

Clearly this is what you might call an AARP movie, but what is wrong with that? The chance to see Caine, Freeman and Arkin -- not to mention Ann-Margret -- again on the big screen is irresistible stuff.
All hail Caesar as War For The Planet Of The Apes and director Matt Reeves gets it absolutely right and produces the best Apes movie on the planet.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Complete misfire doesn't know what it wants to be: inspiring family drama or revenge thriller and comes up short on both counts despite an excellent cast wasted here.
The warmth and heart are back full force in this third-times-the-charm edition of Disney/Pixar's charmer of an animated franchise.
The big laughs out run the big misses in this raunchy female infused comedy that seems like the bastard child of 'Bridesmaids' and 'The Hangover'. Kate McKinnon steals it.
Mara has her best screen outing yet.
Sam Elliott has the role of his career. Period.
It is a brilliantly accomplished directing debut and never goes for cheap laughs or obvious plot contrivances.
Wonder Woman is the most refreshing comic book movie in years, if not ever. Smart, witty , fun and Gal Gadot shines along with Chris Pine.
Garner, as always, is very fine as well as a wife suddenly thrust into a bizarre situation, but this is almost totally Cranston's show.
A bitingly funny, sophisticated look at a marriage gone sour with sensational performances from Debra Winger and Tracy Letts.
Powerhouse performances and provocative table talk make this 'Dinner' worth making a reservation for.
How to make a lousy comedy
movie_title: How to Be a Latin Lover (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Majestic, beautiful and thrilling entry into the very admirable Disneynature series of films that show the splendor of this world rather than its grisly nature.
Predictable and very familiar suspense thriller we have seen in many other movies from the past but Katherine Heigl is very good playing very bad and nearly redeems this.
A powerfully made and sweeping romantic drama that brings one history's most shameful and darkest moments to the screen.
A cross cultural romance with surprising twists and turns makes for great comedy AND great drama . Kumail Nanjiani's true life tale is one not to miss.
Fury not only contains Brad Pitt's finest screen performance , it is also the most powerful and best war film I have seen in the last 30 years.
Ultimately this is, as always, all about the Transformers, and fans won't be disappointed.
Get on out to 'Get on Up', a superb and edgy biopic of the Godfather Of Soul, James Brown. Chadwick Boseman is possessed by the spirit and demons of the man and may be Oscar bound.
Fans of the original won't be disappointed.
No one really asked for it and some may resist it, but Joel and Ethan Coen's splendid new adaptation of Charles Portis' novel True Grit rides with the great ones.
With Oscar worthy performances from Nicole Kidman, Aaron Eckhart and Dianne Wiest, this is tough and demanding subject matter, but something that ultimately provides hope.
Washington and co-star Chris Pine are great together, and up to the task for the unbelievably intense action, pulse-pounding excitement and pure adrenaline high this movie delivers.
A Mega-funny movie loaded with laughs, action and heart.
Thanks to smart casting and sharp direction this story of a mismatched pair thrown together to parent an orphaned baby is really quite funny and heartfelt.

It may not break any new ground in the well-worn, horse racing movie genre, but this thrilling and inspiring entertainment about the legendary, 1973 Triple Crown winning horse should have audiences standing up and cheering.
A stirring,unforgettable motion picture experience. Superbly acted and a courageous story of one woman who made a difference. It deserves to be seen.
As socially significant to this generation as films like Network, All The President's Men and The Graduate were in their own time.
With first rate performances from an A-list cast, the handsome period piece The King's Speech is one of the most accessibly entertaining films of its kind in years.
[A] haunting, touching and unforgettable thriller.
A riveting and explosive crime thriller and one of the year's best pictures.
This all-stops-out Grand Guignol melodrama exhibits more than enough blood, sweat and tears (emphasis on the blood) to score nicely beyond the ballet crowd.
What could have been static and deadly dull comes blazingly to life in this powerful and compelling story of one man's will to survive.
Rogen isn't the obvious choice for a comic book icon but he forces his personality onto this material with an ingratiating ease.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Thoroughly entertaining.
Pays off on the laughs with a strong message about using sudden riches responsibly and the importance of giving back to the community.
A female adventure movie aimed almost exclusively at 30 or 40-something women who feel there must be more to life than the way they are currently living it.
A beautifully crafted and special movie, one likely to stay with you long after most of the so-called summer blockbusters have faded into memory.
With outstanding performances from a brilliant ensemble cast, Middle Men turns out to be wickedly entertaining with some of the best acting you will see all year.
Still as light on story as it is on its feet, but audiences looking to get a cinematic workout from the high-stepping action served up here could do a lot worse.
It's filled with literally explosive excitement.
A wonderful comedy with big laughs, a big heart and great music. This is one summer concert you don't want to miss.
A total blast. A wild comic journey into the head of a true original.
In the mood for a slower-than-molasses viking movie inspired by spaghetti westerns and samurai swordplay epics. Have we got the flick for YOU!
The tale of 'Farewell' with its momentous world-changing events is worth savoring - and remembering - in these troubled times.
This lame musical advertises itself as 'the most rockin' movie of the summer'. Replace 'rockin'' with 'rotten' and they would just about have it right.
It's exciting and full of smarts and style. Plus it's got Jolie. This thing rocks.
It would be criminal if , come Oscar time, Annette Bening and Julianne Moore are not competing for a Best Actress award.
[A] stirring and remarkable true story.
Although Turtletaub could have toned down a couple of the many battle sequences this should be spellbinding summer fun for its primary family and kid target audience.
A refreshingly pure, honest and original love story.
Kids will fall in love with it as a movie treat full of heart, laughs and fantastic songs, and it could have crossover appeal as a Valentine date night treat thanks to all its pointy-hatted romance.
Mr. Popper's Penguins has hatched a refreshing, hilarious and heartwarming movie for everyone.
Let there be light? Eh, not so much.
A highly entertaining and richly human movie experience with a gem of a performance from Jenna Fischer.
If a Hitchcockian psychological thriller peppered with elements from several different films is what you are looking for, then look no further than the compelling Italian drama The Double Hour.
The performances in Skateland will serve as early evidence of the actors' supreme talent.
The perfect summer movie and perhaps the best Pirates of them all.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Woody Allen's time-travelling comedy Midnight In Paris is a valentine to Paris and an absolute delight.
Something Borrowed is a snappy rom com about intersecting desires among a group of twenty-something friends.
Unlike most films of its ilk, Prom is genuinely human and relatable, veering with ease between comedy and drama.
Summer roars to a start with Fast Five which features some of the most spectacular action sequences seen on the screen in years.
Another Disneynature triumph , especially if you are a fan of these cool cats.
A thriller that's riveting from start to finish.
Another winner from Blue Sky Studios, creators of the Ice Age series, Rio is the biggest and brightest animated triumph since Toy Story 3.
A touch of class and sweet sophistication with a brilliantly funny cast. Definitely an indie sleeper worth checking out.
The surprising thing about the new behind-the-scenes documentary Justin Bieber: Never Say Never is that it should have appeal well beyond the star's young, adoring female fan base.
Adult audiences looking for a smart, entertaining film should line up.
The story, about a happy-go-lucky drunk who'll lose his fortune if he doesn't marry, hasn't changed, but somewhere along the way it has lost its reason for being.
[A] challenging and provocative must-see movie that provides no pat answers and will surely have audiences talking long afterwards.
A riveting movie that must be seen. There's a very good reason it won that Oscar.
Hill effortlessly blends state of the art CGI with winning animation.
Although this is basically 'Malcolm in the Middle' style material it's largely entertaining and harmless fun, especially for its target audience.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid 2: Rodrick Rules (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This almost laughable mock-adventure should give Warner Bros at least one good weekend before receipts take a nosedive and audiences discover they are the ones being sucker-punched.

Americanized remakes of foreign hits often miss what made those properties work in the first place, but Jones, DeNiro and company know less is more in this instance and deliver a work that's very fine indeed.
A stirring story that mixes personal horror, courage and eventually triumph.
This one really is winning all the way.
Paul makes going to the movies fun again.
A don't-miss cinematic page-turner with enough twists to fill five movies.
A Hitchcockian thriller with a bit of Unstoppable and a little Unknown.
The perfect family film in every way, moms, dads, kids and even those Martians are gonna love this funny, warm and wonderful tale.
It is at times riotously raunchy and funny but, for the most part, grounded in a sweet reality.
It fails so completely at its reach for lowness that you may find yourself crying out for Mel Brooks, Monty Python, hell even Cheech OR Chong to swoop in and save the thing. No such luck.
Drive dynamically merges a terrific film noir plot with a cool retro look, evoking '60s classics like Point Blank and Bullitt.
A wildly entertaining and dazzling mind-trip not to be missed. Kubrick would have been proud.
Love Ranch proves to be a provocative, highly entertaining and surprisingly touching peek into a unique world movies don't often explore.
A moving story of love, loss, hope and renewal.
Benefits from the forceful presence of Sam Worthington (Avatar) in the key role and is full of high flying action, nifty monsters, valiant heroes, plotting villains and impressive CGI.
What he's achieved here is a beautifully crafted movie likely to have audiences talking long afterward.

Fortunately, The Last Song mercifully avoids some of the clichés of its genre and will likely provide an unforgettably touching and wonderful film experience for the target teen girl audience that is bound to line up for it in droves.
Indie down to its core , this dreary film fails to engage on many levels. The camera work is nice though, particularly when it's focused on pigeons.
A seamy and delicious melodramatic wallow centered by another fearless performance from Julianne Moore.
Although some of this is just too literal and the ending a bit unsatisfying in its obvious simplemindedness, The Good Heart is redeemed as a wonderful opportunity for memorable character studies.
Campanella has laced his story with twists and turns worthy of Hitchcock and the framing device of the novel (which forces the protagonist to sort out the whole thing through writing) is ingenious.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Noah Baumbach rebounds in a big way with Greenberg, a brilliant triumph for all involved.
City Island is pure entertainment in the vein of Moonstruck. Star Andy Garcia has never been better or, surprisingly, more in his comedic element.
The sad thing is good romantic comedies are on the endangered species list. The Bounty Hunter proves the point.

Possesses enough PG rated gross-out gags and recognizable antics (to junior high schoolers and their nostalgia-inclined parents at least) along with that "best seller" pedigree to register a fairly decent opening and a hell of an afterlife on DVD.

Dreamworks may have topped itself with How To Train Your Dragon, an exciting, fun and sensationally entertaining movie for everyone, a thrilling action adventure fantasy that should slay the competition and grab great word of mouth.
Outstanding performances from Richard Gere, Don Cheadle and particularly Ethan Hawke lift this genre material into something special for fans of the actors.
Easygoing effort at times feels over-baked and too full of Perry's now-trademarked melodramatics.
movie_title: Why Did I Get Married Too (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Director Tim Burton returns to his 'A' game with this magnificent, visually stunning movie that is not only one of his best, it is indeed a wonder.

A staple of Oscar season for the past five years, Shorts International and Magnolia bring back the Oscar nominated animated and live action contenders in a program that clearly proves the most inventive work in the short form.
The cast could not be better.
Columbus knows his way around this kind of material even if some of the special effects look like they came from Deep Discount.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Mildly diverting but entirely forgettable.
Entertaining, full of laughs and, as far as chick flicks go, is a sweet, romantic trip worth taking for audiences so inclined.
