Mel Gibson shines in this kind of role, and he's at his very best in this politically charged thriller about a veteran homicide detective who goes after the murderers of his 24 year old daughter.
Essentially a B-movie dressed up with A-level special effects, Legion looks spiffy but sounds bad with a lot of overwritten dialogue scenes and predictable action.
Strictly for 6 year olds, this uninspired, one-joke comedy is full of too many misfired gags and weak comic setups to cross over to anyone whose head reaches above the seat back.
Solidly well-crafted and engrossing drama.
With riveting action that never stops, The Book of Eli gets the year off to a spectacularly exciting start at the movies and should keep turnstiles turning.
Doesn't break any new ground. In fact, it resembles any number of quirky indie character pieces.
If they had dropped The New Daughter title, took Costner's mug off the one sheet and just called it The Mound they actually might have had a modest hit.
A smart, sophisticated and downright hilarious comedy.
Another winner from Laika. It has heart, humor and beautiful animation. What more could you want?

A reimagining of George Romero's 1973 horror flick, The Crazies brings in contemporary themes of paranoia and bio-terror and updates them for a new generation to whom this sort of far-fetched premise holds some fear-based truth.
A rousingly funny, heartfelt and imaginative 'toon blessed with the vocal talents of Steve Carell and loaded with whimsy and smarts.

Clearly Goldberger thinks he can juggle this delicate noirish soufflé but it all comes crashing down around him because the true nature of his characters' actions just don't make a whole lot of sense.
There is no complexity to these characters at all and the relentless pitch for prayer as the answer to all lifeâ(TM)s problems is laid on like molasses.
First and foremost an actor's dream, CYRUS proves to be one of a slow year's rare delicious comedic treats.
A stylish, globe-hopping, action-packed comedy that starts at full blast and never lets up. Cruise hasn't been this loose and comfortable on screen in a long time.
A riveting look at a side of South Africa that seems to have been swept under the rug.
The saving grace of this remake is the inspired idea to set it in China, offering bountiful travelogue opportunities.
Wisely they have reduced the series' camp factor and brought it in line with audience expectations for this kind of patented summer flick.
Woody, Buzz and the gang are back on the screen and that's cause for major celebration for moviegoers.
This absolutely fascinating true story is a rich, romantic and captivating movie experience.
Like Michael Cera, Jesse Eisenberg is seriously in danger of playing the same guy over and over. Or maybe Cera and Eisenberg ARE the same guy. At least the hair's different this time.
Douglas is terrific, delivering one of the best performances of his career.
Brand and Hill have an outrageous and hilarious blast that rocks and rolls with constant comedy.
With first-rate performances from Sean Penn and Naomi Watts and a compelling script, this suspenseful, taut drama should keep audiences nailed to their seats.
A choice cast and, as usual, some snappy Allen patter and observations on amour-or the lack of it-will hit the bulls-eye with Allen fans who follow him wherever he goes.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Stone's surprisingly vital revisit to his hit 1987 movie only really falters right at the end, when it appears to succumb more to old Hollywood conventions than to Wall Street's. But like the key characters in the film it still leaves us wanting more.
You can't make this stuff up, folks. Gibney does a fine job laying it out on the table for what it is.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A fanboy's kick-ass wet dream of a movie that could be a surprise spring smash. Kick-Ass has it all, the triumphant comic book movie fans have been waiting for.
A summertime treat that "reverses time" to when flicks were just plain fun.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Shrek is without question the funniest film of the year-at least so far.
The story behind brothers Logan and Noah Miller getting their movie made is almost better than what's on screen but the film is heartfelt and engaging enough to be worthy of attention.
Caine's finest acting hour in a while reminds us he can still get down and dirty with the best of them.
The basic feeling you get out of this thing is 'been there-done that'.
As he was the first time around, Downey Jr. is the man!
Too introverted and gimmicky for its own good.
Oceans is simply amazing at times, a truly remarkable and extraordinary journey under the sea that takes us places we have never been before.
Although it's formulaic in the extreme, The Back-up Plan is an easygoing romantic comedy treat for fans of Jennifer Lopez.

Director Sylvain White infuses the proceedings with a lot of high tech gadgetry and flashy editing techniques that make The Losers feel more like a video game than a movie, but eventually we get to know the human element and the film takes off.
A perfect family movie.
Offers very little new for those who saw the original.
One of the most profound movies about married life seen on screen in some time.
A piercing and intelligent dramedy.
movie_title: The City of Your Final Destination (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The entire cast is superb.
Pputs a human face on the hot-button topic of immigration in such effective and emotional terms that you may never look at the subject in the same way again.
Faux Altman sexual wallow in which a lot of fine actors are wasted on pretentious mumbo jumbo.
Lock the cage and throw away the key. 'Babe' this is NOT.
A snail with the need for speed turns into the best animated film I have seen all year. We may have seen this all in Ratatouille but it still seems fresh as a slug.
A refreshing , almost film noirish reboot of the Wolverine franchise that uses its Japan locations to good advantage. Jackman is a great action star.
Easily one of the best movies you will see all year. It's funny and grabs the heart. Sam Rockwell deserves an Oscar nomination.
Powerful and disturbing.Michael B. Jordan is brilliant. It shows us we can't change the past but with movies like this perhaps we can make a better future.
The most spectacular visual effects of the year. Del Toro is a master. May be the greatest monster movie I have ever seen.
The screen team of the season , Bullock and McCarthy , deliver a sizzling hot summer comedy. Over the top , but undeniable fun.

Wasn't it just two months ago we watched the White House go up in flames in Olympus Has Fallen? This is the same thing, but even more absurd and ridiculous. An ace cast can't save it though Tatum makes a fine action star.
Zombies are hotter than ever and now it's Brad Pitt's turn. Much better than its troubled production history would indicate , World War Z is epic and fun.
Pixar has done it again. Literally. Monsters University has loads of laughs and heart.
The premise is intriguing but the movie is pretty disgusting. If it really had something to say about violence in our society okay, but it's just there for entertainment so beware.
Want a feel-good movie this summer? Have I got the DOCUMENTARY for you!
Google my words: it's a winner. It may not be as great as Wedding Crashers but this re-teaming of Vince Vaughn and Owen Wilson was worth the 8-year wait.
Sofia Coppola's sly comment on the vapidness of pop culture and a group of teens lost in transition points out our obsession with fame and gets it all right.
This movie makes Superbad and Pineapple Express look like child's play. Outrageous and undeniably hilarious, but how did it not get an 'NC 17'?
If you liked Red , you'll like this nicely pitched sequel. It doesn't break new ground but it's good mindless summer fun with a great cast.
The attempt to do something different and a bit darker is admirable but this Superman doesn't fly, it just assaults the senses. Where's the fun?
Loved Stand By Me? This is for you. The Kings Of Summer is absolutely wonderful, a welcome gift for moviegoers and a true gem in a season of non-stop mayhem. Don't Miss it.
Pure summer movie magic - literally. More fun than Ocean's 11, 12 and 13 combined. You won't believe you eyes - and that's the point.
There's never been a movie like it. Hollywood just doesn't make dramas in 3D but this one is truly sensational. Di Caprio delivers one of his best performances.

Extraordinary, if a little hard to follow at times. A jaw-dropping, exciting and the most visually stunning and innovative science-fiction thriller to hit the screen since 'Blade Runner' . Cruise delivers one of the best performances of his career.
The new year's nicest and most welcome surprise. A funny, heartwarming, superbly acted film that makes you feel good about life.
'Rambo' in the White House! Gerard Butler is an action superstar of guts and glory. A gripping edge-of-your-seat thriller with first rate direction by Antoine Fuqua. A must-see for action fans.
The first great animated film of the year. Truly hilarious.
Powerful and brilliantly acted. Tommy Lee Jones is remarkable as General Douglas MacArthur in a side of World War II that has remained hidden.
A dazzling, thrilling and wonderfully entertaining brand new classic. This is a Wizard of 'Awe'.
Bill Murray winningly portrays Roosevelt with sly understatement and assured authority
The sensational Helen Mirren sounds the war cry for all those unappreciated "plus ones"
A fascinating, savvy look at the inner-workings of the political process and how things in the White House get - or don't get - done
Consider it a force in the Best Animated Film Oscar race
Madea this ain't.
Extraordinary! A magical and wondrous - and blessedly original - animated movie experience for everyone.
This magnificent stop-motion cartoon is alive -- "it's alive! -- with laughs and heart
Woody Allen gets serious with this searing portrait of a woman under the influence and a remarkable performance from Cate Blanchett.
Terrific and scary-as-hell horror movie more in the spirit of psychological classics like The Innocents or the original 1963 The Haunting.
The best of this summer's blockbuster movies. It is amazing. The most entertaining, exciting, provocative and powerful of all the Apes films.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This charmer about late middle-aged renaissance is pertinent for these times and a perfect summer comedy for grown-ups looking to escape robots and superheroes.

Magnificent. Truly epic in its scope and ambition. It stays with you long after you leave the theatre. This 'Noah' is unlike any other film of its kind - an intimate and stirring new take on a biblical story we only thought we knew.
What went wrong? I am sad to say, the script by Cormac McCarthy. It just doesn't work. And who can even follow this thing? It starts out under the sheets and quite frankly should have stayed there.
Coming of age movie about the Beat Generation. Daniel Radcliffe as poet Allen Ginsberg continues to divorce himself from his Harry Potter roots standing out in a fine ensemble.
Robert Redford gives the performance of his life in this one man show brilliantly directed by J.C.Chandor. It's a towering achievement for both of them.
Brutal, harrowing, powerful and exceptionally well-acted. Worth seeing but not for those with weak stomachs. Director Steve McQueen doesn't spare the viewer.
Smart,intelligent that plays like a current 'All The President's Men' , a journalistic thriller with lots of pertinent questions but no real answers.
I was shocked but this Sly/Arnold combo package flick is far more entertaining as an action film than you might expect. Thanks to a clever twist, it's actually a lot of fun.

I really wanted to like this film because its cast is generally terrific in everything they do , but only Richard Jenkins and Catherine O'Hara really stand out here. A near-miss and sadly blah comedy that should have been smarter.

Docudrama about the JFK assasination from different points of view of people on the sidelines has its moments but ultimately falls short of its potential. Still if you are into this subject as the 50th anni nears you may want to go.
Paul Greengrass has made a hell of a white knuckle thriller out of a story in which most people know the ending going in. Tom Hanks' best performance in years.

Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey set the standard for films about space exploration. Until Now. But this one focuses on the human element and boy, are you in for a mind trip with Gravity. The cinematic achievement of the year.
It's a romantic comedy about sex addiction but somehow it pulls off the premise. Director Stuart Blumberg takes some unlikely material for the genre and makes it work.
Forgettable movie about a college-age girl trying to make up for lost time sexually may be just a 'to do' lister for that demo and no one else.
The ads say 'at last a movie for adults' and this time the advertising is not lying. A wonderful grown up movie. Gandolfini and Louis Dreyfus are terrific together.
A lame comedy that looks like it was made - and belongs - in the 60's. Despite a game cast this movie is broad without being even remotely believable.
This is about as intense as movies can get. Superb performances and great direction will keep you on the edge of your seat.
One of the best films this year - or any year. Certainly the finest film about auto racing I've seen because it focuses on the human element.
With more puns than any one movie should be allowed, this is a decent sequel that should appeal to the younger members of the family.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Wong Kar Wai is one of the world's great filmmakers and his first foray into the realm of martial arts is definitely worth seeing , even if at times confusing. Gorgeous to watch and beautiful action sequences make up for the wobbly script.

Easy-going and sweet-natured, this "romantic sports comedy" finally dissolves into a gooey mess of over-cooked comfort food.
Persistently baffling, contrived, and often simply bizarre -- a highbrow misfire of the most peculiar sort.
Unlike many regular thrillers, there is no comedy or cynicism to counterweight the absurdity, and not much actual excitement either.
The film finally fizzles into feeble melodrama, with all the power of an old episode of Grange Hill.
As so often, this diluted Gulliver's Travels is presented as if it were a children's story, clearly influenced by similarly defanged versions of Alice In Wonderland.
Avoid this sickly-sweet, dishonest nonsense.
No screen couple, before or since, had as much chemistry as Bogart and Bacall.

The Way Back is a robustly made picture, heartfelt, well executed with an exhilarating sense of reach and narrative ambition. Where it falls down is a lack of personal intensity to match the spectacle.
The direction and writing are phoned in, and probably the art direction and location catering too. The whole film is on some sort of conference call.
There is one sort-of reasonable joke about the Marriott hotel. Otherwise this is one to miss.
It really is an intriguing modern tale of communication, intimacy, self-knowledge and the web: a great companion to The Social Network.
Unfortunately, the funny side of the film is abandoned quickly, and the muddled plot disappears bubblingly into the lagoon.
Lubitsch demonstrates that romantic comedies, like popcorn, can be enjoyed salty as well as sweet.
A movie that delivers less than it promises.
Even as a fan, I found it very self-indulgent.
Pilger has returned to a subject that can't be revived often enough: the grotesque untruth of "weapons of mass destruction"...

Spasojevic has created a migraine-inducing "controversy" with this badly acted and directed porn-horror nightmare that aspires to be a satire on the dark heart of modern Serbia, with oblique references to the 1990s war.
This is a very postmodern sci-fi, with its downbeat approach to the monsters themselves, but with a hugely involving love story.
The focus is fatally divided from the outset and Freida Pinto looks uneasy and miscast as Miral herself.
The film is a slow-burner: a study in loneliness and alienation, whose unexpected ending and ambiguous aftermath require us to reassess all that has gone before.
Just when we thought John Malkovich didn't have another semi-intentionally deranged performance left in him, he has come storming back with another uproarious turn...
Good stuff, up to a point, but nothing like the passion and brilliance of The Incredibles or Toy Story.
This is a movie with a big heart, and nice performances from Josh Bolt and Eugene Byrne, playing teenage best mates, but for me it somehow never quite got over its sentimental unrealities.
movie_title: The Be All and End All (2009)

movie_review_blurb: For a while, it's a genuinely funny and unnerving experience, promising a lively payoff, but the ending is anti-climactic and the meaning of the title is only revealed in the laborious, jokey ending.

Of Gods and Men strives for simplicity; cinema is usually about dynamism, attraction, ego, but this movie concerns the renunciation of these things, in art and life. But it is also about the question of how to act when this life is violently challenged.
It purrs evenly, like the engine of a luxury automobile, with a cool, sleek satisfaction at how stylish it is. That said, it is pretty stylish...
It's a film with plenty of front, as they say, but uses up all its energy, wit and ideas in the first 20 or so minutes, before collapsing into a flurry of boring violence.
It's an intriguing film...
As this strangely dull story headed for the buffers, the forces dragging my eyelids south were unstoppable.
No it's not. It's kind of a rubbish story.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's entertaining in a cheerfully ridiculous way, though Cage fans will be disappointed that he does not really lose his rag, despite some serious provocation from the Lord of Darkness.
The narrative isn't entirely convincing, but the powerful and heartfelt performances from Turgoose and Grainger are.
This True Grit is a very impressive piece of work, beautifully photographed by Roger Deakins, and if you had never seen the original, it might be getting even higher praise.

The sheer excruciating, stultifying good taste of this movie is almost unbearable - so tasteful it could have started out as a coffee-table book, though actually it is based on a Pulitzer-winning play by David Lindsay-Abaire.
It's impossible to watch Nicolas Philibert's new film without a Darwinian frisson of anxiety, and an animal-liberationist spasm of rage.
This film is one long biopsy of pure horror: the tumours of sentimentality and bad acting metastasise everywhere, and Bernal, in particular, is horrendously bad.
The Fighter looks at first as if it is going to be a far more interesting movie than the straightforward and even rather undemanding drama we finally get.
It's a reasonable film, unpretentious in its way.
A bold and exhilarating picture, summoning up, in its own way, a chill seafront breeze of guilt and shame.
Although its uncritical tone makes it look occasionally like a promotional video, it's clear that there is a lot to hero-worship.
movie_title: How Much Does Your Building Weigh, Mr. Foster? (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Could it be that Peter Morgan's clout gave him the right to dredge up from his desk drawer some terrible old script? Maybe. Either way, it's one to forget for all concerned.
It's all as warm and fuzzy as the smoke from Barney's cigars, and just as much of an acquired taste.
A fatuous and depressing parade of nothingness...
The sheer tidal force of the film sweeps it along, and it is speckled with moments of poetry and unarguable brilliance.
Elegant, eccentric and absolutely captivating, this is simply a gem.
It's arguably too long and there's a touch of self-mythologising but with compelling flashes of rage and nauseous black comedy, and some brilliant and bizarre images...
Audiences who like the spectacle of men being tortured and women being raped may well be the same audiences. For them, this film offers a two-for-one deal.
Harrison Ford gives an under-par performance in this disappointing TV-studio-set romantic comedy.
Undoubtedly, Gould was an eccentric and a hypochondriac, but this film argues for his human vulnerability.
movie_title: Genius Within: The Inner Life of Glenn Gould (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Well, the movie still looks very good, and you'd need a heart of stone not to love the cat.
Fantastically deranged at all times, Darren Aronofsky's ballet psycho-melodrama is a glittering, crackling, outrageously pickable scab of a film.
Earnest, dull...
Almost everything about the film is disappointing.
It's a powerful film.
A potentially interesting idea for a lo-fi British Deliverance-style thriller is badly let down by very slack acting and dialogue, topped off with humourless sentimentalism.
A sombre, painful portrait of a toxic marriage, often touching and sometimes moving, though occasionally contrived and self-conscious in its effects.
It has neither the comic invention of Borat nor the genuine daredevil likability of the Jackass crew. Just depressing.

If anything deserves the "dark masterpiece" tag, this does: a brilliant satirical insight into the neurotic, pornographic element in the act of filming, more relevant than ever in the age of reality television and CCTV.
Perhaps it is all a little recondite, but there are moments of austere visual poetry...
It seems like a very personal project for both Winstone and Howman, filled with interesting but unfinished and undeveloped dramatic ideas.
Future historians of the financial crisis may point to this movie, not Oliver Stone's Wall Street sequel, as the cultural low point of the business world.
It is a scary, moving and troubling film.

Like a very lo-fi Toy Story with the vibe of a live-action Terry Gilliam cartoon and the addled craziness of SpongeBob SquarePants; it's funny for adults and children alike in a refreshing, barking mad sort of way.
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Made in Dagenham goes against the bittersweet/miserablist grain.
By the end, I was quietly wheezing and whinnying with distress.
The counter-Freudian drama is handled with easy wit and flair, like a Shakespearian disguise comedy, and it made a whopping star of Fox.
Chris Smith's documentary centres on a long and disquieting interview with Michael Ruppert, a radical American activist on a mission to expose the "peak oil" cover-up...
This whole film is very "police": that is, not exciting or dramatic, but suspicious, cynical and exhausted.
A low-key pleasure.
This movie naturally boasts some great action scenes. But otherwise it's a slightly plodding account of Chinese myth and legend.

I have to say that Clift's plot is far less compelling than Lancaster's and something of the zip goes when Frank Sinatra disappears from the action, sent to the stockade. But what a punch this movie still packs.
It's the kind of knockabout, kid's-eye-view comedy-horror that hasn't been made for a while, with some nasty, frightening touches, but expertly encased in a distinctive family-movie aesthetic.
This involving film is an eye-opener.
This is a grandiose hallucinatory journey into, and out of, hell: drugged, neon-lit and with a fully realised nightmare-porn aesthetic that has to be seen to be believed.
Sit, watch, groan. Yawn, fidget, stretch. Eat Snickers, pray for end of dire film about Julia Roberts's emotional growth, love the fact it can't last for ever. Wince, daydream, frown.
If you have tears, prepare to shed them for some other tale of woe.
McKay and co-writer Dave Henchy keep on pumping out gags; their movie often looks like a 107-minute comedy sketch, and I laughed throughout.
It's machine-tooled for the horror fanbase: brash, slick, yucky -- by-the-numbers stuff.

It is all given unironic dignity and power due to the outstanding lead performance from 20-year-old Jennifer Lawrence as Ree, a young woman who must take on some scary neighbourhood types to protect her family.
It's a tremendously effective, forthright entertainment, and Frears and Buffini make their craftsmanship look easy, creating a soap-farce pastoral of Brit bourgeois out-of-towners.
Maybe The Runaways is Linson's way of showing that he can make a success of this subject, and I think he has done, with a film which shows how brutal and sexist rock'n'roll is.
A long haul.
Alamar, for all its laid-back charm, offers no real answers and its naivety is perplexing.
If Michael Haneke were drafted in to direct an EastEnders Christmas special, it might look like this raw, no-budget, home-invasion nightmare.
It advances important and laudable ideas, but in a cliched, gimmicky way.
It is a very English tale of a bumbling drug empire built almost by accident. You have to take it with a pinch of salt: but it's entertaining.
A discourse in which the artist as creator is respectfully restored to the very centre of the process, and not marginalised by the cross-currents of money, fashion or theory.
movie_title: Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film withholds the explicit fear and passion that another kind of treatment might have aimed for, but it works as a cogent, subdued parable of mortality.
The last time I heard a film audience in such a state of silence was during Ingmar Bergman's Winter Light.
The great names of both Cuban and American jazz are invoked, and Chico and Rita's tragicomic love story meshes very pleasingly with this musical backdrop.
The tale is told competently enough, but the central relationship between the parents, Clarice and Mathias, is unsatisfying...
A clever, perhaps even brilliant idea for a black comedy has here been slathered and stifled in a thick treacly layer of Disney-sentimental gloop.
You really will need a sweet tooth for this one. Or rather, you will need a complete set of dentures made out of Mars Bars and Creme Eggs.
movie_title: La tête en friche (My Afternoons with Margueritte) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's not entirely believable and yet Arnott and Browne show an absolute, full-on commitment. Even though it's flawed, it's also strangely heartfelt.

There's no doubt about it: this film's an unashamed heart-wringer and a tear-jerker, but it packs an almighty punch and the CGI work at the very beginning, as Tangshan crumbles into nothingness, is impressive and pretty scary.
My only quarrel is that it is perhaps too short, and could have done with more wide-ranging interviews to tackle its implications.
Like Giorgios Lanthimos's recent shocker Dogtooth, it is a grisly satire on family dysfunction and abuse, and on poverty, society and the law.
A very good film, slightly overpraised, has been remade as a slightly good film, very overpraised.
There are some nice moments, but the comedy mostly doesn't come off and there is no double-act chemistry between Downey and Galifianakis.
Why can't non-Jackass films show this kind of energy, clarity, force and ingenuity?
I couldn't help thinking that the standard of writing and characterisation was a little bit broad, and frankly not up to the level of TV dramas such as Skins or Queer As Folk.
In the end, there is something just a little too formulaic about the film.
[A] fatuous, self-serving and fantastically dishonest exercise in pseudo-compassion, composed in the supercilious "globalised" style of Alejandro González Iñarritu's 2006 film Babel.
I found Another Year a deeply involving, intelligent, compassionate drama of the sort only Leigh can create.
A witty portrait of postmodern family life in which script, casting, direction and location all just float together without any apparent effort at all.
I have never before seen something yucky on screen make an entire cinema audience suddenly hunch forward and bury their heads in their laps at the same time, as if in some secular mosque for wimps.
It's all very weird sometimes, but engaging: a nice half-term treat for younger children.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Nothing to frighten the horses, as they say, or interest or entertain them much, either.
Here is a pleasant, undemanding animated family comedy - decent enough, but it feels like a reshuffling of dozens of films you've seen before.
It's very silly and runs out of steam well before the end, though there are one or two gags.
[A] well-intentioned, but laboured and woodenly acted film, based on a true story.
Carlos is a television-drama-turned-movie that interestingly injects a boxset quality into its idea of epic.
Barnard has created a modernist, compassionate biopic: a tribute to her memory and her embattled community.
Tom Hooper's richly enjoyable and handsomely produced movie about George VI's struggle to cure his stammer is a massively confident crowd-pleaser.
It is a perfectly agreeable family entertainment, but not exactly original and nowhere near Pixar's great creations.
Not too bad, though a little plodding.
Which is better, a soulless life of work and striving for money, or a joyous embrace of family and kids in all their gorgeous life-affirming messiness?
This feature is a little rough around the edges, but Kevorkian has mobilised a top-notch cast and his story delivers more than a few shivers.
Bold, brilliant and exhilarating: an intimately horrible, sexually explicit and black-comic portrait of a toxic marriage.
It has the style of a Hammer shocker from decades ago; Wilde's romance is caricatured, certainly, but the whole thing is socked over with gusto.
At its worst, Tricks is tricksy: self-indulgent and a little twee, but at its frequent best it has an easy charm.
A very low-flying, sentimentalised account of the life of legendary first world war German air ace, Manfred Von Richthofen.
There is a kind of upfront honesty about this film, but also a sinking feeling that there is no real point to it.
An entertaining, technically superb if faintly unsatisfying futuristic thriller.
The documentary celebrates the athleticism and creativity of the sport's unsung Nureyevs and Nijinskys.
Despite clever moments and Hornbyesque touches of melancholy, it's let down by sitcom cliches, and by being weirdly incurious about the inner life of its female lead.
A triumphant conclusion to Jean-François Richet's exciting and enjoyable two-part story.
British director Simon Welsford's flawed movie has intriguing ideas and a great opening, but never comes together into a plausible fiction.
One of the most extraordinary moments in screen history. Oshima's film widens and deepens the sensual realm.
movie_title: In the Realm of the Senses (1976)

movie_review_blurb: A blazingly powerful action movie... whose unpretentious clarity makes for a refreshing change.
One of the most enjoyable films of the year.
Witty, ingenious, horrible entertainment.
Broken Embraces is a film in which the director demonstrates a continuing, virtuoso fluency in a cinematic language that he himself invented. It's an embrace I want to submit to.
Still a must-see for Pacino's potent and influential performance.
In the Disneyfied dumbed-down marketplace for kids' films, there's something daring and even refreshing in a movie which messes with conventional narrative. If only it wasn't so frantic.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This is pretty average stuff.
This is frankly pretty cliched stuff.
An intelligent, often gripping, and intriguingly autobiographical drama of paranoia.
The tasty nuggets of fun drown in all the soupy seriousness, but this time travel is sometimes an interesting ride.
There really isn't a spark of genuine humour or life in the entire thing, and the movie grinds its way to a syrupy finale.
A flawed but entertaining thriller.
The movie's problem is the division of loyalties between these two female leads, which fatally divides and muddles the dramatic focus.
You could take the kids to see it this summer holiday and avoid an hour or so of rain - or rent the DVD later on. Inoffensive.
Muscular, forthright storytelling, hard-smoking, hard-drinking action, horribly incorrect attitudes, brutality with a top-note of self-loathing, bushy moustaches and a cracking lead performance.
movie_title: Mesrine: Part 1 (Killer Instinct) and Part 2 (Public Enemy #1) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A tremendously funny and touching coming-of-age story, which he has set in the 1980s with a sprinkling of nicely chosen cultural references.
Head-bangingly hyperactive as ever, action maestro Tony Scott appears to have upped his caffeine intake for this unexpectedly entertaining remake.
A dose of stodgy comfort food in the form of a complacent, mediocre film, with an exasperatingly flaccid and anti-climactic ending.
This entertaining movie has no interest in digging deep. Maybe digging deep in a world of gorgeous surfaces is beside the point.
An utterly baffling and stunningly boring zombie horror thriller.
Overcooked, overproduced, and all the action is swamped with distracting camerawork and gimmicky design.
A loo book written by Pol Pot would have more laughs than this chillingly unfunny, cynically prefabricated non-comedy.
The film is slight, but there's enough there for Meadows to create a plausible narrative arc with solid laughs along the way.
A slow-moving, insistently gripping, faintly Dostoyevskian tale of violence and retribution set in the swooningly photographed Hungarian countryside.
An instantly gripping, funny, quietly persuasive drama that held me from the first frames.
Langworthy and Henein sketch out the way this crisis has entered Hollywood's consciousness, in the form of M Night Shyamalan's sci-fi clunker The Happening.
How can we, as a species, tolerate Jennifer Aniston with her blurry expression of emotional bravery?
A very ridiculous film which is also a treat.
A witty and engaging cine-autobiography.
movie_title: Les Plages d'Agnès (The Beaches of Agnes) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If you thought Deliverance was too subtle, too refined, too delicate, and that the hillbillies in it were far too much like characters from Jane Austen, then this is for you.
A handsomely made but tonally uncertain film; it's unsure whether to be an old-fashioned inspirational heartwarmer, or a paranoid prose-poem about ruined lives on the city's dangerous margins.
Despite the obvious Norman Bates-ish resemblance, Zahn is clearly supposed to be dishy. The Zahn/Aniston pairing is without chemistry and there frankly isn't a spark of real life in the whole film.
A measured, deathly serious epic.
What promises to be an epic story of a group of hippy radicals from May 1968 to the present, gradually unwinds into a long, long soap opera.

This gentle, heartfelt and well-acted film about Charles Darwin and his personal agony preceding the 1859 publication of On the Origin of Species does not shy away from the issues. But it personalises them, and places them in a new context.
The awful truth about no one from the Fame movie or TV show going on to become famous may not yet have dawned on the cast of this new and bizarrely pointless remake.

Goofy, amiable and often quite bizarre, this documentary from British producer-directors Robert Cannan and Corinna McFarlane is a little gem: it is effortlessly entertaining, and boasts what has to be the year's most extraordinary scene in factual cinema.
A potent and intriguing cinema of ideas.

Love's films have, in the past, brought me out in a rash - but this one is watchable. It's well made; there's a persistent and welcome undercurrent of humour in the script that reminded me of Love's sparky debut, Goodbye Charlie Bright,
Film-makers Trisha Ziff and Luis Lopez ask how and why the wisdom of the crowd decided that this image should not merely be a badge of youth radicalism, but an icon of purity.
The standard of acting and directing is at a very low ebb.
Away We Go has an easy, no-particular-place-to-go looseness that doesn't bear too close a scrutiny, but has a certain likability.
I found something a little verbose and stagey in this story in movie form.
It's pretty scary and entertaining stuff, though I always get the feeling that nothing in it lives up to the tremendous opening section.
A whiff of what I can only describe as pure evil billows off the screen while this comedy is playing: a buddy grossout picture with zero laughs and a persistent, chilling misogyny.
You will need to be a little patient and indulgent with this brand of comedy, but its sweetness of nature will win you round.
Despite some nice ideas, and an impressive cast, Avie Luthra's family-ensemble movie doesn't entirely come together.
It is very surreal, absurd, and often quite gross, with loads of very arch and knowing gags. It's not going to win any awards. Really, it's a DVD rental. There are some laughs. I laughed, anyway.
At once loud and boring, like watching paint dry while getting hit over the head with a frying pan. And at two and a half hours, it really is very long.

The romcom suspense caper is a cinematic recipe that Alfred Hitchcock took with him to his grave; certainly I can't imagine anyone now succeeding in blending thrills, spills, caresses and laughs the way he did in this sublime classic from 1959.
Nick Moran's film, based on the stage-play he wrote with James Hicks, is an eccentric, sometimes underpowered but always watchable story about the early-60s prehistory of pop culture.
This film is entirely empty: empty of substance, devoid of plausible characters, and without anything like a satisfying style.
This is high-stakes drama, bordering on realist melodrama. There are some awkward moments. Yet its heartfelt, unironic belief in the power of love is attractive.
The early shots of young Léaud's open, beaming face are desperately sad.
movie_title: Two in the Wave (Deux de la Vague) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A mysterious, hallucinatory and weirdly enthralling metaphysical essay.
At two and a half hours, it's a long haul. But there's entertainment and fun along the way.
The narrative structure is ingenious and sexual assault is at least shown as having dramatic and human consequences of some sort, if only in the context of revenge. Wasn't the original movie enough?
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It turns out to be every bit as crass, offensive and incorrect as you'd expect, but it's also - gulp! - really very funny an awful lot of the time, as well as bizarrely gripping.
Murray's film is clear-sighted about the tough choices involved.

The great-granddaddy of Ridley Scott's Gladiator hasn't lost any muscle tone after nearly half a century, and Kirk Douglas's direct, unpretentious performance as the great slave-rebel Spartacus is more engaging than ever.
This Sporting Life shrewdly anticipates modern Britain: a dour, yet thrilling and exhilarating film.
This bittersweet, autumnal heartwarmer about two middle-aged people getting a last chance at love and happiness exceeded my personal tolerance factor for gloop and gush - but not by too much.
A claustrophobic, tense, ultra-low-budget British film with a neat final twist.
The fundamental silliness and improbability of everything is an insuperable problem.
I personally think Losey's The Servant is the more interesting film, because it has the more interesting performance from Bogarde.
With much buzzing, beeping and whirring, the Terminator franchise comes to an absolute creative standstill, or even goes clankingly into reverse, with this fantastically dull fourth episode.
The film has richness and an unshowy compassion, its grammar and pace adjusting to the tempo of the countryside.
There is a fundamental lack of dramatic traction here and the surrealism creates an inert flabbiness in its already chaotic story.
Engaging and beguiling - perhaps in spite of itself - and a vital part of film history.
movie_title: Pierrot le Fou (Pierrot Goes Wild) (Crazy Pete) (1969)

movie_review_blurb: With elegance and despatch, veteran new wave master Claude Chabrol has brought off his most enjoyable film for some time.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A profoundly disquieting movie, superbly acted and directed. Its sinister riddle glitters more fiercely each time I watch it.
It fails as conventional war movie, as genre spoof, as trash and as pulp.
A bland, faintly pointless slice of sentimentality, suggesting comedy isn't Lee's strong suit.
This powerful, heartfelt and important drama from one of the great names in world cinema deserves to be seen.
Ice Age series comes fully endorsed as a safe ride for all ages.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's a picture with virility and confidence, and unlike Dillinger's machine-gun, which the man himself expertly takes to pieces, it never quite jams, and gets off one or two lethal rounds.
Philadelphia's soul legend Billy Paul takes centre stage in this intriguing documentary, which teases out the nuances of his complex and often painful career.
movie_title: Am I Black Enough for You? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There is a distinct pet-shop whiff coming off this weirdly soulless and not especially funny or exciting family comedy from Disney about guinea pigs.
Crass, contrived, tackily salacious and politically loaded in the most insidious way, this dodgy piece of nonsense purports to be an ensemble, multi-stranded drama in the style of Traffic or Crash.
A handsomely dressed and tastefully furnished drama that rolls out pretty conservatively, but is notable for two excellent performances.
This quietly intelligent drama, based on a true story, finds a new way of dramatising race, class and society in apartheid-era South Africa.
Perhaps the clearer and crisper this film appears, and the more its reputation grows, the more unsettling its indulgences and ellipses appear to be. Well ... never mind. It's still a landmark.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the West (1968)

movie_review_blurb: A game but chaotic attempt at neo-noir, ferociously acted and directed.
movie_title: Kærlighed på Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A bizarrely stilted, placid, agonisingly slow and hypnotisingly wooden documentary presented by Sir Derek Jacobi. It is like something that might appear on schools TV if everyone behind the camera had been smoking a Constable-Hay-Wain quantity of ganja.

The mere spectacle of Elwood and Jake in their shades isn't quite as giggle-inducing as it presumably was back in 1980, but the stunts are still awe-inspiring, and there's plenty of laughs. They really were thinking big.

Antichrist is a smirking contraption of a film, a cheeky, nasty, clever device for making us upset about the dead kid, making us scared at the creepy happenings, making us freaked out at the violence, and finally making us convulsed with liberal outrage.
Sandra Bullock is teamed up with Ryan Reynolds, and each star's face has a waxy immobility that has nothing to do with Botox; the pure awfulness of the script has paralysed their facial muscles.
A heartfelt, if self-consciously derivative drama of human loneliness.
A worthwhile film with real acting and directing talent, though probably best regarded as an extended short.
Not one of Park's best films, but it has bite.
There is a weird, almost comic absence of insight and perspective here. But it is a joke without humour and without a punchline.
With visceral power, they show how the support of Burma's monks gave vital authority to the protests.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Darker, more hormonal, more teenage-angsty and sadly more boring.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Leon Gast's documentary When We Were Kings, about the 1974 Ali-Foreman ﬁght in Zaire, now has a great companion piece.
A hugely overegged pudding of a film. It's an indulgent, complacent family comedy-drama.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A very stylish, if emotionally constrained film.
movie_title: Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters (1985)

movie_review_blurb: Intriguing - but some of the musicians are just the tiniest bit smug about how wackily offbeat they are.
The sex scenes are arguably pedantic and even crude, but Cloud 9 is raw human drama, well acted.
Howlingly funny, staggeringly rude, brutally incorrect and very often just brilliant.
This outstanding new film from Claire Denis demonstrates her fluency and mastery in the kind of movie-language that is rich, quietly complex and subtle - and very un-Hollywood.
For delirious offensiveness and imaginative grossout, this film deserves a congratulatory goblet of gore; and the surreal scenes of damnation have real chutzpah.
movie_title: Encarnação do Demônio (Devil's Reincarnation) (Embodiment of Evil) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Watching his funny and likeable Havana-set comedy is like chancing upon some undiscovered early gem by Godard or Woody Allen, and yet it has a worldliness and drollery that is all its own.
A very ordinary, conventional, by-the-numbers creepfest without any dark spark.
Leo and Upham give performances of great conviction and the film is bold and uncliched: especially the matter-of-fact treatment of guns.
The puzzle fits together very entertainingly here.
A rather smart, interestingly constructed scary movie from British director Christopher Smith.
Generic and workmanlike.
It is very silly, and it may take you some time to tune in to the giggle wavelength. Once you have, it's very funny.
It isn't the transcendent masterpiece that some admirers would have you believe: more like a black-comic nightmare that isn't exactly supposed to be funny. It's certainly arresting, though.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Our Beloved Month Of August is a real one-off: eccentric and singular and cerebral: an arthouse event, yes, but also witty and emotionally engaged. I found myself thinking about it for days afterwards - and smiling a very great deal. Try it.

These extraordinary musicians ought to put an end to any sniffiness about Gypsy music.
movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A somewhat far-fetched, melodramatic ending restores some self-esteem to Clayton. But not before we have seen the weariness and anger chip away at that handsome face.
A classic of English cinema.
An elaborate, self-conscious but arresting take on the Dracula myth.
movie_title: Dracula: Pages From a Virgin's Diary (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It's still vivid, barnstorming stuff.
movie_title: What Ever Happened to Baby Jane? (1962)

movie_review_blurb: A decent cast under Michael Apted's direction does its best, but it's dull, naive and dramatically inert.
You might well find it very silly, but it grew on me, and it's certainly based on an interesting premise.

McAvoy carries the picture confidently enough as a leading man, and there is a nice performance from Benedict Cumberbatch.
Mr Moore's excellent new film is a wakeup call.
Lagerfeld's mannerisms and stage-props are a kind of armour which make intimacy impossible.

once you have acclimatised yourself to the animation style, it tells a cracking good story, and the screenplay by Neil Gaiman and Roger Avary conjures a secret history of vulnerability and human weakness behind the legend.
The sheer ferocity of the central performance in this French psychological drama from writer-director Michel Spinosa is what saves it from being slightly one-dimensional.

Here's a startlingly original true-life story told in an oddly unoriginal way. And that attempt at instant classic status in the title doesn't quite convince. It's got no more dark grandeur than American Idol.

movie_review_blurb: All the story's power is allowed to leak away by the deliberative heaviness with which Rivette pads through his 150-minute narrative, with its exasperating lack of dramatic emphasis.
movie_title: The Story of Marie and Julien (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Dralon is more like it.
Pure fence-sitting liberal agony is all that's on offer here, in a muddled and pompous film about America's war on terror.
There is food for thought and food for every kind of feeling in Sean Penn's outstanding film.
After promising much, it leads nowhere, either emotionally or spiritually.
movie_title: In Memory of Me (In memoria di me) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Cross the street to avoid this one.
Bizarre, horribly violent and frequently brilliant black comedy from Belgium.
An unmissable rerelease.

A cracking armed-robbery thriller.
Relentlessly bad taste.
There can hardly be a bigger waste of time than this conceited and self-indulgent two-hander directed by Steve Buscemi, remade from a Theo Van Gogh film.
There is something thrilling and moving in this documentary about the great era of the Nasa moon landings.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

Sigur Ros' creativity and open attitude was at one with Iceland's ravishingly beautiful landscape.

There are interesting scenes, moments, ideas: but Eastern Promises does not have the sinew and boldness of Cronenberg's best work.

Exquisitely frigid, menacing, disquieting, with a storyline that keeps you off-balance, marred only by a slightly hackneyed dénouement.

movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Two future parents in their early 20s, hardly even grownups, make a romantic, idealistic wager on the future of their love. Apatow pulls off the considerable trick of making us feel protective, even parental towards these people.
Funny, likable and watchable, with some nice performances, particularly from Bob Hoskins as a lovelorn older man.
A fatuous, bafflingly imagined tale of the unhappy and unwell Beethoven and his ordeal in preparing the Ninth Symphony for its premiere.
Goofy and sweet.
De Niro and Joe Pesci are impeccable and Cathy Moriarty is iconically sexy.

Our hero is the ferocious but amnesiac CIA tough guy Jason Bourne played by Matt Damon, the contours of whose rock-hard pecs are traced by his drum-tight T-shirt. It's the role that turned this moon-faced boy into a man.
Gatlif is thrilled by the apparently inexhaustible energy of Romany music; a little of it goes quite a long way. But it's beautifully shot.
They're back! That lovable duo, back to kick some ass and ogle some babes! Yes - it's Max Von Sydow and Roman Polanski.

Josef Goebbels had a home movie made of the failed 1944 Hitler assassins being hanged from meathooks with piano wire. It probably had more laughs, more fun, more feelgood moments than this family comedy.
A bold, clear reading of Shakespeare's play and an exhilarating piece of wartime propaganda.

An engaging piece of work.

The sheer power of Simon Wiesenthal's remarkable story is what propels this heartfelt documentary tribute.
movie_title: I Have Never Forgotten You: The Life And Legacy Of Simon Wiesenthal (2007)

movie_review_blurb: At last, Matt Groening's brilliant creation has arrived in cinemas, dated only in the sense that we all know it began in 1990, but otherwise terrifically funny and contemporary.

Neither comic, nor tragic, nor tragicomic, the movie manages to be entirely inconsequential, gesturing at emotional truths which it is quite unable to embody.

Profoundly mysterious, erotic, funny, gentle, playful, utterly distinctive, it is the work of the Thai director and installation-artist Apichatpong Weerasethakul, who now has a claim to be approaching the league of Kiarostami and Haneke.
The week's biggest disappointment.

It's clear that this portrait of a sick society is meant to explain, at least partially, the horrendous war that breaks out at the very end of the film, and the fascism that quickly followed in its wake.
A shocking yet stately and powerful plea for women's rights.
Some old material given a delightful new grrrl-power twist.
Solid and convincing, if pedestrian, World War II story that has its moments.
Tenderly observed personal documentary on Korean wedding customs.
movie_title: The Korean Wedding Chest (Die koreanische Hochzeitstruhe) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The film is gorgeously shot and contains a plethora of haunting images...
movie_title: The Milk of Sorrow (La Teta Asustada) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There's really very little to say about this film beyond that it's absolutely brilliant.
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Utterly silly excuse for maximum debauchery from a once-talented director.
Quietly powerful.
Uneven but funny and audacious adolescent comedy from a talented beginner.
Feel-good movie about a Chinese dancer presses all the right buttons.
The suspense that director Patrick Hughes manages to mount remains low-grade throughout and the plot never becomes entirely plausible.
Like most of Jean-Luc Godard's other essay films, is all over the place and (purposely) impossible to follow.
Points must be awarded for nerve, but virtually every aspect of this misbegotten film misfires.
The basic premise of this delightful comedy from Sweden is one of the most imaginative you'll ever see.
The jokes, which are in the absolute poorest taste, remain hilarious, while a newer, deeper humanism, sensed in momentary flashes in the earlier film, is now fully on display.

While the mini-genre it occupies -- multi-storylined ensemble pieces about dysfunctional life in southern California -- is already well-established, Crash is a superb, sometimes literally breath-taking new addition to this august group.
Kosmos is nothing less than cosmic in scope, and it's beautifully shot, and profoundly imaginative, but it's finally just too much of a good thing.
All in all, it's a very sweet, quiet, ultra-laidback movie, but it may ultimately be just too quiet for Americans, on whom the in-jokes and local flavor will be lost.
Many stale plot devices are recycled.
A perfectly respectable, solidly-made film which, beyond the expert performance by the always reliable Ellen Burstyn, has unfortunately little to recommend it.
[A] delightful, sexy, and often audacious crowd-pleaser.
movie_title: Le nom des gens (The Names of Love) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A worthwhile, if less powerful offering from the Belgian masters of slice-of-life filmmaking.
A terrific movie.
Less pleasurable after the first fifteen minutes.
[A] flat and thoroughly predictable piece of filmmaking.
It's almost like Pollock has come back from the dead and that we're watching a recently made documentary instead of a fiction film.
It makes us realize, suddenly, and with immense regret, what the rest of contemporary cinema so sorely lacks.
A sublime tone poem that shows what cinema is capable of when it tries to do more than just tell a story.
A quiet film, certainly, but it's filled with small touches that manage to get deeply under your skin by the time the final credits roll.
Probably the most devilishly fascinating movie I've seen in months, if not years.

A superb example of the genre of the self-expressive documentary.
Gorris's recreation of the period setting is scrupulous and fresh.
A quiet delight.
It's more an experience than anything else, and if you're looking for a transformative, redemptive one yourself, at the moment you can't do any better than go to see this film.
One of the best films I've seen all year.
Even if the script had been more accessible, it's doubtful whether its ultra-high concept will connect with general audiences.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Consistently witty and entertaining.
Seldom has such great star power been marshaled in the service of a sillier movie than The Other Man.
At long last in this year's Cannes Competition, a film on a serious subject that nevertheless consistently entertains and often makes you laugh out loud.

We've all seen this film before -- two hoodlum friends from the tough, violent streets of South Boston trying to cope with the lure of easy money and the offsetting threat of jail time -- but we've never seen it this well done.
A solidly entertaining and energizing film.
Once again, veteran Israeli director Amos Gitai has made a subtle yet powerful and moving film on an aspect of Jewish experience.
All in all, it's a highly worthwhile, professionally accomplished project, but in its obsessive devotion to precise documentation, the film forgets to inspire.
The film is hampered by a plodding and unimaginative script whose situations are pedestrian and whose dialogue is much less sparkling than the filmmakers appear to think it is.
This first feature from Juan Antonio Bayona is an excellent exercise in the Spanish-language subdivision of the horror-ghost genre that Del Toro more or less single-handedly invented.
Fatih Akin's new film, once it comes together at the end and finally defeats the shagginess of his script, is a solid if uneven piece of work.
movie_title: Auf der Anderen Seite (The Edge of Heaven) (On the Other Side) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's the very unremitting nature of the vision that forces us to confront an unpalatable truth and in that, many willing to go along may find a strange sort of comfort.
Things never quite come together and the central plot focus of the family drama is never plausible enough to make for compelling cinema.
It is smart-arse rather than witty and the predictable sight gags (the fart cushion gets a trot) seem to have been dreamt up by a committee.
Sharp editing and slick camerawork emphasise the disjuncture between the brightly sunlit killing field and the dark office where political caution wrestles military urgency.
The result is an Everest film for thinking people that is both thrilling and exhilarating, a real must-see.
A day later, I was still chuckling.

The film is, in the end, like a roller-coaster ride: it's dizzying and thrilling but you don't go anywhere. It's a series of such glittering but hollow exchanges between characters who always look and act like characters.
If nothing else, it should urge you to press for large-scale horticulturalists to set aside a fraction of their landholdings for bee forage.
movie_title: Queen Of The Sun: What are the Bees Telling Us? (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Shamelessly sentimental but beautifully handled story of septuagenarian love features two sublime lead performances.
A fine assemblage of acting talent can't redeem lacklustre material in this adaptation of the Maeve Binchy short story, Hardcore.
The script, which [Director Paolo] Rotondo wrote, shows meticulous and clever plotting as the balance of power shifts minute-by-minute.

A loss of focus turns this small English feature from an excellent film into a routine and mediocre one about half-way through, but its opening reels have touches of understated genius about them and it is full of undeniably moving moments.
Much more than a hagiography, the film nevertheless cannot escape the charge of being excessively reverential. But it is nonetheless a compelling portrait of a man's important legacy to history.
movie_title: I Have Never Forgotten You: The Life And Legacy Of Simon Wiesenthal (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It also, not incidentally, an inspiring vision of the way forward for food production, a portrait of what Peterson calls "a dead farm coming back to life". After reading The Omnivore's Dilemma, it may be just the antidote you need.
movie_title: The Real Dirt on Farmer John (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A charmingly improbable and delicately emotionally nuanced Capraesque fable about the healing power of love.
Even the smart ending feels predictable once it's happened: "Move along," it seems to say, just like those New York cops. "There's nothing to see here."
A sophisticated and literate biographical speculation is the basis of this witty and entertaining portrait of the titular artist.
This is a film for people who find cereal-packet philosophy a bit taxing.
More sensuous than raunchy, but a remarkably engrossing adaptation of an early version of the famous Lawrence novel.
Hoss, surely the foremost German actress of her generation, gives a powerhouse performance, full of pain and longing, and the use of the Kurt Weill and Ogden Nash classic Speak Low is a masterstroke.
Three-fifths of a great film, this stylish, Glasgow-based, Danish-inspired stalker drama does not deliver on its promise.
Norton, an American, and Australian Watts are so busy struggling with their accents that they never really find their characters' hearts. But it's a solid piece of period escapism.

Any attempt to examine Redzepi's philosophy, much less interrogate the reasons for the restaurant's success (is it more than a fad or a gimmick?), is notably missing in action. In its place are pretty pictures of glistening leaves.

Unassuming and amiable, this road-trip buddy comedy... belongs squarely in the sub-genre of very-low-budget American indies with untrained actors and improvised dialogue that has been dubbed mumblecore.
What's most striking about the film, which will doubtless annoy textual purists but will surely excite movie fans, is how eerily quiet it is.

The most un-Herzog-like Werner Herzog film you're likely to see, this based-on-fact Vietnam War drama is very classy if rather standard stuff. But it is considerably enlivened by the always engaging presence of Christian Bale.
The film rewards a look for the performance of Marsan alone.
If the film is often pure hagiography, it's rescued by the huge charm of its subject, whose present-day interviews reveal a figure of compassion and humility.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This is an important film driven by a powerful, almost palpable, sense of moral urgency. It's also, not incidentally, an elegy for what newspapers used to be.
This is a brave, bold and important film.

Attention has rightly focused on Redmayne's extraordinary work as the steadily shrivelling Hawking, and the sense of mischief that he conjures using only his eyes is something to behold. But Jones is terrific as Jane, whose story the film is, really.
Well, she's Maggie, isn't she? Magnificent to behold, terrifying, pathetic and irreproachable. There ain't nothing like that dame.
An often gut-wrenching work of precocious mastery, it's as close as the cinema has ever been to the middle of the Holocaust. If you can bear it, you will not soon forget it.
This is proudly a Maori story with a Maori denouement, and it's a fitting reminder of the important place Ihimaera occupies in our national literature.

25 April doesn't seek to reinterpret the past: its mission is to document it is a direct and accessible way and it does that magnificently. It is assured of a long life, if only in the schoolrooms of the future, but it certainly warrants watching now.
Moving seamlessly between stage and screen enactments, Guillaume, who plays both himself and his neurotic, chain-smoking mum, concocts plenty of blackly comic moments.
The geopolitical realities of 2015 entitle us to expect something more nuanced than this.
The syrupy score just adds to the cheesiness of what is a classy disease-of-the-week weepie.

Turing (Benedict Cumberbatch) is front and centre in the new film and he's characteristically brilliant, though anyone hoping for a nuanced portrayal of one of the 20th century's most brilliant minds needs to look elsewhere.
It's all such damn good fun, that you can forgive some of the horrendously clunky lines.

The formidable running time will doubtless deter many, which is a shame: Winter Sleep is never less than richly engrossing, even if some scenes, stretched too long, take on a didactic, even slightly hectoring tone.
It is by turns funny, tragic and savage, but the strongest sense both leave us with is one of wistful mourning. It's not easy being an artist.
The film's multi-platform release tomorrow in cinemas, on television, video on demand and an airline is intended to defeat pirates, but piracy is probably not a major risk.
The film is given life by its superb acting, in particular Huppert's beautifully subtle and textured performance (watch for the great, silent scene at a window near the end).
Pitch-perfect acting and a fine control of high emotion that never slips into treacly sentiment distinguish this small and lovely ensemble piece by writer-director Ira Sachs.

A searching examination of middle-class complacency and gender roles in an age of us-or-them individualism, this assured Swedish drama is the kind of film that's hard to watch and harder still to tear your eyes away from.
A moviemaker's film: particularly in the sequences of work, in which blood and sweat and sweet crude mix and no one speaks, it is pure retina-searing cinema. Enthralling.

In a solid, unshowy turn by Bullock, a very underrated actress, as Harper Lee (plainly a co-creator of the landmark book), and you have a compellingly watchable portrait of the artist as an emotional cripple. Not to be missed.

Largely thanks to Cheadle and Ejiofor in the main roles, it settles into a persuasive rhythm and airs some of the big questions about black struggle against oppression without resorting to glib, feel-good answers.
Conceived as a television film, this recreation of the life and times of hangman Albert Pierrepoint is both unfalteringly grim and mesmerisingly watchable.
Grim but enormously confident feature debut unblinkingly anatomises life among working class Welsh no-hopers.
The best foreign film Oscar-winner is a tautly plotted political thriller of moral heft and fierce intelligence. A masterpiece.
It's predictable and ultimately quite trivial, but Sutherland alone is almost worth the ticket price.
It's a beauty, perhaps largely because it's as much about recent history as about its characters' Jewishness.

The pretext that sustains this provocative and intelligent French drama - that women can be sex tourists too - provides enough rope for anyone given to feminist and post-colonial analysis to tie themselves in knots.
Chaplinesque Italian comedian Benigni's valentine to love is an anti-war film without political bite but full of winsome charm.
movie_title: La tigre e la neve (The Tiger and the Snow) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This densely textured film by the writer-director team responsible for the sublime wartime drama Divided We Fall (2000) displays the same giddy blend of realist drama and bleak humour in the fine absurdist tradition.
movie_title: Up and Down (Horem Pádem) (Loop the Loop) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It's a sobering assessment, rescued from being entirely depressing by the sunny, matter-of-fact disposition of Jasmine and her mates.
Plodding, stolid German adaptation of best-selling book fails to engage with any of the complexities of its subject but the scenery is beautiful.

This elliptical structure demands and rewards close attention for the powerful ironies it illuminates: seeing actions lionised before we see the actions themselves, we confront the contrast between heroism's reality and its hokey facsimiles.

[Jindabyne] accomplished and impressive but if it has a frustration, it's that finally it is less than it seems.
A movie that's dull, plodding and extremely conventional.
It is extraordinarily accomplished but finally pretty sick.

The film certainly has a chillingly predictable arc -- and there's something slightly glib about the upbeat ending -- but it's a very accomplished debut by a film-maker who knows what suspense may be found in the mundane.
[Adams is] a knockout and makes the film, despite its shortcomings, deeply pleasurable.
[A] sincere and utterly unremarkable retelling of the Christmas story.
If you ever enjoyed an English comedy show on the telly and you're ready for a laugh, you're going to love this. Don't worry if you haven't the faintest idea what it's about. No one else does either.

movie_review_blurb: The movie is rich in interesting moments and the sisterly solidarity is touching, but it's insubstantial and incoherent. We emerge knowing that the Land of the Free doesn't much like dissent. But we already knew that.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Woody Allen reprises his Alvy Singer shtick in a pastiche of 50s screwball that is deeply unfunny.

Cleverly conceived, coolly plotted and driven by two splendid performances, this second feature by indie writer-director Brougher (her first shown here) is hampered by a jarringly abrupt ending that suggests a failure of nerve.
It's Jones who carries the film's meaning, and does so effortlessly. He -- and the Coens -- have never been better.
Well-intentioned save-the-planet doco is dense with factoids but ultimately something of a bore.
A top-notch piece of work by a director whose richly authentic dramas are regular inclusions in festival programmes.
Dispiriting.
The prodigally productive Depardieu turns in a perfectly inflected performance, full of grace and skill and with none of the curdled cynicism a lesser actor would have brought to the role.
Most of the problem is the absence of any perceptible chemistry between superstar Tautou and rising star Elmaleh.
At times it flies, but it never comes close to soaring.

Here's a film to take your breath away and make you weep: the former because of the spellbinding, big-screen nature photography that takes us deep into the world of Arctic wildlife; the latter because of a tooth-achingly banal commentary.

This is the film everyone will be talking about - and seeing repeatedly - this summer. Clocking in at less than an hour and a half, it's a small and perfectly formed gem that will leave you glowing for days.
Underwritten and overplayed, it is one that not even Buscemi fans will treasure.
Knowing in advance how it all turned out cannot rob this remarkable movie of any of its drama, although ignorance of the events probably adds to the kick.
Zinger lines, wonderful performances and a profound emotional authenticity distinguish a film about the relationship between an old actor and a young woman.
Slickly plotted murder thriller overcomes its advantages - notably two great performances - to be almost boring.
Sicilian writer-director Crialese adds another to the list of great immigrant films with this evocative, poetic drama about a family of his compatriots who make the fateful Atlantic crossing in 1904.
Of the four brilliant performances that sustain it, the standout is by Julie Christie, ravishing at 66, who communicates as much with utter stillness as in her beautifully articulated lines.
A beguiling and beautifully realised film in which two men, who haven't seen each other since they were kids, sit and talk.
movie_title: Dialogue avec mon jardinier (Conversations with My Gardener) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This is a film that abounds in smart touches.
Paul Verhoeven's first Dutch film in 25 years is lurid and tasteless.
This is a brave, smart and sensitive film.
Embarrassing attempt to replicate the success of the 2003 Jim Carrey vehicle Bruce Almighty.
Initial promise drowns in a tide of subplot complications in this sometimes slick and supremely nihilistic murder thriller which attempts to inject life into Kevin Costner by making him a bad guy.
It's a diverting example of the kind of French comedy that has a bit of meaty meaning to chew on.
Deeply romantic without being sentimental.
A handsome production design and some heartfelt performances in minor roles deliver incidental pleasures but the film as a whole feels like a wasted opportunity.
It's tempting to conclude that the entire thing is a rather distasteful joke at the audience's (and the actors') expense.
Dreadful.
Cinematographer Darius Khondji lends a magic light to landscape and interior alike -- it's as pretty a movie as Allen's done in a while.

Ssuperbly acted and, for much of its intricately plotted length, grips like a vice.

It's an early call, but this film... bids to be one of the best of the year.

Handsomely designed, if schematic.
