No matter how noble the competitor, coming in second in a contest always feels like a lesser effort.

A reverential but knowledgeable documentary about an aggressive offshoot of punk that flourished on the Left Coast from 1980-86, with outposts in such far-flung locales as Washington, D.C., New York, Boston, Detroit, Chicago and Austin, Tex.

[A] glorious mess of a movie.

A pleasing puzzle of feuding conjurers played by Christian Bale and Hugh Jackman.

The perception gap between an author's words on the printed page and how they translate to the screen has never yawned so widely as it does for Running With Scissors, a black comedy more likely to provoke upchucks than yuks.
One of the many remarkable things about this film is watching the band evolve as a result of an unplanned and apparently inconsequential remark.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

Quite dull, truth be told. As good as Dillon and Taylor are in their roles, making us side with them even as we despise them, there's not a whole lot that happens in a life ruled by the bottle, the butt and the shag.

Begins with flatulence, ends with flatulence and is one big gaseous emission in between.

Documentarians David Leaf and John Scheinfeld go beyond the usual glibness, revealing a much fuller portrait of the man.
A story of parental devotion and reconciliation that is a treat to the eyes and also an enticement to tears of empathy.
movie_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles (2006)

Mandatory viewing regardless, much as an alarm clock must be heeded despite its annoying ring.

What might just be the summer's worst movie, no small feat in a season already reeking of foul cinematic emissions.
The film may baffle regular citizens (and migraine sufferers), but it welcomes geeks of all ages and obsessions to its circus tent.
It yawningly snaps into place as yet another series of explosions that are dressed up with no place to blow.
Imagine the sparseness of classic oaters matched with the energy of martial arts movies and you've got what Kim Jee-won has wrought.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Duvall is a true American original.
Dead horse, meet floggers.
In adapting Francis Veber's 1998 French farce Le Dîner des cons (The Dinner Game), Roach and his writers David Guion and Michael Handelman have completely defanged it.
The franchise still has a lot of spark, but next time they need to clean the corrosion off the batteries.
At first, Inception left me cold, feeling as if I'd just eavesdropped on somebody's bad acid trip. Now I find I can't get the film out of my mind, which is really the whole point of it, isn't it?
"After the cinema, nothing surprises us," the narrator intones, and this is perhaps the only idea that Resnais wishes to gently leave with us.
The tragic art of Polytechnique isn't what it shows or reveals but rather the contemplation it inspires. There are moments in life when nothing makes sense and sadness descends; this is one of them.
Nobody does oily like Michael Douglas.
Helen Mirren's estimable talents are wasted in this soapy puddle, which is directed by her husband Taylor Hackford.
Eclipse suffers from an excess of characters and dialogue and a shortage of real plot changes, even with Hard Candy's sharp-eyed David Slade at the helm.
We are given little idea of what made these two icy sourpusses artists, let alone lovers. Both come across as shallow and unlikable people.

The best thing about the film is its bigheartedness. It's not out to mock these people, but rather to show how any person of any orientation can become unraveled when high-minded principles meet with base human instincts.
There are a lot of things wrong with this remake of A Nightmare on Elm Street, not least of which is that it was made at all.

Bissonnette achieves a hypnotic effect with Passenger Side. L.A. slides by in a daze, at once inviting and threatening. Michael and Tobey are just two Canadian dreamers in a city where dreams often die.
The Losers at least has speed on its side -- not to mention a bad case of ADD and camera jitters -- but all compliments end there.
The film is premised on the verbal communication of urgent information, yet its many non-verbal moments provide the greatest strength and clarity.

This pitiful excuse for entertainment is utterly bereft of wit, intelligence or craft on any level. The only thing left to screw up would have been to leave the lens cap on the camera. Wait, that would have been an improvement.
In a year less crowded with new young talent, Katie Jarvis might now be getting fittings for her Oscar nomination dress.

In a world lousy with computer animation and 3-D whizz-bangery -- j'accuse, James Cameron! -- it's nice to know there's still fun to be had with nothing more than plastic figures and a little imagination.
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Martin Scorsese's elephantine exercise in B-movie badness.
What makes it extraordinary is its depth of feeling, which Dolan's age makes all the more impressive: he was just 19 when he made this.
Amidst the gloom, urgently summoning our attention, is one of the most impressive performances of recent times, by relative newcomer Tahar Rahim.
Taking a dramatic turn from the slasher hilarity of his breakthrough feature Hatchet, writer/director Green plays it straight with a script that has the virtue of simplicity.
What begins as a drama about the birth of a great notion -- with its attendant battles between the pro and con sides -- instead becomes a dreary melodrama about family grief.

The plot gets twisted but the direction by Yates never does. He finds the humour in a desperate situation. It's hard to hate or even despise Dick and his stooges, because you can sense how needy they are.
A movie weighed down by a numbskull screenplay (by rookie Gary Whitta) and a careless lack of attention to details.
It's an amusing concept as far as it goes, although it doesn't go far enough.
Is this 2010, or 1950? It certainly seems the latter, since no contemporary woman with an IQ above Guinness temperature would sit with such nonsense.
Parnassus continues Gilliam's decade-old habit of sabotaging his work by piling on wild images without regard to character development or storytelling.
Few films on this topic so clearly illustrate the competing agendas and cut-throat capitalism of America's for-profit health care.
[Director] Hamer has a gift for observational comedy, previously demonstrated in the droll Kitchen Stories, and also for the exquisite framing of wintry images.
Polanski is in total command of his medium, something that hasn't been a sure thing since the 1970s, The Pianist notwithstanding.

If Remember Me is remembered for anything at all, other than being yet another Robert Pattinson vehicle, it will be for its over-the-top ending, which ranks high amongst the most shameless jerkers of tears ever unleashed upon lachrymose teens.
The film is post-modern surgery into the superhero myth, driving a scalpel into the warped logic of misanthropic killers who masquerade as civic do-gooders.

Appreciation of the film relies more on the performances than the problem-solving, and Rapace delivers a complicated and deliciously contrary performance that tattoos Lisbeth Salander straight onto the brain.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: LaBute wisely cast comic actors, rather than actors attempting to be comic. Timing and delivery are paramount in comedy, all the more so when the material is as daft as this.
You wonder how the characters could be so inept about their dirty deeds. How did they get so badly in over their heads? It's almost Biblical in the way it metes out rough justice.
We don't learn that much about Banksy, other than he's a lot more meticulous than his street warrior image would suggest.

Watching Carell and Fey in action, trading quips and dodging gunfire as they attempt to make their way home to white-picket-fence suburbia, makes you wonder why it's taken so long to bring these two gifted comics together.
IBurton and Woolverton pursue a message of self-fulfilment, not as vigorously as they might chase a rabbit but to the same delightful end.
It's one supremely silly movie, but it's also a Razzies-ready hoot.
Like the wonky Jacuzzi that gives the film its title and nutso travel mode, Hot Tub Time Machine operates in fits and starts.

There are two parallel stories: Milo's and Nicole's on-again, off-again relationship, and those guys with guns who keep shooting at them. We know exactly how the first one is going to end and we don't care about the second.

At least a robotic handclap is due to director Sapochnik for working within his limitations (including obvious budgetary ones) and giving this Frankenstein beast as much forward momentum as it possesses.
Fanning and Stewart are the deserving stars of the film, nailing every last look and lick, holding their own even as Shannon savvily attempts to nick every scene.
Green Zone has an attitude -- it persuades in almost documentary style that the war was sold on false pretences but no one's motives in this tangled affair can be completely trusted.

We may know exactly where Kirk and Molly are headed -- he can't get over his good fortune and she can't abide being put on a pedestal -- but the movie keeps upending our expectations and provoking laughs.

The film finds real sensual heat whenever Moore and Seyfried are together, and Egoyan and cinematographer Paul Sarossy turn up the thermostat by making Toronto locales seem exotic and vaguely sinister.
[The screenwriters] haven't given Ferrell a single witty line, which may explain why he seems to be so grimly going through the motions. The jokes aren't just worn out, they're clubbed to death.
Apart from the evocative title, which is a great nod to '50s drive-in fare, the film is as predictable as a meal beneath the golden arches.
Up is a story of human bonds remembered and new ones forged, and never for one moment does it seems insincere or contrived.
Vicky Cristina Barcelona is a comedy, a good one, and also one of Allen's best-ever meditations on the many entanglements of love.
This is still summer trash and no brain cells were injured or even fatigued in the making of it.
If promotional hype of Falstaffian proportions has you convinced that Hamlet 2 is a Shakespearean romp or a musical involving a rocking sexy deity, some elucidation is in order.

Passchendaele hearkens back to war films of decades past, when patriotism, valour and integrity were presented without irony. But it is infused with the stoicism of people who know it is their job to try to find meaning within an insane situation.
None of it makes strict sense, which is why it's called screwball, but in its own crazy way Burn After Reading nails the essential folly of humans pretending to be civilized.
Jackson hasn't had a role this good or this complex in many a moon, even if the rote ending betrays the complexity of the set-up.
Harris follows his strong helming debut Pollock with a contribution to the western movie revival that looks and sounds like a classic.
Sukiyaki Western Django is Takashi Miike's frantic swirl of a spaghetti western, marrying eastern and western elements in what could be taken as either homage or parody -- or both.
Most movies of this kind would lead towards redemption of sorts. Menzel prefers quiet introspection to loud conversion, and that's both a strength and weakness of this movie.
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It all wears very thin by the third act, when The Voice really starts to grate and all remaining sense slams into a brick wall.
[Lee] resorts to many of the same hoary clichés and fantasy situations he so frequently condemns.
Sam Rockwell's resistance to boos serves him well in Choke, a black comedy that actually improves upon the Chuck Palahniuk novel that spawned it.
Patti Smith: Dream of Life, fashion photographer Steven Sebring's impressionistic study of the most influential of punk poets, disarms and charms with its honesty.
Rachel Getting Married is a lot like life: always moving, forever unpredictable and forever getting in the way of best-laid plans.
Nick & Norah's only wishes it had some of Juno's wit and energy.
We need skeptics. They infuriate, but they also illuminate, and anybody whose faith can't take the knocks that Maher dishes out probably has deeper spiritual issues to deal with.
It seems Weide and Pegg were determined to make good on their title How to Lose Friends& Alienate People. You can sum up their results in two words: mission accomplished.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Changeling reminds us that the veneer of civilization is thin and made of quicksilver.
It is certainly possible to make a transgressive movie about children in sexual jeopardy, and to do so in ways that realistically and intelligently depict the abuse while not revelling in it.
It's a classic case of giving the people what they want.
There's nothing really wrong with Pride and Glory, apart from an excessive degree of brutality, but there's nothing terribly revelatory about it either.
The Diving Bell and the Butterfly is one of the best movies of 2007, but I'd argue it's also the one most in tune with what this season of goodwill and tolerance is supposed to be all about.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The transition from the slopes of Sundance to the hard streets of everywhere else is the artistic equivalent of the bends.
What keeps everything from imploding are Downey and Cruise, who are willing to push every audience button and damn the politically correct torpedoes.
Persepolis is a superb film about a young girl's coming of age amidst war, fascism and family tragedy.
If current events hold, Battle in Seattle could look like prophecy as well as history.
There should be some kind of law that if you're going to make an incredibly derivative, violent and vulgar teen comedy then it must also be funny.
W. is an engaging and sometimes revealing watch. At the very least, it's a change from the mindless Bush-bashing that has become so tedious.
Sometimes it amounts to a laugh or two.
Body of Lies is more than anything a missed opportunity -- or perhaps, given its cellular phoniness, a series of missed connections.
Consider that a virtue in a movie content to teach familiar messages without overstating them.
The year's best horror picture is also one of the simplest.
This film is a celebration of human achievement; it soars with the promise that we are shackled to the ground only by lack of imagination and will.

he brothers Duplass have a knack for the to-and-fro of modern relationships. Their horror sense is less acute, but at least they understand that when the budget is low, it's best to keep the villain in the shadows.

Apatow and Green are just throwing whatever they can at the screen, to see what will get either a laugh or a grimace. More likely the latter, since you'll likely leave the theatre wondering if you saw a comedy or a Sam Peckinpah movie.
Indy IV may not entirely be the grand return that everyone had hoped for, but it's still great to see a good old friend come around again.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film does offer a glimmer of hope that behind all the bellowing by politicians and thugs, there are millions of people in the Middle East who simply yearn for peace.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: [A] flaky disaster.
The rapport between the two rogue cineastes is enough to carry both films: the one they're making and the one Jennings is trying to make.
The glue that holds it together is Ejiofor's muscular performance as a man whose principles may be about to feel the brass knuckles of reality.
The singular achievement of SOP is reminding us that truth is always a slippery construct, made all the more so by the fallible human mind and the ever-blinking eye.
For those who'd like some substance in a movie pushing 2 1/2 hours, though, it's gratifying to report that this Sex is more than just a fan dance.
Well acted but dramatically unyielding.
Newcomer Wareing delivers an award-worthy performance as the steely Angie, who is impossible to hate even as she descends deeper into the moral abyss.
This is one of those rare pictures that can gross you out and make you think at one and the same time.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Baby Mama offers ample evidence that Fey and Poehler are more than ready for prime-time screen gigs. Let's hope they team again for a comedy that delivers all that it promises.
This movie is Battlefield Earth bad. It's 10,000 B.C. bad. It's bad with a side of fries and a cherry cola.
This is the long-awaited teaming of superstars Jackie Chan and Jet Li, and it's an occasion to applaud for those who like a few yuks with their kicks.
Forgetting Sarah Marshall finds Apatow back on form, after the recent disappointments of Drillbit Taylor and, to a lesser extent, Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story.
There's no rust on the first blockbuster of summer '08: Iron Man is an ironclad cinch to be a hit.
A less assured filmmaker would have trouble reconciling reality with magic realism, but writer/director Mehta turns kitchen-sink drama into soaring metaphor.
Neither as original as Ratatouille nor as funny as Shrek.
The lack of character shading suggests Marvel Studios went too far in distancing itself from Lee's much-reviled predecessor. Could a better balance between brawn and brains not have been struck?
The story is no more than a thread stitching set pieces of increasing implausibility and ineptitude.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Attenborough is a past master at this type of drama, and he confidently shifts between the decades, avoiding the confusion so common to non-linear films like this.

Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired, a documentary by Marina Zenovich that is also a first-rate work of reportage, makes a forceful case that the whole truth of the matter was never heard in court and Polanski was more sinned against than sinning.
Astute readers will note that I have abstained from making cheap cracks about the I Want to Believe title, an almost superhuman feat given this movie's abundance of sheer nonsense.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: [Director] Gibney assembles a wealth of Thompson memorabilia and first-person interviews for this often insightful and sometimes overly indulgent chronicle.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This film is not only one of the year's best; it may well end up as the finest of 2008. At the very least, it deserves consideration for Best Picture and Best Director, along with the expected Oscar kudos for Ledger.
Even if you can't completely follow the plot, you also can't take your eyes off the scenery, the thrilling horse chases and the throat-slashing battles.
The Wackness exudes a vibe that is rich in emotional truth, even if some of the details get lost in a green haze.
The greatest of all films by Pixar Animation, the little Disney studio with the Midas touch.
[Bekmambetov] hasn't just made a thriller with Wanted, he's redefined the genre.
The film, shot in black and white, like most of Maddin's creations, is a treat for fans and a migraine for the uninitiated or terminally dull.
Myers' Pitka is the stealthiest of holy rollers: he makes you roar just when you think he's going to hell in a hand basket.
The truth is that Get Smart is one of the year's sharper comedies, and if it contains any WMDs, that stands for 'wit of major delight.'
In truth, Canadian filmmaker Martin Gero's very funny and insightful feature debut is far less shocking than its detractors -- most of whom haven't even seen it -- would have you believe.
Hancock is still worth seeing, if only for a glimpse of what might have been a truly innovative idea.
Just one person saves Smart People from being completely wretched. It's the presence of Thomas Haden Church.
You'd probably need a veteran Hollywood psychiatrist to explain Tinseltown's fascination with its own muck.
Does anyone remember when Madonna was considered shocking?

Despite its title, Virtual JFK doesn't imagine a world where JFK survives the events of Dallas and goes on to win a second term as U.S. president. That would be a whole other movie, and a fascinating one at that.
movie_title: Virtual JFK: Vietnam If Kennedy Had Lived (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Impeccable production values help make this family angst unforgettable. Cinematographer André Turpin lenses with Ektachrome brilliance.
movie_title: C'est Pas Moi, Je le Jure! (It's Not Me, I Swear!) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Against considerable odds, Snyder has directed a movie that should satisfy fanboys while engaging adventurous newcomers.
The judicious use of humour makes the fear seem all the more real.
What truly galls is that Greenaway has the germ of a great movie here.
Do not go to this movie if you simply seek entertainment. If you're a sociologist tracking the decline of civilization over the past four decades, you're in for a night of solid research.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The film is so choppy, especially in the final going, it appears that entire reels have been cut.
Garrone's gloomy assessment of the new world order is painfully on target: corruption comes in many guises, and it's as impossible to stop as it is to track.
It's a one-joke pony, but director John Hamburg and his screenwriters manage to stretch it to nearly two hours of hilarity and quasi-profundity.
[Director Gilroy's] determined to put some smarts into the world of double crosses and double martinis, and bless him for that.
The boom-and-bust cycle that afflicts company towns in capitalist countries also dogs the state-run cogmakers, as Chinese auteur Jia Zhang-ke lyrically depicts in 24 City, an ode to changing times.
This film has hidden depths, especially for adults who mistakenly think Monsters vs. Aliens is only for kids.
Adams and Blunt rise above the clunky premise and execution to once again demonstrate why they've become the go-to girls for any director seeking smart, versatile and warm-blooded talent.
Adventureland is what you might call stealth comedy. The laughs are few but they sneak up on you and really deliver.
An alternately humorous and heartbreaking film.
It's time for these car fiends to slam the heap into 'park.' Diesel should use his ESP powers to find a better gig with a franchise that still has some gas -- such as maybe The Pacifier 2?
Among the film's many revelations is a cast of talented unknowns who stand to become much better known in years to come -- which makes the 'no name' title seem almost ironic.
Like its predecessor, Angels & Demons manages the miraculous feat of seeming to plod while racing at breakneck speed, the tempo set by Hans Zimmer's blusterous score.
Toback fashions a sharp doc out of a blunt object.
Phasers set on "stunning."
You've got to love a movie that so eagerly assassinates its leading man's cuddly image, and which also manages to blow a wicked kiss to Fatal Attraction.
The whole thing would collapse under the weight of its own pretensions were it not for the considerable acting prowess of Jackman and Schreiber, who know how to give good growl.
Think of Earth as being akin to a greatest-hits collection of a beloved rock band. The context is gone, but the reason for the renown remains.
A potentially great title-role performance by Benicio Del Toro, which won him the best actor award at Cannes, is buried beneath Soderbergh's stylistic tics and a defiant lack of dramatic tension.
[Director Nuri Bilge] Ceylan takes a step towards the mainstream with a fiercely executed drama that hopefully will expand the ranks of his admirers.

Sugar is a departure from movies of its kind in quietly observing that life is often a series of base hits rather than grand-slam homers. The film has few moments of high drama and the games played matter only in how they shape Soto's character.
17 Again makes Xeroxes look original.
Directed by Kevin Macdonald, it's a capable if convoluted 'B' movie about government corruption, with an 'A' cast furiously pounding the pavement and keyboard.
Gray guides his strong cast to a resolution that is both surprising and entirely realistic.
Relying on images more than words, it's a plea for humanity in times of insanity.

[Director] Hill evidently intends his film to be satirical. But satire requires intelligence to succeed. Observe and Report has a moronic sense of humour, trading in racism, sexism, profanity and violence at every predictable turn.
A movie about an improbable friendship set against the backdrop of urban and cultural decay, The Soloist strives for deep meaning and settles for gritty reality.
Writer/director Charles Martin Smith brings energy and wit to this British-Canadian co-production.
Perhaps there were insurmountable legal restrictions. But the movie still serves as a dandy primer for rediscovering a lot of great music.

'God's gonna trouble the water,' goes the chorus from the African-American spiritual that gives Trouble the Water its title, but no deity is to blame for the tide of bureaucratic bungling and inhumanity the movie reveals.
Like a good book with missing pages, The Reader seems stripped of essential meaning.
The only awe this movie inspires is realizing how well the original stands up, and how little we puny Earthlings have learned in the past 57 years.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: That this much drama can be wrung out of the Frost/Nixon conversations is no small achievement.
The film understandably and movingly centres itself on Penn's portrayal of a hedonist-turned-activist who discovered that in order to change his world, he had to find his voice.
At once sprawling and intimate, melodramatic and comic, magnificent and utterly bonkers, it bears entertaining witness to Luhrmann's love of old movies and his Down Under homeland.
You know a series is in trouble when it begins mocking its own premise. Frank's obsessive rules about who, what and how he transports stuff are ruthlessly violated.
Every element of Doubt is in perfect balance.
Debut writer/director Lance Hammer has rendered [Ballast] with something that can only be called radiant austerity.
Belief may be in question for much of the movie -- only for the perturbed pooch -- but fortunately, enjoyment is never a problem.
There isn't much plot between the action set pieces, and precious little character development beyond Craig's and Dench's continuing evolution.
Soul Men could have been so much more.
Synecdoche is fun to mull over, for a while.
It has everything Madagascar had three years ago, but also two things the original was woefully lacking: a good yarn and genuine yuks.
The exceptional Swedish vampire film Let the Right One In warms your heart as it chills your blood, and that's the most disturbing thing about it.
Twilight is the Diet Coke of vampire movies, but central to the film's success is that you believe in the love between Edward and Bella.
The kicks are more to the head and heart than to the body.
Some of it is funny. Much of it isn't. The committee-written plot seems tired and recycled.
A thoughtful work that continues the actor/director's remarkable late-career surge.
This is the fourth Imax underwater excursion, and the second in 3-D, and it may just be the best yet.
A film that squanders a golden opportunity to make money on the current economic meltdown.
The victories and insights gained in Wendy and Lucy are hard-won and small in stature, but they linger on the mind.
A few truly profound statements emerge from the swirling hormones.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This animated screen rendering of Neil Gaiman's masterful children's horror fantasy is so full of life and texture, it's almost gilding the lily to add the third dimension to it.
As with all of Mann's films, his enthusiasm is infectious. He comes to praise mushrooms, not to bury them, and long may his frying pan sizzle.
You will either be frustrated with its asymmetrical and manipulative storytelling or be captivated by scattered clues that ultimately lead to some kind of resolution.
You'll miss out on a good movie if you consider Taken just another January dumping.
It's surprisingly okay, in a January kind of way.

Director Gary Winick has long since abandoned his cool cred from Tadpole and 13 Going on 30 and given himself over to the dark side of making glossy amusements that are about as deep as staring into a snow globe.
Somehow the film fails to inspire more than admiration, never reaching the same heights of empathy achieved by less impeccable treatments of the same topic.
The Wrestler is suffused with sadness, yet also the wonder of a spirit that refuses to be snuffed out, and it's a lesson to us all.

A magical and moving account of a man living his life resoundingly in reverse, very loosely based on an F. Scott Fitzgerald short tale from 1922, it delivers top-notch moviemaking in every department.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: You should bring lots of Kleenex with you. It might just come in handy.

It's understandable and laudable that they desire not to sensationalize the Bielskis, and they've made a worthy film. But their understated approach makes the struggle seem less urgent than it must surely have been.
Buried deep within the psychedelic sludge that is Domino, there may be a story about a model turned bounty hunter. Good luck trying to find it.
Anyone who has ever longed for the good ol' days -- even the ones that weren't so good -- will find resonance in this well-told and well-acted parable of family and political unification.
The cheesy puns are as thick as rabbits in the bucolic England of inventor Wallace and his loyal mutt Gromit, and that's a gouda thing.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A very funny movie.
It's about keeping it funny, and on that score Undercover Brother is right on.
Apted and his crew pull out all the stops to craft a thriller out of material that looks better on paper than it does on film.
With Beijing Bicycle, Wang has crafted a picturesque morality tale that slyly depicts the hopelessness of communism while pointing up the essential similarities between people of all classes.
Neither the laughter nor the tears make a genuine emotional connection.
movie_title: Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Lillard gives the flick its manic energy, and the rest of the gang holds its own.
It's not much of anything, apart from eye candy.
An entertaining thriller that eschews most of the usual spy gimmicks in favour of old-fashioned sleuthing.
While it wonderfully confounds our narrative expectations as a coming-of-age story and a romantic drama, it works on another level as a great sporting experience.
A charming reminder of the combustible mix of puberty and authority in the lives of 14-year-olds.
movie_title: The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The look and sound of something a little different.

The predictable effort makes the movie seem longer than its audience-friendly 88 minutes, and the script deficiencies account for the high number of alien and human supporting players.
[Del Toro] finds real substance in shadows and whispers, in the terrors that reside at the back of the mind.
movie_title: The Devil's Backbone (El Espinazo del diablo) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Often messy and frustrating, but very pleasing at its best moments, it's very much like life itself.
The only camouflage Carvey should now be considering is a paper bag to wear over his head when he goes out into public, to avoid being recognized as the man who bilked unsuspecting moviegoers.

The continued good chemistry between Carmen and Juni is what keeps this slightly disappointing sequel going, with enough amusing banter -- blessedly curse-free -- to keep both kids and parents entertained.
movie_title: Spy Kids 2: The Island of Lost Dreams (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Disturbing yet engrossing.
What's missing, crucially, is the passion required to make this unlikely tale work.
No one who sees this movie will ever again take it for granted that photo shop employees couldn't care less about their pictures.
Winterbottom captures the spirit of the times, although the film's camera shakes and psychedelic colour bursts may make many viewers feel like reaching for Gravol rather than Ecstasy.
Pushes its thesis way past the breaking point of even the most gullible or charitable of viewers.
It's a more believable scenario for infidelity than most such movies, and Aniston gives her all to the role.
[Dunst] brings genuine humanity to a role that could have been little more than a vampish gold digger.

It is trashy good fun.

Hugely entertaining from start to finish, featuring a fall from grace that still leaves shockwaves, it will gratify anyone who has ever suspected Hollywood of being overrun by corrupt and hedonistic weasels.
movie_title: The Kid Stays in the Picture (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Sunshine State resembles Sayles' sketchbook more than his finished work, and we might hope that something more polished might spring from it.
Clint's aim may not be as straight as it once was, but it's still true.
Rather than 'a new breed of secret agent,' the makers of XXX have created a dumber version of Rambo, and I have just one question: YYY?
An important movie, a reminder of the power of film to move us and to make us examine our values.

Continually challenges perceptions of guilt and innocence, of good guys and bad, and asks us whether a noble end can justify evil means.
The picture should really have been titled Uncle, because that's what many men will feel like crying out after enduring this estrogen-fuelled freakout.
Absorbing character study by André Turpin.

Suffragette has the power to shock even those familiar with the early days of the feminist movement it dramatizes.
Like the ruthless political strategists the film both satirizes and celebrates, Our Brand Is Crisis speaks out of both sides of its mouth.

Hou's kinetic yet serene approach to martial arts is like watching a fast-moving river. It's less about the plot and body count and more about contemplating a story rich in symbols and multiple meanings.
The scattershot story doesn't fully serve this stellar cast, as the drama often flags. But when it connects, the tension is almost unbearable.
Nobody does the aggrieved party better than Blanchett, who could play the title tragedians in any smart recasting of King Lear or Hamlet.
The film falls prey to the zombie curse of excessive laddishness, but at least it finds room for a strong female character.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: What pulls together the story's many tentacles is the unflappable Craig, a less-is-more actor who has evolved his Bond from the "blunt instrument" of Casino Royale into the "good man" of Spectre.
It's a big, wet dog kiss of an animated family film, hitting all the expected notes of the Charles Schultz comic strip and TV specials that generations have loved.
A suspense-free script co-written by Gallo with Jason Lapeyre contributes to the feeling that we've seen all these cards before.
Trumbo is ... a blast, even if the screenplay perversely lacks the energy of its title character, who is played with great wit and brio by Breaking Bad's Bryan Cranston.
Abbott's feral depiction of such fierce loyalty is something close to brilliant.
It makes for a lively documentary subject for critic/director Kent Jones, despite a dearth of archival video and photos of the famous exchange.
Paul McGuigan directs, but apparently without a clue as to what kind of story he's trying to tell.
The Good Dinosaur is an enjoyable romp, especially when it surprisingly turns into a bizarro western midway through.
Guy Maddin's latest act of cinematic mayhem isn't easy to parse, but narrative coddling has never been his intent.
Brooklyn is a simple story affectingly told, bridging the emotional gulf one feels when ambition and home are an ocean apart and love is uncertain in either place.
What began so promisingly as a dystopian saga of gladiatorial games, resonating with current global fears, has turned into just another dull race for the almighty dollar.
For me the film's deeper intent is illustrating the ebb and flow of marriage and the need to not just accept that reality, but to embrace it.
It's a downward spiral that's painful to watch, more pathetic than funny.
It almost requires belief in magic - and high tolerance for hokum - to buy this whopper of an action picture. But here's where good acting builds empathy and defeats cynicism.
A tangled and pedestrian narrative gets in the way of the thrills, which are still considerable.
Cinematic satisfaction is denied in Love 3D, an exercise in bedroom boredom by France's Gaspar Noé.
Many of the things that made the original film work so well seem drained of power and emotion in the remake, and this includes Danny Moder's desultory cinematography.
Watching Tom Hardy nearly upstage himself in the gangster biopic Legend makes for mesmerizing viewing. It's also an object lesson in how great acting can transcend a film's limitations.
The over-the-top destruction that follows seems all out of proportion to the misdeed, but then logic isn't the purpose of a film like this.
It appears all involved had a grand ol' time making Pan, the latest and loopiest retelling of the story of Peter Pan. Too bad for the audience, though.

A story that yields its secrets slowly but sinuously, making the most of its language and cultural differences.
The fatal flaw is that it squanders more time fashioning these familiar Marvel Comics heroes than it does motivating them.
Worth watching, and rocking to.
This indie pulse-raiser is more of a stealth shocker than an overt one, even if the twisted payoff is telegraphed to anyone paying attention.
Almost a "found footage" movie, it makes excellent use of 1,500 archived 16 mm reels supplemented with fresh interviews and some animation.
While it's all too clear that Nolan is unhappy - he also has an ailing dad to care for - the thoughts inside his head remain stubbornly opaque.
This is like an Austin Powers movie directed by Wes Anderson, although Ritchie's personal style is very much in evidence.
Expect to feel uncomfortable watching Diary of a Teenage Girl, which is precisely the point of this finely etched debut feature by writer/director Marielle Heller.

movie_review_blurb: Mistress America is the kind of screwball comedy Ernst Lubitsch or Preston Sturges would have loved, and there's no finer praise than that.
American Ultra has its moments, but it's mostly a waste of good weed and better actors.
Who's human and who's not consumes much of the running time of rote actioner Hitman: Agent 47, which vainly attempts to revive a forgotten video-game spinoff starring Timothy Olyphant.
Zeroes in on the essential contradictions of the Apple co-founder.
movie_title: Steve Jobs: Man in the Machine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film is reminiscent of Catfish in its essential circumstances of love and online deception, but it goes far deeper into how virtual lies cause tangible problems.
movie_title: A Gay Girl in Damascus: The Amina Profile (2015)

movie_review_blurb: We Come as Friends aims a cinéma vérité lens on a place where many promises are made, but few are kept.
In terms of pure popcorn escapism, No Escape delivers from the get-go, cutting to the chase without belabouring the character details.
The cast is uniformly good, especially Efron and Bentley as collaborators on the dance floor but rivals in the bedroom.
Newcomer Jeremy Chabriel commands as 11-year-old Alexander, a chosen son whose dawning sense of right and wrong challenges the social order. An auspicious beginning, for him and Kleiman.
Douglas Tirola's loving doc captures the anarchic '70s college satire magazine that became a comic force.
movie_title: Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of the National Lampoon (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's one of the year's best movies and widescreen 3D experiences, a crackerjack adventure that celebrates human ingenuity over mechanical contrivance.
Somehow The Walk succeeds in spite of its immoderation, especially when the stunt is at hand - in 3D IMAX, no less - which is so often the way of Zemeckis movies.
Archived news reports and a Dick Cavett interview fit seamlessly into the dramatic recreations, as do era-specific rock tunes.
If only real life were like a Nancy Meyers movie.
Michael Shannon and Andrew Garfield make for an incendiary combo, as a predatory realtor and his desperate protégé.
Sicario paints the bleakest of portraits of a realistic situation, drawn from headlines about Mexican cartels that stack bodies with savage efficiency.
So imposing is the mountain, and so realistically rendered by Salvatore Totino's camera (plus CGI imaging), it threatens to dwarf any attempt to bring a human element to the tale.
A crime drama that creeps and drips blood like a horror movie, and in many respects it is.
Good old-fashioned journalism makes for great drama in Thomas McCarthy's [Spotlight].
Producer Luc Besson is determined to wring every last euro out of this concept, having also taken it to TV in recent years. The gas gauge is reading "empty."
The two actors carp and quip well together, enough to carry us through a plot with few surprises.
It's a movie that makes thoughtful drama out of the essential insanity of celebrity journalism, wherein a star proclaims humility while a scribbler promises idolatry.
Some of the horror tropes being played with here - Rosemary's Baby is a clear touchstone - are staying up way past their bedtime.
It ends up demystifying Dean, perhaps by accident but no less regrettably.
The fact we care at all about the outcome is a testament to the actors, and only the actors. But buried beneath the Christmas clutter is a much better movie.
Not just the best Canadian movie of 2015, but one of the year's best films, period.
Ghosts, dreams, regrets - they all mingle in this artful trance: "The most brilliant are those who are focused."
This first feature screen animation of The Little Prince is a pleasure to behold, but as with any journey the venture is not without risk.
His obsession with anal cavities and what goes in and comes out of them suggest Cohen is auditioning to be the after-dinner amusement at a proctologists' convention.
This is one movie that gets better as it goes along, even as it fails to fully hit the high bar of making us care about a very nasty individual.
The third and most useless chapter of the continuing sci-fi bloatfest called The Divergent Series.
Lavant engages, but he was so much better as the Chaplinesque troll of Holy Motors than the chatty nag here. Just another Côté puzzler, I guess.
Those who loved the original should at least like the sequel, which remarkably has reunited all of the players from the oversized cast.
If only the film actually had depth, along with a little levity to lighten the bulk in the script, the visual murk and the sonic overkill.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Bone-dry dystopian satire, with Lanthimos piling absurdity upon absurdity, results in a film that is by turns entertaining and baffling, but also fully in command of its crazy world.
With Kevin Costner narrating, Hock illuminates and entertains as he sketches portraits of the greats, from original fireballer Walter Johnson to the indomitable Nolan Ryan.

Richard Linklater's idea of a baseball movie is one where the first pitch isn't thrown until the 90-minute mark.
Hiddleston's uncanny musical performances, all filmed live, help redeem a movie that exhibits the flawed brilliance of its subject.
First-person POV quickly gets old as the bodies stack and the story loses steam.
The actors strike few sparks, even as combatants, but it's not entirely their fault.
movie_title: One More Time (When I Live My Life Over Again) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Earned tears and unexpected laughter combine for more satisfying impact. Gyllenhaal and Watts can wring empathy out of the oddest of circumstances.
Did you ever think only male comics could obsess over infantile boob, crotch and sex jokes? The Boss will set you straight on that delusion, too.
This scenario allows free rein for patented Key and Peele riffing on race, rap and drug stereotypes while also freestyling on pop-cult obsessions ...
Charlie Parker and John Coltrane get their due, of course, but other sax stars also testify to the sinfully great sound of this most wicked of instruments.
The scenario is airtight - faked archival footage is brilliant - but the story might have worked better as a thriller like Logan's Run or Children of Men.
Will lights and hardware be ready? Can they afford the $200K demanded by headliner Rihanna? The viewer's pulse may rise, too, as Rossi's camera roams frantic hallways, offices and limos.
Field and director Michael Showalter (who also co-writes, with Laura Terruso) find humanity within the humour.
Sing Street knows what it takes to form your own band, made by a guy who really loves music.

From its Hitchcock opening to its eye-popping ending, Dan Trachtenberg's feature debut keeps us wondering about what's really going on, even as we root for Mary Elizabeth Winstead's spunky entrapped protagonist.
Tom Hanks exerts such a gravitational force in his movies, sometimes to his detriment, it's fascinating to watch him struggle for equilibrium in Tom Tykwer's A Hologram for the King.
Stéphane Brizé's humanist drama tallies the slow drip of dignity in a downsized world.
movie_title: The Measure of a Man (La loi du marché) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Von Carolsfeld (Marion Bridge) finds strength and beauty in personal epiphanies of sorrow and joy.
Toronto's Director X, hot video maker for Drake ("Hotline Bling"), Rihanna ("Work") and many others, makes an auspicious feature directing debut.

Cheadle is the right man to play Davis, capturing him in all his madcap glory and fierce musicality. But a more experienced director - Spike Lee or Clint Eastwood, say - might have proven a steadier storyteller.
So much wasted talent. Downright Criminal, it is.
For all but the most timid of moviegoers, this live-action revival of The Jungle Book serves cherished memories, while offering much more than just the bare necessities of entertainment.
It serves as both a talent-squandering prequel and sequel to Snow White and the Huntsman, while doing nothing more than name-check Snow White.
Impressive production values but muddled impact.
movie_title: Mountains May Depart (Shan he gu ren) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Who says only Hollywood can turn out disaster movies?
It makes the 2013 original Olympus Has Fallen - loglined as "Die Hard in the White House" - seem in nostalgic comparison like quality entertainment and a model of logic and good taste.
Kevin Hart clowns, Ice Cube growls. Rinse and repeat.

13 Hours is a movie where the questions are asked first and the shooting happens later, the opposite of Bay's usual modus operandi. Bully for him and bravo for journalism, but it doesn't make for satisfying cinema.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Is it possible to be enthralled and depressed at the same time?
The Revenant seeps into the soul, like the coldest chill ever experienced.
Will Ferrell and Mark Wahlberg go together like candy and whiskey.
Director László Nemes films within a very claustrophobic and shallow-focused frame, bringing home the reality of the Nazi horror while also leaving much terror to the imagination.
Both actors deliver a master class in expression by understatement. The most unsettling of ghosts, we are moved to realize, are the ones we try hardest to deny.
Joy is a fun but untidy muddle, a mess that even the self-wringing mop of its central metaphor can't easily clean up.

The really neat feat of The Big Short is getting us to care about these dollar-hungry sharks and other erstwhile profiteers, and to laugh at their desperate dealings, even if we don't always understand what it is they're doing ...
The Force Awakens isn't just one the finest movies of 2015, it's the best movie of the year, full stop.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: There's real humanity here, and it may hit closer to home than you'd expect.
It stars Michael Fassbender as the murderous general of infamy and Marion Cotillard as his complicit wife. Two of the world's finest actors, they make a magnetic pair.
This whale tale doesn't blow, but it does sniffle a bit too much.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Haynes reminds us how bad things used to be. He also invites us to remember how beautiful mad love can be and to swoon along with it.

This just isn't the Tarantino of Pulp Fiction, Reservoir Dogs or even Inglourious Basterds, although any film that gives Samuel L. Jackson a chance to talk and glower at length is a film worth seeing.
At age 53, Tom Cruise is still a credible action hero. But this time, Rebecca Ferguson really gives him a run for his money, and his heart.
Dirty Grandpa does have one distinction. It makes De Niro's previous comedy low point Meet the Fockers look good by comparison.
Whit Stillman and Jane Austen are a match made in comedy rapture.

Ginnifer Goodwin and Jason Bateman lead an aces voice cast, playing good-cop bunny Judy Hopps and con-artist fox Nick Wilde, who must find common turf to solve a crime wave in the title metropolis. Call it fur noir.
[An] ungodly jumble of a mortals-versus-deities rumble, placed in the time before the pyramids were tourist attractions.
John Hillcoat packs a binge watch of characters and incidents into this corrupt-cop thriller.

[Moore has] made his most enjoyable film in years and also his most inspiring, the antidote to prevailing global doom and gloom.
It's intended primarily for an audience of Christian believers, but genuine drama precedes the preaching.

Gillespie (Million Dollar Arm) and his screenwriters laudably strive to keep true to the film's real-life account from 1952... But history often needs more than just the bare facts to make for a satisfying movie.
Apocalypse wow.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: You can go for the laughs or go for the chills with a high-concept horror like Nina Forever. You shouldn't muddle about the boring middle.
Like its title fool, Zoolander 2 wants desperately to be adored, despite coming hopelessly late to the party.
Reynolds' mighty mutant title character is anything but a conventional superdude, even before he acquires his extreme skills, red-hooded cosplay costume and scarred face and mind.

Despite the gloomy title and the subject's tragic demise, this valuable documentary of incendiary 1960s blues rocker Janis Joplin is actually more celebration than eulogy.

What Big Hero 6 lacks in originality, it makes up for in charm.

I laughed a lot at this movie, possibly even more than I did at the original film, which I enjoyed quite a bit.

A Depression-era potboiler starring Bradley Cooper and Jennifer Lawrence that never manages to get past the feeling of a calculated Hollywood reunion.

Rock is on a roll again.
A handsome and stirring film of Second World War ingenuity that also succeeds as cracking good entertainment.

Mann also used to have a much better feel for action, in movies like Heat, Collateral and Manhunter, than he exhibits here.

National Gallery presents the famous art space as almost a living and breathing thing, with all the complications and rough glory that implies.
Keen observer Mike Leigh brings his hawk's eye to a vibrant rendering of J.M.W. Turner, the celebrated British "painter of light."
Let the dust finally settle on these museum pieces.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: What looked like indulgent folly at the outset now seems closer to epic justification, as Peter Jackson's The Hobbit trilogy draws to a rousing close.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This certainly is one driven narrative. Wahlberg reportedly lost 60 lbs. for the role, and his gaunt look makes Jim seem all the more haunted as he repeatedly throws away vast sums on games of chance.
Andrey Zvyagintsev's Oscar-nominated and vodka-soaked satire of modern Russia, which plays more like tragedy.
Even a cool cat like Christopher Nolan can cough up a furball - and with his sci-fi adventure Interstellar, it's blockbuster-sized.
The emotional aftermath and battle of gender expectations threatens to be more devastating than any pounding of powder.
Gleeson is the great anchor of the piece, conveying much often without even saying a word.
This is what an earthbound Guardians of the Galaxy would be like if every character was Groot, the tree guy.
Let's earnestly hope there is no sequel.
Bat-dung crazy, in a good way, Lenny Abrahamson's Frank is the story of a pop star who really lets his art go to his head.
The funniest bits are when the mimicry and the insults converge.
It's a town of bad women and worse poets, where the fists are hard, the talk is tough but nothing is for real - and nothing doesn't add up to much.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The dialogue is believable and funny, even if strays a little too often into the grotesque eating and toilet habits of the late Elvis Presley.
This overlong adaptation of Gayle Forman's popular young adult novel manages to make the usually effervescent Moretz seem dull.
Director Charlie McDowell and screenwriter Justin Lader raise both smiles and pulses with their impressive feature debut, which never overplays its sneaky hand.

The Judge could have been just another courtroom procedural with extra family pathos, but it's got a third person with something to prove: director David Dobkin, who is better known for comedies such as Wedding Crashers and Fred Claus.
The Drop is steeped in a simmering underworld familiar to fans of late directors Sidney Lumet and Arthur Penn, and stripped of primary colours like their '70s cinema classics.
A large cast that looks great on paper becomes unwieldy on the screen, with talented people struggling to stay with a story and a camera that relentlessly skips from scene to scene.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An unforgettable portrait, set to a dazzling soundtrack of Chopin piano pieces, of the sense of loss we all feel when we are obliged to move into unfamiliar and uncomfortable surroundings.
Gives due credit to an inspired and prodigious maverick while also showing how often reckless good luck guided his peripatetic way.
We're given precious little story (or back story) from screenwriter Richard Wenk (The Expendables 2), but not much is needed for a tale this primal and an actor this watchable.
The Skeleton Twins is all the better for keeping us guessing as to its intentions, because that makes it more true to life. Sometimes you have to smile through the tears, and vice-versa.
David Fincher's Gone Girl takes a big beach read about a troubled marriage and turns it into a suspenseful screen indictment of modern times.
For his directing debut, Gilroy is out for the contact high of that Mean Streets vibe, and Gyllenhaal and Russo deliver it to him in spades.
This movie is so over the top, you can't track it on radar.
Quite simply, Whiplash is one of the year's best films.
You want to latch onto Birdman's scruffy neck and fly wherever it goes, even if it's too close to the sun.
Tu Dors Nicole accurately recreates that feeling of youth when the summer seemed like it would last forever. As the French say, it's très drôle.
A real treat for animation fans, although its meditative pace may test the patience of younger viewers.
movie_title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)

movie_review_blurb: David Cronenberg pans satiric gold from the muck of celebrity ills, in a Tinseltown where reality depends on your dosage.
Nothing can stop the wicked smoulder of Stevens, who makes a smile seem like a weapon of mass destruction.
The latest gaseous emission from the Sparks melodrama machine.
A movie with laughter, soul and a twisting path to the heart.

The Good Lie honestly earns its laughter and tears, even if it has to do so by way of some Hollywood window dressing.

[A] tight anti-thriller, one where the violence of the title is more implied than seen.
Watching Jupiter Ascending is like reading a menu of genre munchies at a drive-thru "B" movie burger stand.
Stunt man Nicholas Powell helms, his directing debut, showing little regard for characters or story.
Designed to daze and confuse, and succeeding, Ryan Gosling's directorial debut is a stunner in visual terms alone.
Wild West vengeance gets a terrific homage and a bloody reckoning in this oater excursion ...
The awfulness and futility of war are seared onto the screen, in images that are often hard to look at.
An entertaining package of characters and ideas that manages to be a whole lot more than the first film while also being a little bit less.
There is much pleasure in watching these fine actors navigate rough emotional waters, each conveying as much in sidewise glances as they do in direct discourse.

Varoom, varoom!

This prequel to the shriek hell, directed and scripted by series writer/actor Leigh Whannell, manages to avoid the Curse of the Triple Cash Grab.
[It] has to be seen to be believed.

Pigeon is a film designed to confound and provoke, sometimes to wearying effect. But it's riveting in its deadpan depictions of drained existence.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Jurassic World ... hits all the expected beats of heroism, action and dinosaur dining. The tourists are delicious, and there are so many more to snack on this time!
A tired exercise in existentialism that apes but doesn't improve upon the writer/director's better work.
Gorgeous cinematography balances impeccable acting and directing for a romantic trifle that delights with design more than content.

If the suggestive use of spray cream whips you into a froth, boy, do these lads have a movie for you.
