Fairly enjoyable and credit is due to its sterling cast, led by Anthony Hopkins as Heineken ...
The walls may be closing in on these people, but we are constantly aware of the vast environment outside, at once threatening and awe-inspiring.
With the darkest of humour, it graphically illustrates what happens when the stress of 21st century living causes regular citizens to "go postal."
There's no small pleasure in watching Dolan and Greenwood square off against each other ...
To quote one damning corporate memo seen in the film: "Doubt is our product."

The Duke of Burgundy is no mere style exercise or slavish homage. Strickland finds both humour and pathos in the situation of Cynthia and Evelyn, who are every bit as trapped as the insects they collect and catalogue.
We can't say we weren't warned. Will Smith has been telling us not to trust him the entire movie.

Long on nostalgia, the film does shed further light on the genius of Brian Wilson and the unfair uproar over the Monkees' need for musical backup. Turns out even the Beach Boys required the Wrecking Crew to rock.
An early candidate for worst sequel of 2015 and also worst movie.
A masterful and heartbreaking account of religion trumping humanity.
What We Do In the Shadows leaps to the top of the pack, by resolutely sticking to deadpan humour and absurd riffs on the awkwardness of being a vampire in a world made for humans.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Vainly seeking to reach the widest possible audience, the makers of this exercise in banality stripped it of almost anything that could cause offence.

We meet some interesting characters, including a bookie who takes bets on rain, and travel to fascinating destinations like "Place of the Clouds" at the base of the Himalaya Range, reportedly the world's rainiest spot.
While the concept is a cut above the usual Sandler swill, the comedy isn't. The script might as well have been penned by the same clueless aliens doing the invading.
The Hunting Ground's most unsettling finding is widespread institutional tolerance of campus rapists, because school administrators fear bad publicity and the loss of alumni cash endowments.
Scenes take on a surreal nightmare quality, sometimes with no accompanying sound, as even the camera seems dazed by what it is witnessing.
It's about all women, and the conflicting dual roles they are expected to play in life, more so than men: nurturer/fighter, mother/lover, submissive/dominant and so on.
It runs a long 128 minutes. You have to wade through not just puddles of tears, but also piles of BS.
A remarkably satisfying and entertaining action movie, one of the best in the series. Put your brain in neutral and enjoy the ride.
Morgan Freeman thunders and Clive Owen glowers, but there's little that can be done to save this muddled medieval adventure from itself.
It often looks like an accident in a film lab, although the sound is great, especially with guest vocalists Kelis, Gerard Way (My Chemical Romance) and Beth Ditto (The Gossip).

While We're Young pairs two New York couples, one middle-aged and anxious and the other millennial and carefree. Both are in for a satirical skewering, but also - and here's a change for Baumbach - something close to a hug.
Young Hadji's silence gives The Search what lasting power it possesses.
The Last Man on the Moon alternates between archival footage and current interviews, the latter tinged with nostalgia and regret. But Craig avoids either lionizing or reducing his subject.
movie_title: The Last Man On The Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Riot Club comes with the dubious ambition of instructing us as to the evil ways of spoiled British toffs, as if that were needed.
Hungarian director Kornél Mundruczó downplays White God as a "genre experiment," but his film has real bite regardless.
The movie seeks to make you laugh while also risking offense by going too far. It succeeds on both counts.

Insurgent has more action than last year's debut film, which was modestly titled just Divergent. Action is what you want in a picture such as this, especially when you don't really have a lot on your mind.
Whatever else we might think of Sean Penn's bid for an active middle age via The Gunman, we can't doubt his enthusiasm.
Another month, another Liam Neeson action movie.
It Follows manages to bend the rules of fateful juvenile sexuality, and does so in a manner that genuinely tingles the spine and disturbs the mind.
It must be said that it goes down rather well, although full enjoyment requires that all cynicism be left simmering on the back burner.
Viva offers few surprises, but it draws us into the sights and sensations of a fascinating city and the excitement of new talent.
Two sons and their father grapple with their dysfunctional family situation, resulting in some reflective, engaging drama.

Every few years, Michael Bay and his giant digital robots sally forth from their gilded dungeon to inflict damage on the world's brain cells. Transformers: The Last Knight is their most concerted assault yet, making me fear for the sanity of the planet.
It's gratifying to see a summer popcorn movie where a simple idea goes a long way.
Is there an American actor of more meaningful solitude than Sam Elliott?
Okja is a populist enviro-fable that's part pet-rescue drama, part mad farce, all Bong Joon Ho.
Her stories are great, especially the one about Dorfman gate-crashing Dylan's Rolling Thunder Revue in 1975. It would have been nice to hear more of them.
movie_title: The B-Side: Elsa Dorfman's Portrait Photography (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Summer can finally start now: Baby Driver is that blast of energy we've all been waiting for.
Hilarious and heartbreaking with no clear trajectory, frequently catching viewers off guard, it's a rom-com of both heart and brain about a couple tested by illness and clashing cultures.
Here's some Despicable Me math: third movie plus Gru times two plus one new supervillain = not much of anything.
The story is briskly told - it's 11 minutes shorter than Siegel's version - with good performances that alternately amuse, seduce and shock.
The movie's not flawless, but it is fun, a big improvement on the non-wowing The Amazing Spider-Man and its sequel of recent years.
Reeves and Bomback are determined to keep this extended prequel smart and the dialogue impressively lean, even as the story begins to wear as it stretches towards the 2 1/2-hour mark.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This blockbuster spectacle is an intense experience of pure cinema that far exceeds the standard "miracle at Dunkirk" narrative.
Besson ... stuffs us to the breaking point with this psychedelic space fantasy. I enjoyed the feast, too, although I found it more junk food pig-out than fine-dining experience.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A Ghost Story is the most unusual and loneliest phantasm saga ever to give you the shivers.
If the James Bond franchise people ever get creative and cast a female 007, Charlize Theron will have to be high on their list of possible candidates.
Rumble is truth you can rock to. Play it loud!
movie_title: RUMBLE: The Indians Who Rocked the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A dumb fantasy movie adapted from Stephen King's most derivative novel series.
So generic is this film, drawn from the vast pulp output of thriller scribbler Vince Flynn, it offers a glimpse into a dazzling future when robots begin making movies.
Aronofsky ratchets up the tension by degree, employing claustrophobic camerawork and a sound design that slowly turns from minimal to maximal.
It makes Mama Meyers' It's Complicated looks like Bergman's Scenes From a Marriage in comparison.
Moondi and his actors let Alex and Justin sketch their own stories, which are written in their faces and in the bad choices they habitually make.
Patti Cake$ isn't really a comedy; too much sadness and despair intrude to make it so. But it's a joy to watch Macdonald in action ...
The Hitman's Bodyguard is the cinematic equivalent of a guilty burger drive-thru meal when dinner is too wearisome to contemplate.
It really was a special moment.
It comes on like a Sundance comedy ... but it unfolds like a Hitchcock suspenser.
Soderbergh is in the mood for some fun, and so is a star-filled cast led by Channing Tatum, Adam Driver and Daniel Craig.
Good acting helps us overlook the story's obvious trajectory.
An auspicious directorial debut for writer/director Taylor Sheridan ...
An almost unbearably twee story about pursuing a dream.
There's more doom and gloom - but also hope for meaningful change - to be found in Al Gore's followup to his Oscar-blessed 2006 doc that sounded the alarm about global warming.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The injustice and anger behind it all feels like current reality, even a half-century on, making Detroit urgent viewing regardless of its character-development flaws.

Pattinson makes Connie one of the best roles of his career by turning a two-bit hood into a loyal family guy driven to help his brother. John Steinbeck would recognize these characters. So would Martin Scorsese, who is thanked in the credits.
The bloom is definitely off the brick. The anarchic spirit and spitball humour of The Lego Movie and The Lego Batman Movie have been replaced by characters and gags from a faulty assembly line.
As obvious as the movie's intent and execution are, it gnaws at the conscience thanks to the brilliance of the lead performances.
Rough Night has many narrative bumps, but what smooths them is the great chemistry of the five women caught in the central dilemma.
Bill Condon's enchanting live-action adaptation of Disney's Beauty and the Beast is designed to make believers of skeptics - even those who think the 1991 animated version can't be topped.
There's something reassuring about how little Sick Boy, Begbie, Spud and Renton have learned about life in the past two decades.
This would be grist for the mills of filmmakers seeking strong drama or dark comedy, but Kore-eda sagely follows a different path.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Weirdos is one of Bruce McDonald's sweetest films.
Too bad the shipwreck of a screenplay can't keep up with the visuals, which are pretty great ...
Clowes turned ink into flesh and blood for his 2001 screenwriting debut Ghost World. He seems to have lost the knack.
Casting saves the movie, notwithstanding the thorny issue of cultural appropriation.
An "A" cast takes on a "B" production in Going in Style, and pulls off the real heist of this unnecessary but amusing comedy remake.
Terrence Malick's latest film isn't so much a movie as it is a freeform collection of whispers and beseeching looks.
A more useful subtitle for this fans-only doc would be Everything Before Eraserhead, the surreal 1977 horror movie that launched David Lynch's feature film career and eventual critical acclaim.
I predict they'll be eventually leaving skid marks on the moon, as long as their varooms are answered by box-office ka-chings.
Scherfig sets so many plates spinning in this Second World War romantic drama, part of the film's great appeal is wondering if they'll come crashing down.
Expressive acting by Hawkins and Hawke smooths out narrative bumps, creating a portrait of a woman in thrall to art and nature and a couple whose love resisted hardship and defied definition.
Holy guacamole! Fast Times at Ridgemont High collides with The Poseidon Adventure in graphic novelist Dash Shaw's exuberant animated mash-up.
movie_title: My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its usefulness as a 21st Century public service announcement, what Unforgettable can't really do is scare, educate or entertain anybody, since it blandly misses both extremes of the thriller genre.
It's a sci-fi/horror/psychodrama/comedy/thriller /revenge/romance film - and that jumble of a description not only works, it does so in spectacular fashion.
The Lost City of Z eschews multiplex formulae in favour of the jungle of the mind, a much more fertile place to explore.
Cox makes an impressive Churchill, an imposing man of physique and intellect who, closing in on 70, has been laid low by age and circumstance.
Did our hero even bother to read the script for this toxic CGI dump site?
Aussie co-directors Martin Butler and Bentley Dean prize authenticity over conventional drama.
It's ... insistent that life is a series of complex decisions, with fate intruding, and the path's never clear.
We can overlook how the third act yields to the blows-up-good formula of blockbuster franchises. For now, let's just celebrate a superhero movie that runs on estrogen rather than testosterone.
A story like this can't get by on terror alone. It also needs good actors to put it across, and Alien: Convenant more than delivers on that score.
Cars 3 happily gets back to where it belongs, not just to home turf Radiator Springs (for a brief spell) but also to the storytelling essentials of making us care about anthropomorphic automobiles.
Oi! What's Guy Ritchie gone and done with King Arfur, then?
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The movie earns a few chuckles, but humour is largely held hostage by a lewd and lazy screenplay that wanders like Billy in The Family Circus.
Like a visit from amusing friends who stay a bit longer than expected, it's easy to forgive the indulgence.
When these four fine actors remain seated, arguing morality and family grievances, the tension commands attention.
A film of empathy, grace and wit that goes a long way to explaining the populist anger so emblematic of these times.

Ably assisted by Marillier - and Ella Rumpf as Justine's controlling sis - Ducournau captures the more quotidian dread of fitting into cliques, losing your virginity and living up to family expectations.
Gere ... deserves to be remembered at awards time.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A movie that's not just very good, but also trés bien.
Even if you've Googled the outcome, or are old enough to remember watching it on television, the film's reenactment of the battle and the bluster makes for entertaining and at times riveting viewing.
Has there ever been a face more suited to male anxiety than Ben Stiller's?
Jake Gyllenhaal's portrayal of the painful and frightening struggle to recover and get his life back feels jarringly real.
The Shape of Water makes the deepest dive into romance this year of any movie - literally, figuratively and on both sides of the camera.

Oldman brings a wicked wit and compassionate heart to the role, one for which he seems almost superhumanly suited for - and that's really saying something, consider how many great actors have played Churchill.
Everything strains to serve an underwritten story that resembles a community theatre stage production more than a major motion picture.
The Finnish auteur's compassion and absurd wit [are] once again abundantly evident.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The two lead actors, along with Toronto writer/director Daniel Warth and co-writer Miles Barstead, make a virtue out the film's unsteady tone.

The Last Jedi boasts many very good performances, ones that enrich the characters and which salute writer/director Johnson's ability to find the humanity within technology, something he proved early on with his artful time-travel thriller Looper.
One of the year's most romantic movies, and also one of the best.
It's surprisingly OK, largely due to the likability factor of the four leads.
Plummer elevates the film in his last-minute but fully realized performance as J. Paul Getty.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The movie version of a card player who doesn't know how to quit when she's ahead.
Robbie delivers a performance that is breathtaking to behold, almost to the point of exhaustion.
It's a great watch.
Day-Lewis has hinted that his role in Phantom Thread will be his last for the screen. I seriously doubt this, just as I am sure he will work once again with Paul Thomas Anderson.
Neeson is the rare actor who can made something as dumb as this reasonably diverting, at least until you run out of patience with the increasingly arcane plot.
If you think the title is anything but a grim joke, you don't know Haneke.
It asks questions about grief and justice that resonate with these perilous times, all the more so in light of recent terror atrocities the world over.
Here's the real crime: Who shot the editor?
The screenplay is credited to four writers, director John Luessenhop among them, and they've all been busy cutting-and-pasting from other movies.
Roth and Carnahan do an OK job updating Death Wish, combining the horror elements (and torture porn) that is Roth's stock in trade with the gallows humour that is Carnahan's.
Red Sparrow is a brutal, muddled and dispiriting watch, but it may inadvertently be one of the more accurate screen depictions of the messy world of espionage. This is not a recommendation.
The setup is almost too twee for words, but Rice burnishes acting skills that were already gleaming after The Beguiled and The Nice Guys. And kudos to the inclusivity and diversity of the casting ...
Zvyagintsev and his sterling cast expertly paint the portrait of a family too blinded by selfish desires to see the pain they are causing others.
It's storytelling that feels like a stalking.
The old alchemist's trick of turning lead into gold has nothing on The Disaster Artist, a film that masters the trickier feat of transforming trash into art.
It's hard not to be impressed by what filmmakers Brian McClave and Tom Wichelow have achieved with their patient and watchful study of a Sussex walled garden.
movie_title: A Year in an English Garden: Flicker & Pulse (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Spettacolo serves as a hymn to the creative process, but also as a eulogy of sorts to the let's-put-on-a-show spirit of pre-digital times. Come for the drama, stay for the gorgeous scenery.
At its core, A Fantastic Woman is the story of genuine love, something requires no definition.
With The 15:17 to Paris, Eastwood once again tells an American story with a narrow-minded efficiency that somehow makes reality seem fake.
Rarely has a superhero origin story been as satisfying as Black Panther, which in many ways doesn't feel like a typical Marvel movie - and more power to that.
The screen romance of Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool may seem as odd as the real-life pairing was, but it's a credit to all concerned that the validity of it is never in doubt.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Bale and Pike find a strange kind of peace within their characters, intuiting how tough it would be to live in a world where death is easier to contemplate than life.
As always, Park is delightfully absurd with his stop-motion tomfoolery, although the story by Mark Burton and James Higginson only occasionally reaches the heights of Aardman films past.

Suck It Up is true to life in how it shows two different personalities struggling to engage with each other. It's well acted, but as so often happens with Canadian films, the landscape is the greater part of the story.
It's so well put together, it's hard to believe this is Wong's first feature.

Director Dagg and sibling screenwriters Benjamin and Paul China ratchet up the tension. So does the eerie score by another set of siblings, Will and Brooke Blair, who previously teamed for the horror thriller Green Room.
Hall's direction and script are efficient and to the point. The actors all acquit themselves well, but always with a grim sense of reality that the film seeks to really drive home.
At a long two hours, the film gets as repetitive as the tide.
movie_title: Take Every Wave: The Life of Laird Hamilton (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Such abundant talent, yet what we get on the screen is like a snow cone made with horse urine.
Essential viewing, even if you have to watch through your fingers.
A valuable and heartfelt document ...
movie_title: BPM (Beats Per Minute) (120 battements par minute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The furtive figure history knows best as Watergate snitch Deep Throat gets a movie treatment more suited to the printed page than the big screen.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I'm inclined to give Suburbicon a mild thumbs up.
Alexis Zabe's rapturous cinematography reminds us that magic is where you find it. You don't need a golden ticket to Mickey's kingdom, although you can see it from here.
It's diverting stuff, for the most part.
Blade Runner 2049 is one of the brainiest films to come out of Hollywood in a long while, asking more questions about the meaning of life than it answers.
Just when it seems it may be time to close the book on Tom Cruise's acting career, something comes along to suggest new chapters are possible.
A film of solid craftsmanship led by another royally magnificent performance by Judi Dench.
Trophy presents the very definition of making a deal with the devil.
Hittman demonstrates a sure hand throughout, marking her as a filmmaker whose future work will be hotly anticipated.
What's a five-letter word meaning "great performance"?
Using archival and recent footage, Jacquet tracks the work of pioneering polar scientist Claude Lorius, a climate change verifier whose astounding discoveries should silence all deniers.
movie_title: Antarctica: Ice & Sky (La glace et le ciel) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [A] delightful, artful road trip ...
The success last year of Bad Moms made a sequel as inevitable as Christmas overindulgence. The combination of the two may lead to indigestion.
A surprisingly fresh movie about a story we all know very well.
Every step of the way in Coco is a visual and sonic delight.
Washington turns this seemingly unsympathetic character into a figure to embrace on the screen and to remember at awards time - the actor once again courts serious consideration at the Oscars.
Bow-tied brainiac Bill Nye gets a sympathetic treatment from admiring filmmakers in this non-shocking doc.

McDonagh knows how to get good characters into a story but not always how to get them out of it. This time he's considerably more focused, letting McDormand's ferocious mother-bear of a performance, her best since Fargo, drive the narrative.
The film is marginally better than last year's sour and dispiriting Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice, but that's like saying that dental surgery is preferable to passing a kidney stone.
Haynes struggles to connect all the dots. Wonderstruck reaches for the stars and falls short.
Sean Anders, the returning director and co-writer (with Brian Burns and John Morris), runs out of gas at the halfway mark.
The delightful and insightful Lady Bird achieves flight in its own unique way, just like the aerodynamically unorthodox ladybug the title tips to.
Kenneth Branagh's remake of Murder on the Orient Express is billed as a motion picture. But it might better be thought of as a two-hour moving selfie of the director, who is also the lead star.
Leo's impassioned acting makes a supporting role seem like a leading one.
Performances are solid all round, but the standout is Irish actor Keoghan. Shy and lonely one moment, utterly blood-chilling the next, he's a mesmerizing presence on this screen of menace.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's laugh-out-loud funny and occasionally just plain silly. But it asks a serious question that seems more urgent with every passing day: "How much inhumanity does it take before we access your humanity?"
Thor: Ragnarok is more fun than a barrel of winged monkeys, but man, do we have questions.
It seeks not to excuse Dahmer but rather to illuminate his sociopathy.
This lazily directed and sloppily written heist non-thriller unspools like one of those amusement park distractions where tourists play at being in a movie.
By the time MacLaine's character Harriet shows real humanity, all sympathy for her character's loneliness has long since vanished.
This is a real Kong show, the one demanded by popcorn peddlers and munchers alike.

"I'm kind of half-bored, half-fascinated," Eisenberg tells his bro over the long-distance line, and the sentiment could also apply to the movie - although Storaro's sumptuous cinematography makes even its mundane moments enchanting.
"The Film They Don't Want You to See" sales pitch will now draw more eyeballs than this disingenuous screed deserves.

The story gets a tad too busy at times, but visually Phantom Boy is delightful, cloaked in the same imagination as director Jean-Loup Felicioli's and Alain Gagnol's previous Oscar-nominated animation, A Cat in Paris.
The experience of Jason Bourne may ironically work best for those who are able to put past chapters out of their mind and just thrill to the movement on the screen.
[A] strange embrace of a movie, which continues to tantalize even as it overstimulates.
The antagonists all make persuasive arguments. Sachs, co-writing with Mauricio Zacharias, is careful not to demonize the families or trivialize their sentiments.
Schamus gets the suffocating look of 1951 American academia just right, with its sweaters and skirts, and with a rose motif worthy of Citizen Kane. What's missing is any real drama or purpose.
It looks like Pixar, but plays like Monty Python.
The film is humanist rather than overtly feminist, since it shows the high personal cost of trading conscience for filthy lucre. But it's certainly novel to have a financial drama led by women.
Herzog regards the online world with a mixture of wonder, humour and horror, observing that the ingenuity of people to build machines is outdone only by their capacity to misuse them.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [A] drama that watches what happens when adolescence ignores the calendar.
Enjoyable summer entertainment for grown-ups and anyone else seeking refuge from superheroes.
Hell or High Water isn't just a great time at the movies, it's one of the year's best pictures.

This drama of how a "little monster" struggles to find a place within society has a few strong scenes, and a hint of potential stardom for Paradot, whose character Malony rages for humanity as well as himself.
This is a movie where every jump scare is worthy of a shriek.
Fabulous scenery, dopey cops, hapless hoods, furious spouses and a Froot Loops-loving kid round out a picture that gives new meaning to "icing" someone.
What power the film possesses is due mainly to the expressive performances of Fassbender and Vikander, who sweep away the murk more than any lighthouse ever could.
The Birth of a Nation is a film for alert minds, even those that can't - and shouldn't - forget the past and present behaviour of its maker.
It's perfectly nutty and perfectly dull, like St. Vincent on Quaaludes.
It seems unnervingly accurate for anxious times.
That's one small step for Apollo 11 hoaxers, one giant leap for Matt Johnson.
Berg - with major assists from his camera and special effects crew - demonstrates once again that he knows his way around an action scene. He can tell a big story and sell a lot of popcorn.
Hess and his three scripters rely more on the improv skills of an impressive cast than on anything resembling jokes or a credible story.
With a delicate palette and soft tones, the craftsmanship on display is impeccable, but the pulse-free drama - think crying over spilled milk - makes for muted impact.
Havana Moon delivers almost a full Stones concert in grand sound and image, made more special by its historic circumstances. Imagine what Fidel made of "Sympathy for the Devil"!
Bridget Jones's Baby is a bit of all right, as Shakespeare might have said.
Joseph Gordon-Levitt sympathetically portrays the bespectacled title cipher, a Rubik's Cube champ with an IBM brain.
Wingard and Barrett aren't trying to reinvent the wail here, which is mostly a good thing.

What Fuqua's Magnificent Seven lacks in originality it makes up for in personality, with his Training Day and The Equalizer compadre Denzel Washington earning his oats as an ensemble leader in his first western.
Clint Eastwood is simply the ideal director for a big-screen telling of the "Miracle on the Hudson" hero pilot story that Sully delivers with confidence and grace.
Potentially great chemistry and good performances are largely wasted in this gimmicky rom-com, in which Jean Dujardin plays a four-foot-five Romeo seeking to woo a regular-sized woman.
movie_title: Up for Love (Un homme à la hauteur) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There's much to cheer about a movie with such a diverse cast of talent both familiar and new, set in a land that all too often is depicted on screen as a place of war and hopelessness.
It's a story of amour fou, which Maslany and DeHaan portray with affecting realism - notwithstanding the presence of a bear that speaks with the voice of legendary Canuck actor Gordon Pinsent.
Director Roger Ross Williams' storytelling skills are at their finest in an engaging story suffused throughout with emotion that never descends into mawkishness.
Hovering spirits of Ghostbusters past prove more treat than trick for Paul Feig's energetic reboot of the storied 1980s comedy franchise.
Civil War reminds us it's OK to enjoy a few laughs, even while diabolical villains plot doom, outraged citizens demand accountability and your best pal mistrusts you.
Action may seem slow in coming, but interest never flags and Winocour doesn't flinch from necessary violence. Hollywood awaits her, if she's interested.
Talent is squandered by writer/director Scafaria's penchant for shallow contrivance over emotional depth.
It recognizes the inchoate anger of people who suddenly realize they've been duped by a fast-talking hustler who promised gold but delivered dirt.
Complicated lives get tough yet compassionate treatment in Dheepan.
Visually ravishing and sexually provocative, Neon Bull offers an unforgettable portrait of a changing Brazil, at once earthy and arty.
A commanding lead performance by Agyness Deyn as Chris, a farm woman tested by extraordinary circumstances, overrides most concerns. "The land endures," the narrator says, and so does Chris, vividly.
It's about social anxiety, with Lalonde and his strong ensemble cast smartly illustrating the tyranny of expectations, in and out of the bedroom.
movie_title: How to Plan an Orgy in a Small Town (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It maintains an almost unbearable tension throughout its 95-minute running time, as an A-list cast of French actors tear into each other over long-simmering family conflicts, the camera just inches from their faces.
movie_title: It's Only the End of the World (Juste la fin du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Shorn of much of the whimsy and wordplay that made Carroll's Alice tales immortal and Tim Burton's Alice in Wonderland a treat, this belated revisiting fractures the narrative and tries the patience.
Lolo happily takes the rom-com road less travelled, the one marked "Danger."
The most droll of male-bonding comedies, as viewed through the astringent lens of Greece's Athina Rachel Tsangari.
This painfully unfunny dysfunctional family comedy is like an acid flashback to a bad 1970s tax-credit CanCon picture.
The comedy is in the performances, not the scattershot storytelling.
Ultimately the movie seems more focused on setting up sequels than exploring the abundant source material.

Johnson and Hart actually do have potential as a comic duo - better than Ice Cube and Hart in the already stale Ride Along franchise - but Central Intelligence isn't smart enough to make the most of their pairing.
Finding Dory may be more of a minnow than a whale of a tale for Pixar, but it's still a good catch.
Well-groomed characters carry the day.
Sic transit gloria mundi for the beleaguered title pooch of Todd Solondz's latest societal eyeballing, which leashes a dog's life to human absurdity.
An astounding chronicle of hubris.
It's impossible not to get caught up in it, even if you're simultaneously repelled by it.
The film follows the expected path toward Spielbergian contentment for young and old alike.
It's possible, even likely, that more effort was expended on sculpting Alexander Skarsgard's abs for The Legend of Tarzan than on providing good reason why the movie was made.
Viggo Mortensen is truly in his element in Captain Fantastic, in every conceivable way.
A Civil War rebellion becomes an enervating movie by Gary Ross.

Refn is hardly the first moviemaker to find a link between supermodels and scary monsters, but he may be the most style-minded one to make the connection. Imagine an issue of Vogue with Maleficent as guest editor.
The film is so cluttered with characters, exposition and space junk, thickly lacquered with 3D, it's like a party piñata waiting to burst open - but inside are rocks, not toys.
The Shallows pushes the buttons it's supposed to push for a summerthriller, even if the outcome is as deflating as it dumb.
This well-rounded doc rigorously probes, shames and - wonder of wonder - inspires.
Firth and Law falter with their characters' awkward bromance: the former a fatherly cipher (will he ever take off that fedora?); the latter a clatter of drunken scribe clichés.
He could go on for days with his war stories, and the doc makes you wish he would.
This New Zealand doc tickles the funny bone but also chills the spine. It delves into a goofy fetish that leads down serious and unsettling paths.
Awaiting the verdict makes for a real nail-biter, even knowing the outcome. Denial does a stellar job demonstrating the truth is worth fighting for.
Sanga creatively employs a swirl of text messages, voice-overs, baseball signals and other linguistic modes to beautifully illustrate the jumble of thoughts cascading through young minds.
Some books just can't make the leap from page-turning read to big-screen attraction.
The year's worst movie.
A perfectly enjoyable romantic adventure, featuring two of the world's most charismatic stars.
Themes of loss, regret and alienation emerge and are respectfully considered, with fine acting but not always the conviction one would expect from both Almodóvar and his characters.
People say the movie musical is dead. Tell that that to your tapping toes while watching the enchantment of La La Land, one of the year's best films.
If Fences barely escapes the confines of its titular enclosure, the performances all sound to the skies like Gabriel's trumpet.
Taraji P. Henson, Octavia Spencer and Janelle Monáe serve both history and the demands of popular entertainment with serious performances that also have a good sense of humour.

The actors are steeped in the drama and mysticism of the moment, especially Garfield's stoic Rodrigues, who emerges as the central figure and also narrator of this journey into the unknown, both the physical and metaphysical.

Did the real story all go down like this, and does it matter? The answers are "not exactly" and "probably not," since Patriots Day is meant as an ode to teamwork, civic pride and doing what a man's gotta do.
Bening's characters are always as comfortable as Dorothea's abode; we never see or feel the exertion behind the acting.
Intensely involving ...

Affleck falls prey to the occupational hazard of wanting to create his own myth, as he produces, directs, writes and stars in a flaccid screen adaptation of Dennis Lehane's Prohibition-era crime novel.
What's the real story? Kastner gets as close to it as probably anyone could.

If there's a lesson to be learned from The Founder, it's that self-inflating guys like Ray Kroc - and Donald Trump by extension - have always been with us, working every angle while promising to make America great.
Wholly original, yet informed by legends of both the East and West, it invites us to contemplate humanity's connections to the natural world and the realm of the spirit.
Despite a nearly three-hour running time that feels at times like a miniseries, Ade's script is that unique conundrum: an art house comedy with a deft pace and finely tuned emotional intelligence.
Gold is more of a bronze.

Tighter editing might have made this a great movie, rather than just a good one. The material is there. But They Call Us Monsters nevertheless helps us better understand the eternal conundrum of family-loving teens who turn into violent threats ...
Assayas confronts shallow materialism with intense spiritualism, conjuring real chills in an artful take on horror.
A fine actress, Deutch makes a compelling and empathetic protagonist, even as the story veers closer into the supernatural.
Logan is kind of a special superhero movie, in a good way, and if Jackman holds to his stated intention to make it his Wolverine swan song, he's going out not with a whimper but a bang.
Oyelowo and Pike make for a convincing couple, even if the romance is the love-at-first-sight variety that requires a certain leap of faith.
When the blood starts flowing, along with audience cheering, the battle for hearts and minds is well and truly on.

Shamelessly, but also quite movingly, hits all the required notes of the most pandering of feel-good Tinseltown sagas, with its story of a grouchy guy who turns out to have a heart of gold and a past worth sighing over.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Cameraperson summons us to really think about a world that is more connected than we may realize.
A first of its kind in a male-dominated genre, these four short films are signed, sealed and delivered as a form of empowerment.
First-time director Chris McKay, late of the Cartoon Network's Robot Chicken, throws at the screen seemingly everything his committee of screenwriters scripted.
The first film, now seeming so much better in hindsight, had more kinks and even a few laughs. What few yuks there are in Fifty Shades Darker are due mainly to the risible dialogue.
Jarmusch, who made supernatural vampires seem human in Only Lovers Left Alive, now finds inspiration in the mundane.
Far too much effort is expended on larding in ridiculous elements and characters that send the story in all directions, none of them involving brain cells or any real sense of dread.
Using handheld camera and a minimum of dialogue and music, Farhadi turns the mundane into the momentous.
A career nadir for director Taylor Hackford.
High concept meets lowest common denominator comedy in Fist Fight, a schoolhouse farce that has nothing to teach about entertaining the masses.
Much more than a mere sideshow in the Star Wars saga, these rebels build on a brilliant legacy.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Rarely does a film plotting the Internet amount to much more than a series of glowing screens. Lion, a fact-based story and auspicious feature debut by Garth Davis, makes for a captivating exception.

What emerges is more serious docudrama: a fully rendered vision of a woman ill-served by most previous accounts, featuring an Oscar-worthy lead performance by Portman. It's also one of the year's best movies.
It's something to watch and to feel good about, in this most negative of election years.
Hacksaw Ridge is old-fashioned moviemaking of the kind Gibson excels at: where men are men, women are women and champions rise to smite villains in gory combat.
Cumberbatch wears that Strange cape well.
Morlando draws great performances out of his two young leads.
It just needs to be watched and embraced, as an entirely fresh example of the power that great movies can exert on our lives.

Kinky by design, artful by intent, the film draws visual inspiration from Gothic erotic art while distilling its screenplay - Chung Seo-kyung and Park share co-script - from the Sarah Waters Victorian crime novel Fingersmith.
Palast's dogged detective work is solid and shocking in its revelations, but he blunts his lance somewhat by hamming it up as a fedora-wearing noir sleuth.
movie_title: The Best Democracy Money Can Buy (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Unusual, bittersweet - and vital.
Sure, he's eventually going to punch out and/or kill whoever dares cross him. But does he have to be so darned grumpy about it?
The actors capably hit their marks but rarely illuminate the interior torment of Roth's prose. The direction and cinematography are similarly workmanlike but unremarkable.
It ... frees the story from the musty confines of newsreel footage.
More than the sum of its shaky-cam parts.
It turns a probing and revelatory lens on the soul-destroying task of chasing eyeballs with sensationalistic news, long before clickbait became a journalistic mission.
Affleck makes passivity magnetic as he negotiates ever-shifting situations and dispatches foes with a ruthlessness James Bond would applaud.
Once again directed by the reliable Ron Howard, it's by far the worst of this less-than-stellar trio.
The tragic cliché of the heroic hockey enforcer is explored with art and impact in this powerful feature debut by Vancouver writer/director Kevan Funk.
A brainy and funny look at the creation and still-evolving legacy of a rock 'n' roll band Jarmusch considers the greatest of all time, even if RollingStone and snobby critics won't admit it.
The epiphanies go down like eggnog, along with the smooth R'n'B and jazz on the soundtrack.

A tiny bit of invention and a few good laughs emerge. Which is what you'd hope from a cast featuring some of the funniest actors around, among them Kate McKinnon, Jason Bateman, Jennifer Aniston, Rob Corddry, T.J. Miller and Jillian Bell.
This is Chastain's movie, as the title implies. She's never less than riveting ...
Huppert brings immense fortitude and dignity to the role of Nathalie, but pity is never an option.
One of the year's best pictures.
Moana is a movie of natural delights.

Evocatively lensed but clumsily staged, this is a movie at war with itself, although it's not until Beatty shows up as eccentric billionaire Hughes, about 30 minutes in and shrouded in half-light, that the battle is apparent.
[Villenueve has] a keen appreciation of film's ability to get at hidden truths.
Pitt and Cotillard aren't convincing as a couple, although she tries harder than he does. They're lost amidst the sandstorms and plane crashes that Zemeckis is so good at conjuring.
Equal parts sexploitation drama, social satire and empowerment fantasy, Elle leaves us unsure of what we're watching and how we should respond.
Adapting his screenplay from Austin Wright's 1993 novel Tony and Susan, Ford interweaves influences and style obsessions with an exactitude bordering on malevolence.
Ang Lee's heart may be in the right place with his Iraq War thumb-sucker Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk, but his head is somewhere in the clouds.

Fantastic Beasts offers a good intro to Potter-iffic times ahead, some of them suitably creepy (note the parental guidance rating) as the dark wizard Gellert Grindelwald threatens to bring his evil doings across the Pond from Europe.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The election of climate change denier Donald Trump to the U.S. presidency underscores the urgency of this doc linking global warming to other crises.
Writer/director Jeff Nichols serves history faithfully, if at times with too much deference, in a handsomely mounted dramatic recalling of a landmark U.S. legal battle.
The world needs another boxing movie like a palooka needs another hit to the head. But it can always use a good story - and Bleed for This certainly qualifies as such.
Not much of an effort is made to differentiate the personalities of the turtles, who all frankly look as grotesque as a Terry Gilliam cartoon.
There's no small irony in a Frank Zappa doc being built around the man's interviews, since he regarded journalism as a form of torture.
movie_title: Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The characters are great and the movie is often very funny.
Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close approaches what I would call "9/11 porn" in the way it exploits tragedy to milk emotion.
Here it is just the first week of January, and already we have a strong candidate for the worst movie of 2012.
Streep gets under the skin of one of the 20th century's most dynamic and also most contained personalities.
Cronenberg has reached the stage of his career where he doesn't feel it necessary to pander to expectations. Instead he seeks to engage us, and he succeeds.
A poignant documentary that tracks the fast rise and slow fall of the Hansard-Irglova fairy tale, through both tunes and tears.
Haywire is really just a vehicle for Carano to demonstrate her action chops, which she does with a vengeance, set to David Holmes' buoyant and badass score.
When Red Tails literally flies, as it often does, it soars. There are more grand aerial battles here than in any of Lucas's space operas.
Rashomon-like in its perceptual complexities, truth vs. belief, Asghar Farhadi's drama forces us to constantly shift our assessments and allegiances.

Beckinsale's Selene is back with a vengeance, that famous black catsuit and two fully cocked pistols, having wisely sat out the wretched third installment of the franchise. Don't expect much more than this.
It's a tapestry of fraught relationships, weaving issues of parental authority, social taboos and national boundaries. Empathy comes through understanding, but it's not easily achieved. It never is.
You won't find two finer performances in recent times than those by Mullan and Colman, who in a perfect world would each have received Oscar nominations this week.

As stripped of colour as its title, apart from the red of flowing blood and burning eyes, The Grey urges contemplation on man as the human animal, one suddenly cast into the wilderness where real beasts dwell.
Nobody should be this hard up for entertainment.
To compare this mess to a sitcom would be an insult to sitcoms.
What begins as something akin to Robert Wise's The Haunting becomes something more like James Wan's recent Insidious, which makes The Woman in Black a multi-generational horror.
Naranjo is unflinching in his determination not to serve up mindless entertainment.
It is a whale of a comic tale, if also one overly crowded with characters and incidents.
Shallow performances, script and direction mute the laughs and the insights in a movie that ultimately doesn't have much to say.
It looks as if Disney simply borrowed and recycled the sets of Prince of Persia and Gladiator, adding leftover props from The Phantom Menace and Cowboys and Aliens.

It wouldn't work without the exceptional work of Olsen. Her uneasily captivating performance here could almost be viewed as the "why" prequel to Martha Marcy May Marlene, the other chiller from Sundance 2011 that established her as rising star to watch.
The parent and homeowner in me were appalled by the debauchery and incredible property damage. The teenage boy in me couldn't help but smirk anyway.
Looks at a Ukrainian family of one single mom and a huge brood of children and finds that love grows exponentially.
movie_title: Family Portrait In Black And White (2012)

movie_review_blurb: For the most part admirably chooses honest documentation over emotional manipulation.
If anyone thought Steven Spielberg couldn't top himself for manipulating audience emotions, they didn't reckon with War Horse.
This painstaking but gorgeously realized police procedural by Nuri Bilge Ceylan, the Turkish poet of the long take, nods to Sergio Leone's Once Upon a Time in the West.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This isn't your average out-of-control character, and Harrelson has to work against a narrowly defined screenplay that is short on specifics.
It takes hockey hooliganism to heights not seen since Slap Shot was offending the nation's finger-waggers back in the 1970s.
In Darkness presents a credible scenario about the effects of desperate times upon the human psyche, and it also shows how base human instinct can nevertheless be elevated.
Washington's Tobin is a pedantic cipher and Reynolds' Weston a dull Dudley Do-Right, and the resulting mix, apart from a few good chases, is bland enough to bottle for Gerber's.
There's no equivocating ... over the excellence of the acting by Swinton and casting find Ezra Miller
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: As yet another found-footage film, Chronicle makes a good argument against further use of this tired conceit.
Doppelgänger Paul is a comedy about modern alienation and loneliness, but also the peculiar vagaries of modern male bonding.
It's audacious, given the huge resistance of Americans to subtitled films. It's also a good idea. If only it were funnier.
Carnage is a comedy of claustrophobia and revealed truths, and Polanski knows both all too well.
A movie of chain smokers and whisperers, of grey skies and glum expressions, of rattling tea cups and rotary-dialed telephones.
Shortcomings aside, The Ides of March does provide an impressive showcase for fine actors to explore eternal truths about trust, loyalty and accountability.
A sobering but not hopeless look at how the Windy City is attempting to turn around a rising tide of street shooting, through the work of a unique group called CeaseFire.
It simply aims to keep us on the proverbial seat edge, and it mostly succeeds, even if Gajdusek's twist-filled script has more turnovers than a closely fought football game.
We never doubt the sincerity of the emotions on display, or of the foretaste Circumstance provides of a society on the brink of radical change.
None of the changes improves on the original Footloose, even though the two young leads are both professional dancers - didn't the budget allow for anything more than raft swinging and barn hoofing?
All of these featherheads - both the avian and human kind - are lovable. Even better, they're funny, in a comedy that doesn't have to swoop to conquer.
The really chilling thing is how believable it is.
From out of the gloom comes the hypnotic grooves of a band called Staff Benda Bilili. The name means "look beyond appearances," and the members of this remarkable musical collective do just that.
At least he's being honest: Johnny English Reborn makes no attempt to hide Atkinson's shameless thievery, his lack of invention or even his graying hair.
The very existence of this film illustrates barrel-scraping desperation of the Hollywood kind.
Series creator Oren Peli and his conscripts have managed to do it again, but you have to wonder how far they can continue to push this found-footage angle.
Olsen's unlined face is like the unbroken water of a deep lake, reflecting both innocence and guile as she maintains a marvelous and inscrutable presence.

Anonymous is so dubious in its intent and so tangled in its execution, it might have worked better as a comedy like Notting Hill or The Boat That Rocked, where Ifans could agreeably play the fool as before.
The film has more twists than a bull's neck and mucho polish (Alberto Iglesias's jazzy score also enchants), but it's more freaky than frightful, a "B" picture by an "A" director.

Writer/director Robinson is anything but disciplined... and he's more inclined to just turn the camera on and let Depp do his thing. Which Depp does very well, but as talented and watchable as he is, even he can't completely save the picture.
An exceeding droll comedy from Finnish master Aki Kaurismaki, whose dark worldview is balanced by a deep empathy for his blue-collar characters.
Like a fine old single malt, the story and performances have acquired greater richness and depth...

The real mission is to renew a stale franchise, and here Ghost Protocol largely succeeds, on the strength of good action scenes - including an IMAX-enhanced Dubai skyscraper dangle by Cruise - and the good humour of a well-chosen cast.
As good as Theron and Oswalt are, and they're very good, Young Adult doesn't give them enough room to breathe.
Eros snores.

Herzog is pursuing no agenda with Into the Abyss, despite his opposition to extreme judicial measures. He's seeking to answer the question of why people kill, especially in a situation such as this where the reason for the murders was so meaningless.
The wisdom of Shame is that it offers no easy exit for this prison of the mind.
Curtis occasionally takes his characters out of Pinewood, but they're never really set free, either in physical or emotional terms.
In the incendiary performance by Rooney Mara, one of the year's best, you have all the incentive you need to drag out the Dragon Tattoo gun yet again.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Movie magic hangs in the air of Martin Scorsese's Hugo, much like the steam and dust that fills almost every frame.
Melodrama reigns in this supernatural soap opera, even though author Stephanie Meyer's tale takes a decided turn toward the weird and violent.
This is stealth comedy, richly delivered, and the rising Oscar buzz around it is deserved.
Von Trier remains a potent writer/director and master manipulator of images and moods.
It's a realistic take on what happens when high-flying money speculators suddenly hit ground. It's also a great calling card for J.C. Chandor, the writer/director making his feature debut.
DiCaprio wrings truth out of a cipher. The Hoover of both headline and whispers comes into sharp relief in this Oscar-beckoning performance.
Another thing Ratner is good at is not wasting our time when he runs out of ideas. But he leaves us smiling, if not believing our own eyes.
Café de flore leaves you wrestling with your emotions, not sure of how to react.

Tatum and Hill steamroller any misgivings right from the start. They take a comedy connection that seemed doomed to fail - pairing Tatum's hunky command with Hill's nerdy neediness - and make it look like the most natural thing in the world.
Heads downward in every sense of the word.
Like many of the 400-odd movies Roger Corman has produced and/or directed, Corman's World: Exploits of a Hollywood Rebel has a title that sizzles over content that merely simmers.
movie_title: Corman's World: Exploits Of A Hollywood Rebel (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The Island President is an important portrait of a determined man standing fast in a place where the ground is literally shifting beneath his feet.
The visuals in Randall Cole's paranoia chiller 388 Arletta Avenue evoke Michael Haneke's Caché and Alfred Hitchcock's Rear Window in the way they make domesticity seem terrifying.
We are never sure if what we are seeing is actually happening, including the nature scenes that Pawlikowski interjects as contrast to the urban jungle - and also as a symbol of man's animal nature.
It's a movie where you're never quite sure where the fiction ends and reality intrudes, but it feels all the more honest for the confusion.
movie_title: I Am A Good Person/i Am A Bad Person (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Unusual for Pixar, Brave follows an entirely predictable trajectory, but it's not without its amusements.
ALPS is a real mind trip with strong acting, and it leaves you to wonder what Lanthimos and Filippou will do next.
Magic Mike may carry a big shtick, but it speaks softly in unexpected ways.
People Like Us is neither funny enough for comedy or serious enough for real drama.
Ted's real trick is turning a one-joke premise into a reasonable facsimile of a movie, and one that isn't entirely bent on grossing us out.
As awful as Abe is, you can't help rooting for him as he struggles to get his life in order, all while his vivid fantasy world seems to be closing in on him.
As the incredibly awkward title suggests, Tyler Perry's Madea's Witness Protection is less a movie than it is an exercise in product branding.
The Amazing Spider-Man is at least better than Raimi's Spider-Man 3, which was a mess.
The best thing that can said about the picture is that it's a pleasant time-waster that also doubles as a travelogue for anyone interested in visiting Italy.
How did this film end up with such a muddled story?
It's as if you're looking out at new land you've never seen before, or an old one you haven't really paid attention to.
What really matters is the interplay between two fine actors, the icy Donovan and the fiery Morse.
This Knight not only rises, it also cuts deep -- not just as spectacular entertainment but also as harrowing drama.
Luckily, the good outweighs the bad in this bright 'n' breezy comedy about competitive a cappella singing groups.
It's a head flip of a time trip.
Trouble with the Curve is one of those easy-going old-time movies that they say studios don't make anymore. They still do on occasion, but you need a guy like Clint Eastwood to pull them off.
The story just doesn't have the heft that its 161-minute running time implies. It's about an hour longer than the story requires, even for one that spans decades.
After so many films, not just Ayer's, where LAPD cops are depicted as corrupt, homicidal or suicidal, it's refreshing to see one where the boys in blue really are the good guys for a change.
Likely Oscar nominees both, Phoenix and Hoffman command the giant screen so completely it's hard to imagine anyone pulling it away from them.
How can you hate a film that promotes its guitar-pick-thin story with the surprisingly honest advertising tagline, "Nothin' But a Good Time"?
What do we learn? That it's bad to steal the work and identify of other people. For this we need an oh-so-serious movie?
Sit back and enjoy it as a summer jolt of pure adrenaline.
And If We All Lived Together? is just fine as it is.
They all take turns playing the clown - and for the most part, it's fun to watch them at it, even if the body count is distressingly high.
It's routine stuff as horror setups go, especially if you've seen such obvious influences as The Orphanage and The Others.
Submitted for your approval: one Sixto Rodriguez, a Mexican-American singer/songwriter whom Rod Serling would surely embrace, in or out of the Twilight Zone.
Gilroy's a fine writer - he also penned Michael Clayton - but without the discipline of an action veteran like Greengrass to rein him in, he indulges his weakness to over-explain things.
All slicked up but mostly firing blanks, John Hillcoat's Prohibition-era western Lawless looks and sounds great but fails to tell a compelling story.
Quote not available.
High School sucks harder than it blows.
Stripped to its visceral essentials, the franchise is meant to frighten us and gross us out, and Prometheus rises to that modest challenge.

In seeking to make frothy entertainment out of the growing pains of an orphaned baby chimp named Oscar, with an insipid story and almost mocking narration by Tim Allen, it runs counter to its professed scientific intentions.
You can't fault it as smart entertainment, which eschews parody to make a sincere tribute that also serves as cogent current commentary.
The Three Stooges is moronic, stupid, idiotic entertainment for knuckleheads.
To say that TheCabin in the Woods isn't your average horror movie is like observing that King Kong isn't your average ape.
Count me - and hopefully you - amongst Keyhole's grateful dead.
Webdultery not only doesn't break new ground with its exploration of digital infidelity; it at times threatens to stray into You've Got Mail territory.

Fortunately, Damsels has an abundance of the erudite zingers that Stillman excels at writing, and that make his elegantly staged works seem like period pieces, even though they're set in modern times.
American Reunion, remarkably, might just be the funniest issue yet from the American Pie franchise factory.

The letdown factor has been most keenly felt in conversions from 2D, but Titanic 3D shows how the ambition can be realized if the will and skill are there. We can only hope that other filmmakers follow Cameron's example.
Worthington remains a distinctly humourless hero, which makes you long for the likes of a prime-time Harrison Ford or Arnold Schwarzenegger, who knew how to make a fondue out of cheese.
A heartbreaking Albanian film that counts the toll a family feud takes on all involved.
Writer/director Joseph Cedar is wise to the comedy of frustration and alert to the tragedy of hubris.
It's a surge of adrenaline that connects a strong protagonist and story to martial arts moves - traditional Indonesian silat - that are well beyond business as usual.
[It] arrives in theatres ... not only intact, but in command of the essentials of storytelling and characterization. The film deserves the massive success it will surely enjoy.
Hirsch's documentary truly shocks by the two sets of outrageous bureaucrats it exposes: one cowers on-screen, and the other hides in the offices of the MPAA, America's movie censor.
While Will and Libby struggle to adjust their thinking caps, the viewer already knows, thanks to the tell-all trailer, the reason for much of the confusion.
The script ultimately resorts to just counting off comic beats as it creaks through its unfathomable two-hour running time.
It's not just laziness - although it's a fair cop - that prompts the observation that Safe is both the worst movie title and attitude for Jason Statham at this stage of his career.
Always the star of his movies, even when he shouldn't be, the atheist Moretti gets caught up in his own papal bull. But Piccoli's blessed empathy prevails.
You don't have to completely buy into the premise of The Intouchables to appreciate the very good acting by Cluzet and Sy.

What we can't argue is that Cosmopolis is the work of a master filmmaker, one who is determined to have us think about the ideas packed into the trunk of this limo bound for the furthest corners of the psyche.
It wants to show us the man behind the famous dreads, beatific smile and durable songs of love, hope and longing. In this task it succeeds admirably.

What to Expect When You're Expecting is pretty much what you'd expect. It plays to its target audience with a vengeance, and that audience would be people expecting kids or who can remember their own pre-parenthood jitters.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A literate, knowing and sweet-hearted reverie about adolescence, that strange gap between childhood and adulthood. It's beautifully rendered by a filmmaker very much in touch with his inner rebel kid.
It's a lot to squeeze into 86 minutes, and Spurlock pulls it all together with infectious brio, making us realize that geeks are people, too, who maybe just dream harder than the rest of us.
movie_title: Comic-Con: Episode IV - A Fan's Hope (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Stumbles blindly along with Barnabas for most of its overlong 113 minutes, leaving viewers in the dark as to its intentions.

That's some good acting by Hennie, but it's also good writing by co-scribes Lars Gudmestad and Ulf Ryberg. They freshen up familiar caper and thriller tropes, adapting the bestselling prose Norwegian crime writer Jo Nesbo.
A saga guaranteed to pass muster with the Comic-Con cognoscenti, without forsaking regular popcorn munchers who just hope to see the planet get saved with maximum firepower and a few laughs.
Quote not available.
Neither good enough to impress as a meta mashup of horror and comedy, nor bad enough to hoot and throw popcorn at, it slides into a gray area of unfocused ideas and unrealized potential.

If Edgar Allen Poe were alive today, working as a Hollywood screenwriter (God forbid), I suspect he'd be penning not the abysmal script for The Raven but something called The Fall of the House of Cusack.

Engagement gets the most important thing right, which is the lead casting: Segel and Blunt are completely convincing as Tom and Violet, star-crossed lovers. They really do care for each other, but life seems to be conspiring against them.
Sound of My Voice grounds its science fiction in scarily effective "what ifs" that don't require a light year's stretch of the imagination.
The first thing to be kidnapped is logic, as the action moves to Istanbul from Paris and Liam Neeson ridiculously reprises his role of avenging ex-CIA dad Bryan Mills.
[A] pleasant timewaster, which has a good cast but a not-so-good script.
Filmmaker Jon Foy sets it to a thriller's pace, even contributing his own fateful score.
movie_title: Resurrect Dead: The Mystery of the Toynbee Tiles (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A film by the painstaking James L. Brooks that is so eager to ask the question about true love, it doesn't have time to mess with boring punctuation.
A perceptive and sympathetic film by John Cameron Mitchell that looks at grief by way of selfish reasonableness.
You may not physically experience the punches that rain upon Mark Wahlberg's dogged pro boxer "Irish" Micky Ward, but it feels as if you do.

In choosing not to reinvent the wagon wheel with True Grit, the Coens ironically seem radical by being conformists. There's truth and beauty in their faithfulness, though, and a reminder never to presume too much about these sibling ciphers.
There is being a good sport and there is career suicide, and De Niro is skating perilously close to the edge.
One of the most successful adaptations yet of a Richler novel. And with Guy Dufaux's sun-dappled lensing, it's also one of the most beautiful.
Quote not available.
In visual terms, it's a whiz-bang marvel of swooping and soaring camera work and psychedelic imagery, lit by the gaudy fluorescence of Tokyo's seamier nightclubs.
Did either Cage or Sena even bother reading Bragi F. Schut's patchwork script, before adjusting the wig, flicking on the camera and cashing the pay cheques?
The film proceeds in what feels like real time, but with no obvious beginning or end. It's a latticework of moments happy and sad.
It's the singular achievement of Sofia Coppola's affecting new film that she manages to make us care for a dissolute movie star, his angry ex-wife and their indulged daughter.
The many tunes in Country Strong are of such astounding banality, it's as if they were written by caged chimps as they were driven through Nashville on the way to a medical research lab.
A too-clever-by-half attempt to both satirize and celebrate the superhero genre.
Another Year, a terrific new Mike Leigh movie, assesses that moment in every thinking person's life when the question "what now?" exceeds physical survival.

Nostalgia for the Light isn't didactic in the strictest sense. It simply shows the truth, illuminated by [Patricio Guzman]'s poetic voiceover narration and the found sound of wind and footsteps that echo across the desert plains.
