The drama is deadly but the volcano's a blast, making Pompeii something less than the complete disaster you might expect.
McDonald isn't seeking to make explosive drama about a human time bomb, preferring to show the many mood swings of real life.
Not quite a comedy and not quite a drama, this Chilean film looks at middle age from a refreshingly even-handed perspective, not a wacky or tragic one.
The best kind of blockbuster comic-book movie, tweaking the brain while dazzling the eye.
Despite the best efforts of Morris, the man comes across as not only shallow, but as a completely empty vessel. It makes for repetitive and depressing viewing.
Most of Under the Skin operates on an almost subconscious level. The truth is out there in Glazer's screenplay, which he co-wrote with Walter Campbell, but it's intuitive rather than didactic.
A tough rural drama by David Gordon Green that digs deep in all the right ways.
This latest blockbuster assault wins us over, or wears us down, by dint of fine actors who are clearly enjoying themselves, in a film that thankfully doesn't take itself too seriously.
The quality of mercy isn't just strained in The Railway Man, it's measured out by the teaspoonful.
The only clichés missing to complete the set are the funny gay friend and the meddling mom, but the studio is probably saving them for The Other Woman 2.
Not much is said, but much is communicated in a blood-soaked film that acts as its own accuser.
We get an idea of what could have been via the colossal illustrated screenplay still lovingly held by Jodorowsky, who is every bit the dreamer in his 80s that he was in his youth.
You've got to take your toque off to a dumb movie that is clever enough to try to rook Ottawa politicians into doing the right thing for the wrong reason.
movie_title: Trailer Park Boys: Don't Legalize It (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Includes some genuine chemistry between Depp and Hall, which puts heart and soul into this machine.
Not destined for Costner's personal hall of fame.
By opening the action up to the entire city for the sequel, there's less claustrophobia but also less excitement.
It's a short, gentle film but a powerful one, a reminder that we can get past any sorrow.
movie_title: The Lady In Number 6: Music Saved My Life (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Dom Hemingway is mainly a one-man show. But it's a hoot to watch Jude Law sink his teeth into such a despicable character ...
Cinematographer Yaron Scharf shoots Bethlehem like a modern western, every grimace, twitch and drop of sweat playing in stark relief against an implacable landscape that has seen much spilled blood.
Meetings With a Young Poet is like an absurd literary cage match where only one of the fighters is participating. The other just sits there looking stunned.

Believe the Oscar buzz. Britain's Steve McQueen (Hunger, Shame) nails the horror of America's slavery shame but also finds humanity in one man's determination to free himself and return to his family.
This is smart dumb comedy, with the main story working an idea that audiences anywhere can get: the fear of change.
Our Nixon shows that while the stooges were good at scheming (up until Watergate, at least) they sucked as filmmakers.
Les Misérables sings so desperately for its Oscar supper, it makes you want to scoop it up in your arms like Jean Valjean cradling the wretched Fantine.
An effort is made to provide some character definition for Leatherface, which is probably a mistake. He's much scarier as a cipher.
The actors do their best, but they're bringing their "A" game to a decidedly "B" production, with Penn being the most enthusiastic of this game crew.
Chastain makes Maya as vivid as a bloodshot eye. Her porcelain skin, delicate features and feminine attire belie the steel within.
The hilarity is muted by the really excessive amount of violence. People don't just die in The Last Stand, they explode like blood bombs.
The film is a handsomely photographed and competently cast work that does justice to Kerouac's concept of "the purity of the road." Yet there's still something maddeningly lacking about it.
It gives Baker his musical props while at the same time demonstrating the film's title is no exaggeration.
Apichatpong resists control and eschews close-ups, maintaining as always a Zen-like approach to his material.

It's not very often you can blame a bad movie on a secondary character. Jennifer Lopez earns that dubious distinction in Parker, dragging down what would otherwise be just another generic Jason Statham actioner.
The camera hovers expectantly across shattered landscapes; the sound hints of menace. Krivina is as much a film of the mind as of the eye.
The film isn't funny enough for comedy or scary enough for horror, and the anachronisms are ludicrous.
Your laugh mileage may vary (God forbid), but we can all agree on one thing: this is the biggest waste of talent in cinema history.

Even if you don't know what [Grohl's] talking about when he says a room gives "great decay," or when somebody else extols "24-track sensibility," the passion of this project really pops right out of the groove.
It's just fun to watch Pacino, Walken and Arkin work together, very much enjoying the shared experience. Seeing Stand Up Guys is an offer you could easily refuse, but hey, why fight it?
Stereotype collides with cliché in Cockneys vs. Zombies, but the impact isn't as painful as you might imagine.
A lighthearted documentary by Canada's Simon Ennis that examines just how intently some Earthlings fixate upon that glowing grey gem in the night sky.
Side Effects is a cracking thriller that ranks amongst Soderbergh's best, featuring electric performances by Rooney Mara, Jude Law, Catherine Zeta-Jones and Channing Tatum.
A sea of poignant pictures and muttered observations.
The cautionary adage about weaving tangled webs in the process of deception certainly applies to Dead Man Down, an overwrought thriller brought to ground by its own contrivances.
You could easily see this playing as part of a double bill with The Wizard of Oz, even if the effects in Raimi's film often look cheesier than the ones in its 74-year-old predecessor.
A monolith crumbles in The Gatekeepers, and it's a sight to inspire awe.
Smart casting redeems the film.
The film plays like a Brian De Palma homage to Hitchcock - albeit one loaded with Park's symbol-laden visuals.

Tarantino is clearly having a grand ol' time with Django Unchained, and so are his actors, every one of whom are more than willing to share in the writer/director's filmic vision, no matter how ghastly it may be.
Tower is the rare film that leaves us wanting more of the story.
It's Oliver Twist by way of City of God.
A sci-fi chuckler that somehow manages to elude tedium, despite being a revisionist rip of rival 'toons, from Pixar on down.
Perhaps the best thing that can be said about the film is that it adequately depicts the narcissism of its star ...
movie_title: A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Willis and Courtney make a strong match, believable both as fractious family members and also as sarcastic adversaries forced by circumstances to work together.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: If only we could hope that Beautiful Creatures would stick to a single film or a maximum of one sequel, before its modest charms wear out.
A film remarkably true to life's haphazard rhythms.
Williams, Bernthal and Pepper ride to the rescue of the marquee talent, and also to Snitch.

More than ever in this seventh edition, the Up people seem to be fulfilling Henry David Thoreau's observation that "most men lead lives of quiet desperation and go to the grave with the song still in them."
No worse and maybe a little better than most of the vigilante movies that clutter the multiplex.
The movie frequently shifts from comic to dramatic and back again, true to Apatow's whiplash style but also true to life.
There's little happening here except slavish imitation and embarrassing hackwork.
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Too bad the story sags, although the padding is a riot.
There's a lot of talk of "miracles" and "acts of God" in Flight, but it's completely human deeds that make this movie soar.
Only true devotees of the game are likely to recognize many of the figures on the screen, or care about a byzantine story stitched together from innumerable horror and fantasy shows.
Cloud Atlas creates awe about worlds seen and unseen, frequently bypassing the brain on the way to the heart and soul.
It's all faint-by-numbers this time, without even a cool device like the low-tech fan cam from PA3 to interest us or really scare us.

Morgen and his editors do more than just provide a potted history. The fast cuts, which remind me of Arthur Lipsett's avant-garde NFB work, give the feeling of the whirlwind popularity of the band's early years.
Tyler Perry finds it easier to step out of Madea's dress than into Morgan Freeman's shoes in the thriller Alex Cross, a trite attempt at franchise building.
Provides the farewell that fans had been hoping for since Led Zep loyally disbanded following Bonham's death.
More stupid than scary, Sinister can't even figure out who its real demon is.
There's an undeniable "ick" factor to this film that overwhelms the justifiable cougar angle. Even worse is the boredom that soon sets in.
The film is a whopper of a tale, one designed for Oscar nominations, Best Picture and Best Director among them.
Wallace is heard but not seen in the film, a decision by Toronto director Angad Singh Bhalla that serves art more than it does the story.
Sarah Polley's brave quest to uncover her family's deepest secrets unfolds like a thriller, one where the resolution is literally part of her DNA.
The Paperboy bears some promise as a good-bad movie, but it unfolds as a bad-bad one.
Similar to the slow-creep style of Dogtooth director Giorgos Lanthimos, the narrative unfolds with escalating tension, the cause of which is heard and felt but not always seen.
The 23rd official Bond seems as fresh as the first, incorporating tradition with innovation in gratifying ways.
Lincoln serves history better than it does the multiplex, and that's a brave and worthy thing in a time of slippery truths and splintered attention spans.
The film is worthy of both your attention and of the Tolkien legendarium in which Jackson, his actors and his Weta Workshop technical crew are so firmly situated.
Funny how a film that explodes our conventional notions about time should be so up-to-date with the news.
Playing for Keeps doesn't play with a full deck.
Look closely at how Côté approaches those metal bars - you're never quite sure what will pop into view and who the real prisoners are.
This is a deeply cynical movie, with not much to say but a lot to feel.
The very picture of noble failure, it's a bright red heart without a beat.
Extreme choices and attitudes confronting women in India are laid bare in Nisha Pahuja's quietly shocking film, the Best Canadian Feature winner at Hot Docs 2012.
Hitchcock is a stab in the dark. The film gets the suspense part of Alfred Hitchcock right, but for the wrong reasons.
Claudio Miranda's luminous camera, set to Mychael Danna's intoxicating score, captures all manner of wild delights.
You'll perhaps need a little patience to fully appreciate Rise of the Guardians, which is likely to grow in stature over time.
Silver Linings Playbook isn't perfect - the ending is untidy - but it may just be the year's best comedy.
This is the most exhilarating cinema ride of 2012, a marvellously mobile mystery trip.
It's a very naughty tome, with many dangling bits.
movie_title: A Liar's Autobiography - The Untrue Story of Monty Python's Graham Chapman (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Breaking Dawn - Part 2, the fifth and concluding chapter of the young vampire romance franchise, manages to find a pulse as it profitably clicks the turnstiles one last time.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: More of a buffet spread than a single plate. But every morsel is worth a taste.
There's barely a wasted moment in the film, which runs a brisk 76 minutes and contains no female roles.

Roger Michell's brightly lit film turns America's 32nd president from world statesman into naughty codger, quite the fall from grace for the man who led his country through the Great Depression and the Second World War.
No amount of smoke and mirrors can hide the burst seams, frayed wires and bad-hearted humour of The Incredible Burt Wonderstone.
The casting is impeccable, beginning with Cavill as an uncommonly brooding but refreshingly deep Superman. The script doesn't give him much to say, but it doesn't need to.
The whole movie seems in many ways like a fortunate accident. But there's no doubting the deliberate wisdom of making a star of Pitt's talent and stature the lead.
Everything's okay. Good, even. Pixar has nobody to blame but itself for making us expect more.
It has nothing to say about kids who had nothing better to do than to thieve from the rich and famous.
It's as real as a blast of saltwater to the face, and the film's moments of human self-doubt are as fascinating as the superhuman antics on view.
White House Down has exactly what you'd expect from [Emmerich] and from the genre, only louder and dumber.
The cookie-cutter plot might have worked if the jokes were good.

It presents a terrifying reality -- the future is now! -- where all of the things we consider to be personal and private in our lives are easily accessible to anyone anywhere with a few clicks of a keyboard
The beguiling basics are still there, including the goofy gadgets and sly references to other films.
Who, exactly, was this bipolar oater made for?
An airborne trifle that passes for Pedro Almodóvar's new film.

You know all those doo-doo-doos and whoa-whoas-whoas you hear in pop hits? Without them, supplied by the likes of Darlene Love and Merry Clayton, you likely wouldn't be singing along to the songs you hear on your car radio.
The film certainly gives the band its due, but it will likely appeal more to Big Star cultists, ones eager for minutia about recording and business deals.
movie_title: Big Star: Nothing Can Hurt Me (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Even if you smirk at the plot conceit of mind-linked humans inside skyscraping robots fighting blockbuster sea beasts, the technical prowess on display can't help but impress.
It's possibly the least glamorous and also least interesting role Gosling has ever had. It's not likely to expand his fan base much, or Refn's for that matter.
This is a horror film where a pair of suddenly clapping hands gives you the heebie-jeebies, and Wan doesn't cheat with his jump scares.
Presenting itself as a sort of found-footage movie for geeks, this amusing and thoughtful oddity by writer-director-editor Andrew Bujalski is upfront in form but more stealth in content and intent.
Closed Circuit will engage you from the explosive opening frames. It may also leave a deep impression about the limits of personal freedom in a society where electronic eyes are everywhere.

Ip Man's story has been told many times before by other filmmakers. Wong builds upon it, establishing the noble fighter as a reflective but still ferocious grandmaster in 1936 in Foshan, Ip Man's home city in southern China.
The only real benefit of Getaway is pointing out the likely winners of the next Razzie Award for Worst Screen Couple. Come on down, Hawke and Gomez, you certainly deserve it.
Satisfies the expectations of Midnight Madness gore hounds - and then it happily goes about exceeding those expectations.
Edited together into a non-linear and virtually wordless whole, it creates a briny immersive effect that is almost hallucinatory.
This movie isn't just smart, it's also wise.
You may have trouble at times deciding whether to laugh out loud or to avert your horrified gaze.
This feature debut by writer/director Lake Bell, who also takes the lead role, finds a bastion of previously unexplored male chauvinism that makes for grand mirth.
The film covers a lot of ground with many players, sometimes risking collapse, but it never lets us forget the quest for wholeness at the heart of the story.
Co-directors Rob Epstein and Jeffrey Friedman never quite pull it off - although you can see how they might have.
Damon's presence greatly alleviates the been-there feel of this Elysium excursion, which starts to run out of steam when the usual explosive heroics kick in.
Even knowing the outcome ... doesn't diminish the intensity and awe of watching it recreated in this deftly framed docudrama by prodigious Icelandic auteur Kormakur.
Radishes, cabbages and melons meet horrific ends in Berberian Sound Studio, a down-the-earhole psychodrama where what you hear is more terrifying than what you see.
The Smurfs 2 has everything you hated about the first movie, and more.
It no longer seems very smart (the YouTube and texting references are so 2010) and it's also not much fun anymore.
Marling has a focus and poise that keeps us invested in her character's journey - even when the film begins to falter, as The East eventually does through inconsistency and expedience.

It leaves us not only with an unforgettable final image, but also the troubling thought that witch hunts, like war, will always be with us - all the more so in the modern era of instant communication.
One of the best films of 2013 and the irresistible climax to Richard Linklater's trilogy of on-the-run amour.

Sci-fi hits the skids as bad melodrama rules, and we get such risible dialogue as, "It's not really me you like, it's this body" and "I'm still of two minds." And how about this groaner: "Kiss me like you want to get slapped."

There are no easy villains or heroes in this sad and slow but forcefully told tale, which exhibits the same humanity Mungiu brought to 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days, his abortion drama that won the 2007 Palme d'Or.
Emperor falls prey to the temptations endemic to historical docudrama: the desire to pack a miniseries' worth of events into one feature-length film, with romance tossed in for added appeal.
Do any fresh revelations or insights remain, a half century past Monroe's overdose death at age 36?
The really scary thing about Fede Alvarez's Evil Dead is its failure to shock. Are we all now completely desensitized to movie horror?
This movie doesn't just stand the test of time, it transcends it.
Meanings are multiple, debatable and ultimately pointless. What really impresses about Upstream Color is Carruth's confident navigation of this fast river of ideas ...
Kiarostami's apparent simplicity masks serious complexity.
Danny Boyle seems to have had a blast making Trance. It's a pity he makes it so difficult to share in his joy.
It's like a giant explosion on a distant planet, observed but not felt.
Cianfrance and his sterling cast keep it all together, vanquishing doubt and soap suds. There's a palpable sense of teamwork that brings out the best in all of these players.

To the Wonder suggests the creep of doubt and possibly even despair into Malick's cosmic questing. This may not be as profound as he intends - to be human is to forever question - but it makes for stimulating viewing.
Neither as thrilling nor as funny as it ought to be.
You need better dialogue than Berger supplies to help It's a Disaster make a liar out of its title.
Oblivion gives us stars in the cast, stars in our eyes and it even tweaks a brain cell or three.
A Romeo and Juliet story for the age of CGI overkill, Upside Down zigs where it should zag and dulls where it should dazzle.
The more you see of the movie and the more elaborate the tricks get, the less you are inclined to believe that humans rather than machines are in charge of the illusions.
A mesmerizing, realistic and often hilarious look at the politics of power and the power of ideas ...
A mother's love for her child takes on brutal new meaning in Pieta, a film by Kim Ki-duk that's as hard to watch as it is to forget.
It all goes down shockingly well, even if Butler lacks the sarcastic wit of a Bruce Willis or Arnold Schwarzenegger and even as the film keeps upping the eye-rolling quotient with cartoon characters.
The only value in watching it is to see an expensive disaster slowly unfold.
This is a mature rom-com, if that's not a contradiction in terms.
It's cultural commentary as blunt instrument - and as blunt instruments are wont to do, it achieves an end while making a bloody mess.
You barely get a chance to catch a breath as this saga takes off like a starship and just keeps going, from its Indiana Jones-style opening to its cosmos-rattling finale. And all in 3D, no less.
The picture disturbs more than it amuses, but the overall effect is ultimately as scattershot as the ammo.
The clock starts to drag, and some energy is lost. But the movie displays a lot of promise both in front of and behind the lens.
We're ... reminded of what this movie could have been, had not Luhrmann hit the autopilot switch and allowed Fitzgerald to do all the dramatic thinking for him.
Quietly observes a love tested by infirmity and bureaucracy, becoming all the stronger for it.
Downey is in fine comic form, especially when he's sparring with young Simpkins, who thankfully throttles back on the precociousness.
The Colony is a blue-bin blockbuster, a collection of recycled ideas of sci-fi thrillers past.
The human brain is a marvellously suggestible organ.
The film is fine summer entertainment for people who don't take their movies or themselves too seriously.
Quote not available.
In a time when vacant retreads such as The Fast and the Furious are the problem, Vanishing Point is the answer.

Documentarian Mark Hopkins does not try to exploit emotions, and he doesn't need to. You're left in the position of one exhausted doctor who asks: how can you not do something when you know so much needs to be done?
movie_title: Living in Emergency: Stories of Doctors Without Borders (2010)

movie_review_blurb: If he were judged solely by the first five minutes of his films, Jean-Pierre Jeunet would rank among the world's top filmmakers. Unfortunately, the remaining 100 minutes or so place him among the most overrated.
This latest in the slumming mini-genre offers a couple of new wrinkles: Michael Caine and self-righteous, soul-satisfying vigilante justice.
By the fourth time Michael Douglas wakes up hungover and shirtless on a sour double bed, we get it: he's old. Can we move on?
Compelling both as drama and as an indictment of the eight years of folly known as the War on Terror.
A gang ofelderly morons have sex with garbage. What more can I say about Trash Humpers?
It might be G-rated, but Toy Story 3 is fully mature.
As oblique and laconic as its characters, Tabakman's moral tale rises to a melancholy spirituality.
The six and a half hours of Matthew Barney's Cremaster Cycle is sheer movie tedium, inert and unmoving, broken up by imagery that's more irritating than fascinating in its self-indulgent preciosity.
Charming as always, Jordan goes a little easier on his foolish mortals this time, but only at the expense of increased melodrama, cliché, and sentimentality.
Sumptuous, overheated, and ridiculous, Love is a visual delight -- the opening montage of a snowy Milan alone make it worthwhile
There's no excuse for Stephenie Meyer's terrible writing. And now her mind-numbing logorrhea has overwhelmed whatever salvage operation the big screen can offer.
Watching such naked emotion seems almost indecent. Isn't it a kind of voyeurism, well-intended or not?
Jim Thompson might be the darkest of noir writers, but Michael Winterbottom's version of Thompson's 1952 novel reduces its mirthful nihilism to lurid unpleasantness.

Kind of like what Wim Wenders did in Wings of Desire, but here it's all hot air.
Elliptical, nuanced, and non-judgmental, with hilariously genuine dialogue and exquisite performances, all of it observed with the probing eye of a Frederick Wiseman documentary.
Natali explores this hoary theme with apt, flippant gravity, updating it with canny hipness, but subjecting it to too many mutations to bring it fully to life.
The songs are rousing, but it takes more than a soundtrack to make a revolution.
Funny and heartbreaking.

Watching a James Ivory film is like entering a room aglow with plush furniture and exuding tasteful music and promising comfort and a brush with sensuality. The people inhabiting that space, however, vary in appeal.
movie_title: The City of Your Final Destination (2010)

movie_review_blurb: In her debut feature, Jordan Scott (daughter of Ridley) has conjured a lovely oddity combining elements of The Prime of Miss Brodie, The Children's Hour, If, The Belles of St. Trinian's, and even a bit of Lord of the Flies.
Kevin Hamedani's muddy, heavy-handed parody of War on Terror paranoia doesn't vary much from genre formula, but it does serve up political correctness with refreshingly bad taste.
The battles possess their own daffy clarity and logic.
Kind of like John Carney's 2006 hardscrabble charmer Once, only with morality police and sharia law.
movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Kim fills up his vast Gobi Desert location with stunts and chases where Leone in his wisdom knew when stillness and empty space were required. But be patient: in the final, triangular showdown, Kim does justice to the master.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A pointless, uninspired rehash, it begs contemporary relevance by making what might be half-hearted gestures at Tea Party discontent with repeated bromides condemning taxation and demanding the right to bear arrows and poach the king's deer.
Don't expect intensity of any kind in Bujalski's films; the emotions range from mild annoyance to bemusement, but within that minimal palette he's a master.

Icelandic writer/director Dagur Kári embraces the deadpan, absurdist comedy of Finland's Aki Kaurismäki and Norway's Bent Hamer, but in place of the usual laconic antihero, he offers Cox's bellowing, Beethoven-maned troglodyte.
[A] brooding, uneven, but ultimately satisfying venture into levity, Loach style.

For about an hour, Josh and Benny Safdie's trendy indie about a deadbeat dad taking care of his two boys for two weeks in Manhattan seems like the kind of movie in which you hate everybody -- especially the directors.
Like the seashells treasured by the Hawaiian princess of the title, Marc Forby's bio-pic is gaudy, brittle, and hollow.
Perhaps the most prominent characters in the film are the trains themselves. They keep roaring past and taking the camera into dark tunnels, a ubiquitous, vaguely malignant presence.
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Maybe Romero is pursuing a Marxist project by analyzing feudal modes of production, but his real problem is coming up with new ways of shooting people in the head.
Provokes and fascinates.
movie_title: Harlan - Im Schatten von Jud Süss (Harlan: In the Shadow of Jew Seuss) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Mann seems undecided about what he wants Enemies to accomplish, so he tries a little bit of everything.
The Israeli Defense Forces, as depicted in the movie, seem a bunch of crybabies. Well, they have a hard time of it, encountering some of the more predictable of war's horrors, ironies, and clichés.
Shot mostly in a chiaroscuro black and white, with color interludes for the flashbacks and for surreal ballet sequences in the mode of Michael Powell's The Red Shoes, Tetro rewards the eye.
The set-up alone has some of the funniest semen humor since There's Something About Mary.
Veteran Hong Kong filmmaker To mixes the grand gestures of John Woo with the tactics of Christopher Nolan's Memento; the result ranges from the silly to the sublime.
Alamar is worth seeing, if only for the cattle egret that puts in the year's best animal performance.
Sitting through Rob Reiner's adaptation of Wendelin Van Draanen's YA novel is like watching the summer's worst movie -- twice.
It's good to see the Turkish-German filmmaker lighten up in this broad, rough-around the edges comedy...
Movie allusions ultimately do Corbijn in ... he breaks the unwritten rule never to show a scene from a movie that's better than yours.
Amir Bar-Lev's infuriating, heartbreaking account of the life, death, and afterlife of NFL star turned problematic war hero Pat Tillman.
Kind of a low-rent GoodFellas with no voiceover narrator.
Regardless of its lapses, [it] is a reminder that at one time cinéastes could put together a formidable street demonstration...
movie_title: Two in the Wave (Deux de la Vague) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: In terms of character and plot, The Town doesn't challenge conventionality. Where it excels is in sustaining mood, and this has a lot to do with the performances.
Some realities even the best propagandists can't spin.
In his first feature, TV veteran Pascal Chaumeil demonstrates a flair for schmaltz and pratfalls, evoking nostalgia for a time when French cinema wasn't a farm league for American studios.
Next to the Internet's capacity for deception, alienation, and personal reinvention, Michelangelo Antonioni's existential quandaries seem quaint.
As far as missing-bridegroom movies go, this is less inspiring than The Hangover.
Awful music, obnoxious editing, overwrought camera work, and strained comedy can't hide the hackneyed, smarmy pointlessness of it all.
Stone jazzes up the dry proceedings with fancy filmic footwork, but even he is no match for derivatives.
By the end, you won't need to slice onions to get the tear ducts working.
You can't get enough Happiness -- or so Todd Solondz must have thought when he spun off this sour sequel to his 1998 misanthropic ode to suburban perversion.
[A] lumbering, aptly titled hulk of a movie.
Unpretentious, engrossing...
[This] investigation into the dark regions of horror, culpability, and memory is all the more powerful because of his film's rueful hilarity.
A familiar scenario both here and in China, but Jia Zhang-ke has shaped it into a complex and lucid cinematic poem about identity, transience, and loss.
This last motif surges in the film's coda with a sequence that is 2002's most rapturous, a long, undulating shot that combines serenity and horror.

First-time directors Chris Renaud and Pierre Coffin and the other filmmakers behind this slight but engaging kids' animated comedy have no ambitions to be original, but like their villainous hero, Gru, they insist on stealing only from the best.
If there's a way to make this riveting on screen, the Swedes adapting the first two books haven't figured it out.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: At a spry 100 years old, Manoel de Oliveira has conjured a brilliant miniature, a Buñuelesque daydream with the look of a Vermeer.
Cage and Molina add magic, but not enough.
Could Michael Cera be getting more vaporous with each repeat of his epicene screen persona?
Personally, I got more thrills out of the simple animation of Richard Linklater's Waking Life.
My advice is to stay away from Elizabeth Allen's bland and banal adaptation, which plays like a contemporary Leave It to Beaver without irony or ingenuousness.
Maren Ade's moody character study evokes such classics as Voyage to Italy, Knife in theWater, and L'Avventura in its romantic ennui...
Hovers between the trauma of Pier Paolo Pasolini's Salò and the creepiness of Michael Haneke's The Seventh Continent.
The ending might be predictable, but it shows that you're never too old to enjoy the bliss of love -- or suffer its pains.
When the most endearing character is a mouse corpse dressed in a tiny suit, you suspect that the rest of this Dinner might not agree with you.
By far the funnier of the summer's two comedies featuring an accountant...
Duvall adds sparkle with his cryptic decrepitude -- until that becomes as mannered and canned as the rest of the movie.
[A] charming, uplifting, and very funny subversion of the traditional patriarchal family.

movie_title: In Search of Memory (Auf der Suche nach dem Gedächtnis) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: I can't speak for the kids, but I would rate Spike Jonze & Dave Eggers's adaptation of Maurice Sendak's 40-page children's picture book up there with Up and WallE as topping the recent renaissance in children's movies.

Woody Allen might have passed on making this film 35 years ago because it was too dated and middlebrow.
Doomsday is good therapy. What does it matter that billions die if that brings a family together in one big hug?
It's all a creepy mishmash of sci-fi and fantasy classics that director Jorge Blanco tarts up with an unwholesome preoccupation with pee, anal plugs, and homosexual anxiety.
The film comes close to collapsing into exploitation or self-parody. Thank Sidibe's extraordinary performance that it doesn't.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: For those who found the Coen Brothers' adaptation of Cormac McCarthy's No Country for Old Men too lighthearted, John Hillcoat's relentlessly faithful version of the author's post-apocalyptic Pulitzer-winning novel might hit the spot.

movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Count me among the few not captivated by Anderson's animated adaptation of Roald Dahl's book; I found it as stilted and twee as the title canid's tippy-toe gait.
